para.paratext: (1) A court may predicate error, set aside or reverse a judgment, or grant a new trial on the basis of admitted or excluded evidence when a substantial right of the party is adversely affected and:

(a) When the ruling is one admitting evidence, a timely objection or motion to strike appears on the record, stating the specific ground of objection if the specific ground was not apparent from the context; or
(b) When the ruling is one excluding evidence, the substance of the evidence was made known to the court by offer of proof or was apparent from the context within which the questions were asked.

If the court has made a definitive ruling on the record admitting or excluding evidence, either at or before trial, a party need not renew an objection or offer of proof to preserve a claim of error for appeal.
(2) In cases tried by a jury, a court shall conduct proceedings, to the maximum extent practicable, in such a manner as to prevent inadmissible evidence from being suggested to the jury by any means.
(3) Nothing in this section shall preclude a court from taking notice of fundamental errors affecting substantial rights, even though such errors were not brought to the attention of the trial judge.

Subsection (1) This section amplifies § 59.041 of the Florida Statutes in stating the “harmless error” rule as it applies to evidentiary rulings by the court. In addition to the requirement that a substantial right of a party be affected, the nature of the error must be called to the attention of the court so that proper remedial measures by judge and counsel may be taken. The objection and the offer of proof are the means to accomplish that goal. The Florida cases have long followed this rule. In Butler v. State, 94 Fla. 163, 113 So. 699 (1927) the court said:
Technical error, committed by a trial court in the reception or rejection of evidence, does not necessarily constitute harmful error.
It is injury resulting from error that warrants an appellate court in reversing a judgment of the trial court.

The provisions of § 59.041 regarding other alleged errors are not affected. The question of harmless constitutional error is not covered by this section but is examined in Chapman v. State of California, 386 U.S. 18, 87 S.Ct. 824, 17 L.Ed.2d 705 (1967).

Existing Florida law also requires that a timely specific objection be made to preserve the point on appeal; see Nat Harrison Associates, Inc. v. Byrd, 256 So.2d 50 (Fla.4th Dist. 1971); Hanisch v. Wilder, 210 So.2d 491 (Fla.3rd Dist. 1968), and that an offer of proof be made when the evidence is excluded unless the answer is apparent from the question asked, see Browder v. Da Costa, 91 Fla. 1, 109 So. 448 (1926). Fla.R.Civ.Pro. 1.450(b) provides that the court may add to the offer that shows the character of the evidence, the form in which it was offered, the objection made and the ruling thereon in order to reproduce for higher tribunals, as exactly as possible, a reproduction of the events in the trial court. Rule 1.450(b) also allows the court to exercise its discretion to produce on the record, in both jury and non-jury cases, what the witness's testimony would have been if the question had been answered.
Similar provisions are contained in Fed.Rule Evid. 103, Calif.Evid.Code §§ 353-54, Kansas Code of Civ.Pro. §§ 60-404, 60-405 and Uniform Rules 4 and 5 [1953].

Subsection (2) A ruling which excludes evidence is a pointlessly formal and ritualistic procedure if the excluded evidence nevertheless comes to the attention of the jury. Bruton v. United States, 389 U.S. 818, 88 S.Ct. 126, 19 L.Ed.2d 70 (1968). Both Fed.R.Civ.Pro. 43(c) and Fla.R.Civ.Pro. 1.450(b) provide that “[t]he court may require the offer to be made out of the hearing of the jury.” Additionally, this section provides that preliminary questions upon which the offer is based do not have to first be asked in the jury's presence. A similar provision is contained in Fed.Rule Evid. 103.

Subsection (3) The purpose of this subsection, which is in accord with Fed.R.Crim.Pro. 2(b), is to allow appellate courts to raise issues sua sponte. Under Fla.R.Civ.Pro. 1.530, the judge may order a new trial or rehearing and under Fla.R.Crim.Pro. 3.580 order a new trial or arrest the judgment.

The subsection is applicable to both criminal and civil cases although it is traditional that only in criminal cases have appellate courts displayed unwillingness to be bound by breakdowns in the adversary system, although, numerous examples exist with the same effects in civil cases. See Campbell, Extent to Which Courts of Review will Consider Questions Not Properly Raised and Preserved, 7 Wis.L.Rev. 91 (1932); Vestal, Sua Sponte Consideration in Appellate Review, 27 Fordham L.Rev. 477 (1958-59). Generally, this section will be applied more often when evidence is erroneously admitted since the failure to comply with the requirements of offer of proof will result in an absence of material in the record to disclose the error.
A similar provision is contained in Fed.Rule Evid. 103. See McCormick, Evidence § 52 (2nd ed. 1972).

Laws 1977, c. 77-174, a reviser's bill, amended subsec. (1)(a) of this section by inserting “appears” following “motion to strike” editorially inserted in Fla.St.1976, Supp. in the interest of clarity by the division of statutory revision and indexing.

Laws 2003, c. 2003-259, § 1, added “If the court has made a definitive ruling on the record admitting or excluding evidence, either at or before trial, a party need not renew an objection or offer of proof to preserve a claim of error for appeal” at the end of the subsection.
For rule relating to rulings on evidence, see Rule 103, Fed.Rules Evid., 28 U.S.C.A.
For rules relating to rulings on evidence, see Rule 103, Uniform Laws Annotated, Master Edition, vol. 13.

head.head.info: 1. Construction and application

para.paratext: "Proffer" is preservation for record purposes of excluded evidence, and requires only sufficient offer of proof of excluded testimony. Taylor v. State, Dept. of Transp., App. 2 Dist., 701 So.2d 610, 22 Fla. L. Weekly D2513 (1997). Appeal And Error  499(3)

Rulings as to admissibility of evidence in civil actions are traditionally made at trial and such rulings often depend upon availability of other evidence. Meehan v. Seaboard Air Line R. Co., App. 3 Dist., 210 So.2d 476 (1968). Trial  43
Where improper evidence has been admitted, the court should exclude it in express terms, and not by implication. Louisville & N.R. Co. v. Collinsworth, 45 Fla. 403, 33 So. 513 (1903). Trial  98

head.head.info: 2. Prejudicial effect of ruling

para.paratext: Error in the admission of evidence is not ground for reversal if not prejudicial to the rights of the complaining party. Groover v. Hammond, 73 Fla. 1155, 75 So. 857 (1917); City of Key West v. Baldwin, 69 Fla. 136, 67 So. 808 (1915); Tampa & J. Ry. Co. v. Crawford, 67 Fla. 77, 64 So. 437 (1914), followed in Seaboard Air Line Ry. Co. v. Stephens, 114 So. 672, 94 Fla. 965; Atlantic Coast Line R. Co. v. Peoples, 56 Fla. 145, 47 So. 392 (1908); Bacon v. Green, 36 Fla. 325, 18 So. 870 (1895).

Personal representative of patient's estate did not suffer substantial prejudice as result of trial court's ruling prohibiting the elicitation of evidence from expert witness's deposition that expert allegedly had originally been retained by internist, and thus personal representative was not entitled to new trial in medical malpractice action against internist, his practice, and other defendants. Dones v. Moss, App. 2 Dist., 884 So.2d 230 (2004), rehearing denied. New Trial  41(2)

Personal representative of patient's estate did not suffer substantial prejudice as result of trial court's ruling limiting personal representative to two standard-of-care experts in internal or family medicine, and thus personal representative was not entitled to new trial in medical malpractice action against internist, his practice, and other defendants; number of experts that personal representative was allowed to retain was same as total number of defendant's experts. Dones v. Moss, App. 2 Dist., 884 So.2d 230 (2004), rehearing denied. New Trial  41(2)

In close cases of contested fact, where misleading testimony is improperly admitted, Supreme Court must accept it as having been tendered by a party and admitted by court for purpose of establishing some fact vitally necessary to prove the case, or as having a tendency to influence jury in reaching a conclusion and where a verdict is obtained in favor of party insisting on introduction of such testimony, court cannot say testimony had no effect and was harmless. Perper v. Edell, 44 So.2d 78 (1949). Appeal And Error  1050.1(1)

head.head.info: 3. Substantial rights

para.paratext: A judgment will not be set aside on ground of an improper ruling on evidence unless it appears that error injuriously affected substantial rights of complaining party. Reliable Services, Inc. v. Taft, App. 3 Dist., 247 So.2d 97 (1971). Appeal And Error  1047(1)

In action to recover on hull policy for fire damage to aircraft, any error in admitting over objection testimony that insureds' agent refused to take lie detector test and testimony of deputy fire marshal as to cause of fire did not affect substantial rights of insureds and was not reversible error. Leeb v. Read, App. 3 Dist., 190 So.2d 830 (1966). Appeal And Error  1050.1(5)

A judgment will not be set aside on ground of improper rejection of evidence unless it appears that error complained of has resulted in a miscarriage of justice or that error injuriously affected substantial rights of complaining party. Atlantic Coast Line R. Co. v. Ganey, App. 3 Dist., 125 So.2d 576 (1960). Appeal And Error  1056.1(1)

Error in rulings upon evidence does not warrant reversal or new trial unless it appears from entire case that substantial rights of complaining party were injuriously affected. Prince v. Aucilla River Naval Stores Co., 103 Fla. 605, 137 So. 886 (1931). Appeal And Error  1047(1)

head.head.info: 4. Books and documents--In general

para.paratext: Denial of appellant-defendants' pretrial and posttrial motions for order requiring plaintiff to produce for inspection and copying the agreement which he had entered into before trial with the remaining defendants was error, which, though it did not result in prejudicial harm during trial, could not be determined to be harmless with regard to entry of judgment. Ward v. Ochoa, App. 4 Dist., 271 So.2d 173 (1972), remanded 284 So.2d 385. Appeal And Error  1043(6); Appeal And Error  1047(5); Evidence  368(2); Pretrial Procedure  376

Where two expert witnesses testified independently that under-inflation or overloading, or both, caused tire to blow out and that there was no manufacturing defect in tire, plaintiff's witness could not testify as to what caused the tire to blow out or whether there was manufacturing defect and pamphlet introduced by tire manufacturer was merely cumulative of the experts' testimony, error, if any, in admission of pamphlet which contained hearsay was harmless error. Farmer v. B. F. Goodrich Co., App. 2 Dist., 252 So.2d 593 (1971), certiorari denied 255 So.2d 686. Appeal And Error  1050.1(11)

In action against owner of hotel for burns suffered by plaintiff guest when struck by flame during preparation of cherries jubilee by headwaiter, any error in admitting into evidence portions of Florida Hotel and Restaurant Commission regulations and fire marshal's regulations was harmless to hotel owner which admitted that jury could have found headwaiter guilty of simple negligence and trial judge did not instruct jury that violation of regulations would justify award of punitive damages. St. Petersburg Sheraton Corp. v. Stuart, App. 2 Dist., 242 So.2d 185 (1970). Appeal And Error  1050.1(11)

Ledger book in which entries were made from memory by the husband or wife after about a week or ten days following completion of each job was not admissible in evidence in mortgage foreclosure action to prove certain payments were made on note, since entries were not made contemporaneously with the transactions involved and were not made in regular course of business, and admission of ledger book was prejudicial error since it formed the sole basis for certain claimed setoffs. E. Z. E. Inc. v. Jackson, App. 4 Dist., 235 So.2d 337 (1970). Appeal And Error  1050.1(11); Evidence  354(10)

Permitting defense counsel to read to jury court reporter's transcript of testimony plaintiff had previously given at workmen's compensation hearing, at which plaintiff had attributed all his difficulties to prior automobile accident and related that he had suffered little trauma or discomfort as result of subsequent accident with defendant, was error in absence of showing that plaintiff's counsel had agreed that transcript was admissible without authentication, and error required reversal in view of verdict that plaintiff take nothing. DeLong v. Williams, App. 4 Dist., 232 So.2d 246 (1970). Appeal And Error  1050.1(11); Evidence  366(7)

Trial court's permitting weather report indicating maximum recorded wind gusts during hurricane were 135 miles per hour at elevation of 111 feet to go to jury after plaintiff in breach of contract action had introduced evidence that highest recorded velocity was 100 miles per hour at elevation of 23 feet was not reversible error. Eastern Air Lines, Inc. v. J. A. Jones Const. Co., App. 3 Dist., 223 So.2d 332 (1969), certiorari denied 229 So.2d 868. Appeal And Error  1050.1(11)

Error in permitting a witness to detail the terms of a written contract in evidence was harmless where there was no dispute as to the correctness of the terms in the writing, and the testimony of the witness corresponded therewith. Roof v. Chattanooga Wood Split Pulley Co., 36 Fla. 284, 18 So. 597 (1895). Appeal And Error  1051(4)

head.head.info: 5. ---- Photographs, books and documents

para.paratext: In personal injury action, trial court did not commit reversible error in admitting photograph taken after collision depicting armored truck in which plaintiffs were riding where judge cautioned jury regarding purposes for which photos were being admitted notwithstanding defense contention that photos did not accurately depict damage done to truck. Waller v. Traud, App. 3 Dist., 301 So.2d 127 (1974). Appeal And Error  1050.1(11)

Permitting patient who brought malpractice action against hospital and surgeon for injuries arising out of removal of both breasts to introduce color photograph depicting breasts after mastectomy was not reversible error. Variety Children's Hospital v. Osle, App. 3 Dist., 292 So.2d 382 (1974). Appeal And Error  1050.1(11)

Exclusion of photographs bearing on extent of injuries of minor plaintiff taken upon child's release from hospital was not reversible error where liability was not established. Oliva v. Baum, App. 3 Dist., 194 So.2d 319 (1967). Appeal And Error  1056.4

head.head.info: 6. Affidavits

para.paratext: Failure to object contemporaneously to admission of affidavits in connection with motion for summary judgment constitutes waiver of right to appellate review of issue. O'Quinn v. Seibels, Bruce & Co., App. 1 Dist., 447 So.2d 369 (1984). Appeal And Error  223

As with other evidentiary matters, admission and consideration of affidavits on motion for summary judgment is matter within sound discretion of trial court, and no error may be predicated on such admission absent timely objection or motion to strike. O'Quinn v. Seibels, Bruce & Co., App. 1 Dist., 447 So.2d 369 (1984). Judgment  185.1(1); Judgment  186

head.head.info: 7. Examination of witnesses--In general

para.paratext: After defendant asserted claim for ineffective assistance of trial counsel, trial court should have allowed defendant to proffer witnesses' testimony to permit him to complete his record rather than taking testimony of trial counsel but declining to hear other witnesses subpoenaed by defendant and, thus, defendant was entitled to remand to permit him to proffer testimony. Porro v. State, App. 3 Dist., 656 So.2d 587 (1995). Criminal Law  1181.5(6); Criminal Law  1614

Discharged employee who sued union for alleged arbitrariness, discrimination, and bad faith in representing him at discharge proceedings should have been allowed to call retired union official as adverse witness, but error did not require reversal where witness could not have given testimony supporting allegations. Farmer v. Brotherhood of R.R. Trainmen, App. 3 Dist., 258 So.2d 503 (1972). Appeal And Error  1048(1); Witnesses  276

head.head.info: 8. ---- Competency of witnesses, examination of witnesses

para.paratext: Even if it was error to admit the opinion of an expert because it was based on facts not yet disclosed by him, the error was cured by afterwards bringing out all of the facts within the knowledge of the witness. Aetna Life Ins. Co. v. Caffee, 1923, 286 F. 657. Federal Courts  900

In action by father of fatally injured guest against mother of driver of automobile, which failed to negotiate curve and slid into two palm trees, court properly held that police officer, who had attended four and a half months in traffic police administration including subjects dealing with physical laws and accident investigation and who had conducted various experiments with various types of automobiles and on various surfaces to provide a backlog of statistical information and who had personally conducted more than 6,500 tests, was qualified to testify as an expert and court did not commit prejudicial error in permitting officer to testify as to critical speed of a certain type automobile rounding the curve in question. Myers v. Korbly, App. 2 Dist., 103 So.2d 215 (1958). Appeal And Error  1048(2); Evidence  539

Where, in malpractice actions against doctors for loss of infant's fingers and thumb due to doctors' alleged negligence in treating poor circulation in daughter's arm immediately after birth, jury could have found, as matter of their own common knowledge and experience and independent of expert testimony as to acceptable medical practice, that fingers and thumb of premature infant were needlessly burned off and that such could not be considered acceptable medical practice in any community, allowing testimony of physicians from outside state to testify as to propriety and acceptability of treatment administered to infant was not reversible error in view of fact that only testimony of one such doctor on issue of proximate cause was needed to sustain verdicts of jury. Montgomery v. Stary, 84 So.2d 34 (1955). Appeal And Error  1048(2)

Alleged erroneous action of trial court in permitting witness, who had been adjudged mentally incompetent, to testify as a witness without qualifying examination, did not constitute reversible or prejudicial error, in view of clear and coherent manner in which testimony of witness was given, and his evidence capacity as a witness. Florida Power & Light Co. v. Robinson, 68 So.2d 406 (1953). Appeal And Error  1048(2)

head.head.info: 9. ---- Credibility of witnesses, examination of witnesses

para.paratext: Trial court properly refused to allow inquiry into substance of conversations which three arresting police officers had with state attorney in presence of each other since, once fact that said witnesses were interviewed in presence of each other prior to trial became known, trier of fact was in position to consider credibility of witnesses, the only proper use of such fact. A. McD. v. State, App. 3 Dist., 422 So.2d 336 (1982). Witnesses  268(9)

Where reputation of plaintiffs' expert witness was not relevant or material to issues in breach of contract action and no foundation was laid for injury into character of plaintiffs' witness, permitting defendant's witness to answer inquiry as to reputation of plaintiffs' witness among others of same occupation for ability was reversible error. Ecker v. National Roofing of Miami, Inc., App. 3 Dist., 201 So.2d 586 (1967). Appeal And Error  1048(7); Evidence  560

head.head.info: 10. ---- Form of question, examination of witnesses

para.paratext: Allowing insurer's expert medical witness to give, over insured's objection, an expert psychiatric opinion based on a hypothetical question which contained no history pertaining to insured's preexisting psychiatric problem was reversible error, where there was nothing in record to conclusively refute claim that disability for which suit was brought resulted from fact that injury triggered a disabling aggravation of a psychoneurotic condition and insured's psychological history was a fact which was obviously necessary to formation of an opinion by expert. Steiger v. Massachusetts Cas. Ins. Co., App. 3 Dist., 273 So.2d 4 (1973). Appeal And Error  1048(3); Evidence  553(2)

Permitting answers to plaintiff's hypothetical questions lacking proper predicate could not be considered as harmless where answers would have permitted jury to infer that plaintiff's decedent was driving at a proper rate of speed and collided with defendants' vehicle traveling at an unreasonably low rate of speed. Nat Harrison Associates, Inc. v. Byrd, App. 4 Dist., 256 So.2d 50 (1971). Appeal And Error  1048(1)

Trial court committed harmful error in allowing expert witness to answer hypothetical question which contained assumptions based on expert's opinion as to the speed of automobiles and drivers' reaction time. Autrey v. Carroll, 240 So.2d 474 (1970), conformed to 242 So.2d 174. Appeal And Error  1048(2); Evidence  553(3)

In personal injury action, where liability was conceded and issue was solely on question of injuries and damages to plaintiff, permitting plaintiff's medical witness to answer question asked by plaintiff's counsel as to whether plaintiff made any complaint about having nausea or loss of appetite did not constitute prejudicial error even though question was leading. Florida Motor Lines Corp. v. Barry, 158 Fla. 123, 27 So.2d 753 (1946). Appeal And Error  1048(3)

head.head.info: 11. ---- Error in question cured by answer or failure to answer, examination of witnesses

para.paratext: Hypothetical question proposed to defendant's expert witness improperly sought to elicit an opinion of witness as to validity of opinions expressed by plaintiff's expert witnesses; however, the error in overruling objection to question was harmless where defendant's expert in his answer failed to express any opinion as to validity or invalidity of opinions of plaintiff's expert witnesses. Carlton v. Bielling, App. 1 Dist., 146 So.2d 915 (1962). Appeal And Error  1048(5); Evidence  553(1)

A hypothetical question improperly framed, but allowed over objection, does not constitute reversible error, if witness admits his inability to answer the question as framed. Atlantic Coast Line R. Co. v. Brash, 73 Fla. 478, 74 So. 503 (1917). Appeal And Error  1048(5)

Any error in not sustaining objection to a question is harmless, the answer not disclosing anything not properly admissible. Younglove v. Knox, 44 Fla. 743, 33 So. 427 (1902). Appeal And Error  1048(5)

head.head.info: 12. ---- Rebuttal witnesses, examination of witnesses

para.paratext: In action by condominium against paint seller for breach of implied warranty of merchantability, trial court erred in refusing to permit condominium to use rebuttal witnesses to show that, contrary to testimony of seller's witnesses, paint was properly applied. Blair House South v. All Florida Paint Store, Inc., App. 3 Dist., 435 So.2d 971 (1983). Trial  62(1)

head.head.info: 13. ---- Cross-examination and re-examination of witnesses

para.paratext: Error in trial court's refusal to allow defendant to cross-examine arresting officer regarding five prior complaints of excessive force leveled against officer was not harmless error in trial for resisting arrest without violence; defendant and officer were only witnesses, and each presented different version of events. Michael v. State, App. 2 Dist., 884 So.2d 83 (2004). Criminal Law  1170.5(1)

Cross-examination extends to entire subject matter, and to all matters that may modify, supplement, contradict, rebut or make clearer facts testified to in chief. Buford v. State, 403 So.2d 943 (1981), certiorari denied 102 S.Ct. 1037, 454 U.S. 1163, 71 L.Ed.2d 319, certiorari denied 102 S.Ct. 1039, 454 U.S. 1164, 71 L.Ed.2d 320. Witnesses  268(1)

Error in refusing to permit former employer, which contended that two checks given to former employee were given as loans, to cross-examine the employee, who contended that the checks represented draws on commission, with respect to whether the checks had been reported as income on the employee's income tax returns was reversible. Lely Estates, Inc. v. Polly, App. 2 Dist., 308 So.2d 165 (1975), certiorari denied 316 So.2d 285. Appeal And Error  1048(6)

Restricting maker's cross-examination of payee and direct examination of maker of note where defense of fraud in the inducement was involved was not reversible error. Holm v. Woodworth, App. 4 Dist., 271 So.2d 167 (1972). Appeal And Error  1048(2); Appeal And Error  1048(6)

Where initial examination of defendant, in suit to recover real estate commission, by plaintiffs' counsel, who chose not to request that defendant be declared adverse or hostile during initial examination, contributed nothing to plaintiffs' case, later request to have defendant recalled as an adverse witness was essential to plaintiffs and court's refusal to permit defendant to be so called was prejudicial error. Goldberg v. Russo, App. 3 Dist., 233 So.2d 134 (1970). Appeal And Error  1048(6); Witnesses  283

Use of text identified by two expert witnesses as authoritative work on subject of gymnastics in cross-examination of director and head coach of defendant city's recreational program, the author of which was recognized by witness as authority in field, was not reversible error. City of St. Petersburg v. Ferguson, App. 2 Dist., 193 So.2d 648 (1966), certiorari denied 201 So.2d 556. Appeal And Error  1048(6)

Refusal to permit cross-examination of plaintiff with respect to his affidavit which had been filed in cause but withdrawn on motion and order without defendants' objection was not error, and any error was harmless where plaintiff's testimony was at most cumulative. Coleman v. Coleman, App. 1 Dist., 191 So.2d 460 (1966). Appeal And Error  1048(6); Witnesses  275(6)

Refusal to permit cross-examination of defendants' truck driver, on how long it was before driver came back and talked to other people, and what he did after parking tractor-trailer, on ground that this was not cross-examination of anything brought out on direct examination, was not prejudicial error. Huffman v. Peek, App. 2 Dist., 102 So.2d 641 (1958). Appeal And Error  1048(6)

In action for injury to theater patron by falling on step when patron was leaving theater due to alleged dangerous and slippery condition of step, refusal to permit cross-examination of theater owner's employee, who had testified on direct examination that after each accident he examined place of accident, to state the number of falls at such place prior to the accident, was fundamental error. Florida Coastal Theatres v. Belflower, 159 Fla. 741, 32 So.2d 738 (1947). Appeal And Error  1048(6); Witnesses  268(3)

In action for damages on a charge of wilfully and maliciously assaulting and beating plaintiff, where the cross-examiner had been permitted to bring out that plaintiff's witness was receiving a “certain retainer” from plaintiff for testifying, it was not prejudicial to defendant to refuse to permit witness to be questioned concerning the amount of compensation he was receiving. Pandula v. Fonseca, 145 Fla. 395, 199 So. 358 (1940). Appeal And Error  1048(6)

In action for damages to truck, sustaining objection to question on recross-examination of plaintiff as to how many “of these items have you been reimbursed for?” was not reversible error, where question was objected to on ground that there was no evidence that plaintiff had been paid for any items, and that question was not pertinent to anything brought out on direct examination. Allen v. Hooper, 126 Fla. 458, 171 So. 513 (1936). Appeal And Error  1048(6)
It is harmful error to deny right of cross-examination of witness to bring helpful light on subject of inquiry. Johnson v. Reynolds, 97 Fla. 591, 121 So. 793 (1929). Appeal And Error  1048(6)

head.head.info: 14. Impeachment of witnesses

para.paratext: Admission of hearsay impeaching testimony which went to the heart of case was not harmless error. Seaboard Coast Line R. Co. v. Hunt, App. 1 Dist., 299 So.2d 84 (1974), quashed 327 So.2d 193. Appeal And Error  1050.1(10)

Trial court erred in permitting plaintiff's attorney to use for impeachment purposes a written statement made by one defendant to an investigating officer from highway patrol shortly after highway accident which gave rise to litigation, but such error was harmless where similar written statement which had been given by defendant to his own employer shortly after the accident was properly admitted in evidence and evidence of statement given by defendant to highway patrolman was cumulative. Hall v. Haldane, App. 4 Dist., 268 So.2d 403 (1972), certiorari denied 268 So.2d 909. Appeal And Error  1048(7); Witnesses  392(1)

Where plaintiff in negligence action for back injury admitted, without objection, on cross-examination to all of her prior accidents, defendant's failure to introduce into evidence deposition used on cross-examination for purposes of impeachment was harmless error. Hicks v. Daymude, App. 1 Dist., 190 So.2d 6 (1966). Appeal And Error  1048(7)

Where counsel employed by automobile liability insurer to represent insured concluded that insured was not cooperating in action begun by automobile guest against insured and continued in name of executrix after death of guest with additional claim for wrongful death, and that the action was a collusive one, and that guest had been driving automobile at time of collision, rather than insured, as contended by insured, counsel's successful impeachment of insured constituted reversible error. Spadaro v. Palmisano, App. 3 Dist., 109 So.2d 418 (1959). Appeal And Error  1048(7); Witnesses  323

Where only testimony bearing directly on critical facts as to actual occurrence involved in negligence action was testimony of witness whose credibility was sought to be impeached by proof of his prior conviction for crime, erroneous refusal to permit impeachment by such proof would require reversal. McArthur v. Cook, 99 So.2d 565 (1957). Appeal And Error  1048(7)

head.head.info: 15. Contradictory evidence

para.paratext: Where plaintiff in personal injury action had testified that his condition of health had been perfect for past two years, prejudicial error was committed in rejecting evidence that he had been assigned permanent partial disability in workmen's compensation case and had, some months prior to trial, requested reopening of such case. Schield Bantum Co. v. Greif, App. 3 Dist., 161 So.2d 266 (1964). Appeal And Error  1048(7); Witnesses  406

Erroneous admission of a letter introduced to contradict a witness was harmless, where the witness' testimony was of little materiality. Tampa & J. Ry. Co. v. Crawford, 67 Fla. 77, 64 So. 437 (1914). Appeal And Error  1048(7)

head.head.info: 16. Irrelevant or immaterial evidence

para.paratext: The admission of irrelevant evidence is harmless error, where it was such as not to prejudice the complaining party. Nickels v. Mooring, 16 Fla. 76 (1877); Carter v. Bennett, C.A., 4 Fla. 283 (1852), appeal dismissed 15 How. 354, 14 L.Ed. 727.

Where contents of hearsay statement improperly admitted into evidence were neither relevant nor material to any issue in case and were adequately explained and clarified by other testimony of same witness offered by opponents on surrebuttal, admission of statement was harmless error. Seaboard Coast Line R. Co. v. Magnuson, App. 4 Dist., 288 So.2d 302 (1974), certiorari denied 297 So.2d 30. Appeal And Error  1050.2; Appeal And Error  1052(3)

In action against newspaper publisher for injuries suffered by delivery boy, an independent contractor, who fell from lowered tailgate of station wagon being driven by publisher's district manager for circulation, wherein evidence on issues of negligence and contributory negligence was balanced, evidence of prior accident in which another boy had fallen from tailgate of station wagon while being driven by same driver was irrelevant and immaterial and its admission was reversible error. Short v. Allen, App. 3 Dist., 254 So.2d 34 (1971). Appeal And Error  1050.2; Automobiles  243(5)

In action against other occupants of building for damage to tenant's property by fire allegedly caused by negligent use of acetylene torch by defendants' employees, where other evidence established that instrumentality which defendants contended caused fire had no connection with alleged contributory negligence of plaintiff, whether instrumentality had been repaired prior to fire was irrelevant and admitting hearsay testimony of electrical contractor that repair work had been completed in accordance with his instructions prior to fire was harmless error. Perma Spray Mfg. Co. v. La France Industries of Miami, Inc., App. 3 Dist., 161 So.2d 13 (1964), certiorari denied 168 So.2d 147. Appeal And Error  1050.2

New trial should not be granted if relevant testimony sustains verdict, though some irrelevant testimony was admitted. Davis v. Ivey, 93 Fla. 387, 112 So. 264 (1927), certiorari denied 48 S.Ct. 19, 275 U.S. 526, 72 L.Ed. 407. Appeal And Error  1050.2

A new trial will not be granted because immaterial evidence was introduced, unless the jury appears to have been misled. First Nat. Bank v. Roberts, 92 Fla. 18, 109 So. 635 (1926). Appeal And Error  1050.2

In the trial of a cause during the taking of evidence before a jury, if evidence is permitted which is irrelevant, but nevertheless operates to give an unfair advantage to one of the parties over the other, placing the latter in an unfavorable light and embarrassing his defense, a miscarriage of justice may reasonably be said to have occurred. Charlotte Harbor & N. Ry. Co. v. Truette, 81 Fla. 152, 87 So. 427 (1921). Appeal And Error  1050.2
The erroneous admission of evidence on an immaterial issue is harmless. Rhodus v. Heffernan, 47 Fla. 206, 36 So. 572 (1904). Appeal And Error  1050.3

head.head.info: 17. Opinions and conclusions

para.paratext: The erroneous admission of opinion evidence or a conclusion is harmless where the facts on which the opinion or conclusion is based are shown by proper evidence, and the opinion or conclusion is shown to be correct. McCallum v. Driggs, 35 Fla. 255, 17 So. 407 (1895); Jacksonville, T. & K.W. Ry. Co. v. Peninsular Land, Transp. & Mfg. Co., 27 Fla. 1, 157, 9 So. 661, 17 L.R.A. 33, 65 (1891).

In action challenging validity of tax assessment of property for 1970, no reversible error was committed when plaintiff's expert witness testified as to amount of 1969 assessment in discussing methods used by tax assessor's office. Culbertson v. Saga Development Corp., App. 3 Dist., 261 So.2d 538 (1972). Appeal And Error  1050.1(12)

Admission of testimony of expert witness, who was both metallurgist and mechanical engineer, that defendant driver was traveling at 50 to 55 miles per hour on road with 45 miles per hour speed limit was not prejudicial error, in action against automobile driver, owner of automobile and driver's employer for injuries sustained by plaintiffs in automobile accident allegedly resulting from defendant driver's negligence, even though there were conflicts in the testimony, where expert employed assumptions which were favorable to owner of automobile, and testimony was cumulative with other evidence that defendant driver was inattentive or speeding, or both. International Sales-Rentals Leasing Co. v. Nearhoof, App. 3 Dist., 251 So.2d 349 (1971), certiorari denied 255 So.2d 682. Appeal And Error  1050.1(12)

Where physician was an examining physician rather than a treating physician, it was reversible error to admit his testimony relating to his estimate of plaintiff's disability when opinion was based on combination of personal observation and history of case as told to him by plaintiff. Bondy v. West, App. 2 Dist., 219 So.2d 117 (1969). Appeal And Error  1050.1(12); Evidence  548; Evidence  555.10

head.head.info: 18. Other evidence establishing facts sought to be proved--In general

para.paratext: The admission of improper evidence is harmless where the fact thereby sought to be shown is otherwise fully and properly established. Equitable Life Assur. Soc. of U.S. v. Mittelhauser, 130 Fla. 794, 178 So. 559 (1938); Clark v. Orr, 127 Fla. 411, 173 So. 155 (1937); Pensacola & A.R. Co. v. Anderson, 26 Fla. 425, 8 So. 127 (1890); Bridier v. Yulee, 9 Fla. 481 (1861).

The admission of improper evidence of a fact in issue is harmless when the verdict or judgment is supported by sufficient competent evidence. Brevard County v. Apel, App., 246 So.2d 134 (1971); Fern v. Fern, App., 207 So.2d 291 (1968); Mansfield v. Johnson, 51 Fla. 239, 40 So. 196 (1906); Upchurch v. Mizell, 50 Fla. 456, 40 So. 29 (1905).

Plaintiff was not prejudiced by refusal of trial court to permit introduction of three letters into evidence, where there was oral testimony which contained the same evidence which would have been presented had the letters themselves been introduced into evidence. Coral Plaza Corp. v. Hersman, App. 3 Dist., 220 So.2d 672 (1969), certiorari denied 229 So.2d 867. Appeal And Error  1057(1)

Error in permitting defendant to read into evidence in action for injury to automobile passenger in collision with defendant's automobile testimony, on which defendant's argument to jury was based, given by defendant's expert witness on previous trial of action against her for injury to driver of automobile in which passenger was riding was prejudicial to passenger, even though conclusion of defendant's expert as to speed differed factually only a few miles per hour from that presented by passenger's expert. Osburn v. Stickel, App. 3 Dist., 187 So.2d 89 (1966). Appeal And Error  1051(1)

In action for damage to plaintiff's property by fire allegedly caused by negligent use of acetylene torch by defendants' employees, permitting fire expert to testify that there was no indication that fire resulted from defective wiring was harmless error, particularly in view of evidence that electrical wiring did not contribute to fire. Perma Spray Mfg. Co. v. La France Industries of Miami, Inc., App. 3 Dist., 161 So.2d 13 (1964), certiorari denied 168 So.2d 147. Appeal And Error  1051(1)

X-ray report prepared by radiologist, who did not testify, was improperly admitted, where sole basis was testimony of treating physician that he had referred plaintiff for examination and thereafter he received the report resulting therefrom, but admission of radiologist's report which attempted to establish that plaintiff had ulcer was not reversible error, since existence of ulcer was clearly established by treating physician without reference to report. Williamson Candy Co. v. Lewis, App. 3 Dist., 144 So.2d 522 (1962). Appeal And Error  1051(1); Evidence  377

New trial will not be granted because of admission of illegal evidence to prove fact fully established by legal evidence, where verdict was not influenced by illegal evidence. Davis v. Ivey, 93 Fla. 387, 112 So. 264 (1927), certiorari denied 48 S.Ct. 19, 275 U.S. 526, 72 L.Ed. 407. Appeal And Error  1051(1)
Error in rejecting evidence to establish a fact afterwards found by a referee to exist is harmless. Hogans v. Demps, 63 Fla. 177, 58 So. 33 (1912). Appeal And Error  1057(1)
An error in excluding evidence as to a certain fact was harmless where the fact was fully established by other evidence. Carlton v. King, 51 Fla. 158, 40 So. 191 (1906). Appeal And Error  1057(1)

head.head.info: 19. ---- Admissions of facts, other evidence establishing facts sought to be proved

para.paratext: Error, if any, in admission of tenant's testimony, in action against landlords for injuries sustained by tenant's invitee when her leg broke through flooring on leased premises, that she was aware that floor sills on porch were rotted through and that she had reported need for repairs to landlords' rent collecting agent was not prejudicial as against landlords' contention that by defaulting on third-party complaint alleging that condition of porch was due to normal wear and tear, tenant admitted such allegations, where landlords admitted by their pleadings that rot on wooden porch was cause of defect. Braxton v. McBride, App. 1 Dist., 241 So.2d 716 (1970). Appeal And Error  1051(3)

Where it had been agreed that tax returns introduced in death action spoke for themselves and were, presumably, within comprehension of ordinary intelligent juror, exclusion of testimony from tax expert with reference to their interpretation was not prejudicial. Schnedl v. Rich, App. 2 Dist., 137 So.2d 1 (1962). Appeal And Error  1057(1)

Rejection of additional evidence as to force and impact of automobile that caused injuries being sued for was not error where injured party had testified to facts surrounding injury, and defendant offered no testimony to refute such evidence and admitted liability. Katz v. Red Top Sedan Service, Inc., App. 3 Dist., 136 So.2d 11 (1962). Appeal And Error  1057(2)

In action to recover damages resulting from collision between automobile and truck, where automobile driver admitted he had been exceeding the speed limit, if admission of testimony that father of automobile driver had paid fine arising out of charge of excessive speed against driver was error it was harmless. Parker v. Perfection Co-op. Dairies, App. 2 Dist., 102 So.2d 645 (1958). Appeal And Error  1051(3)

In action for damages resulting from diversion of water from natural flow onto property of plaintiff, in absence of a plea denying ownership and possession in plaintiff, ownership and possession were admitted by plea of not guilty, and admission of plaintiff's testimony that he was owner and in possession of described land when the damage occurred was not reversible error. Panama City v. York, 157 Fla. 425, 26 So.2d 184 (1946). Appeal And Error  1051(3); Pleading  115; Pleading  376

Error, if any, in excluding defendant's evidence relevant only to reduce complainant's claim to minimum contract price was rendered harmless by subsequent action of complainant in conceding such reduction. Standard Lumber Co. v. Florida Industrial Co., 106 Fla. 884, 141 So. 729 (1932), certiorari denied 53 S.Ct. 522, 289 U.S. 723, 77 L.Ed. 1474. Appeal And Error  1057(2)

Where defendant admits sending a libelous letter, the introduction in evidence of a copy of the letter in connection with other evidence of publication is not harmful, but the admission in evidence over objection of a copy of a letter purporting but not shown to be from the person to whom the libelous letter was sent, containing matters relating to the privilege of the letter complained of, and containing ex parte suggestions relating to defendant, is harmful error. Briggs v. Brown, 55 Fla. 417, 46 So. 325 (1908). Appeal And Error  1051(3)

An assignment of error on ruling of court admitting in evidence copies of telegrams when the originals were not produced or accounted for presents no reversible error where it is admitted in open court that such copies were true copies of the originals. Daniel v. Siegel-Cooper Co., 54 Fla. 265, 44 So. 949 (1907). Appeal And Error  1051(3)

head.head.info: 20. ---- Cumulative evidence, other evidence establishing facts sought to be proved

para.paratext: Failure to admit certain hospital records did not present reversible error inasmuch as it appeared that the declared purpose for the admission was simply to compile cumulative evidence as to claimed tendency toward hypochondria. Collard v. Keeton, App. 3 Dist., 317 So.2d 121 (1975). Appeal And Error  1058(1)

Where evidence to which objection was made was cumulative, and where where was ample, competent evidence to prove issue, error, if established, was harmless error. Jefferson Disposal Co., Inc. v. Green, App. 3 Dist., 311 So.2d 785 (1975). Appeal And Error  1051.1(1)

In action arising out of collision between southbound motorist and left turning northbound motorist, assuming arguendo that it was error to admit testimony of eyewitness that southbound motorist was far enough north to allow northbound motorist to complete his turn, such error was harmless, where the eyewitness testimony was merely cumulative and repetitious to other abundant testimony upon which jury could find that northbound vehicle was not negligently operated. Hughes v. Canal Ins. Co., App. 3 Dist., 308 So.2d 552 (1975). Appeal And Error  1051(1)

Where issue in false arrest action was whether restraint of plaintiff was warranted by circumstances, and admission into evidence of police department property receipt was cumulative evidence as to existence of articles listed thereon, any error in admitting receipt over plaintiff's objection that it was hearsay was harmless. Olund v. Federated Dept. Stores, Inc., App. 3 Dist., 300 So.2d 31 (1974). Appeal And Error  1051.1(2)

Even if police officer was qualified in field of automobile accident reconstruction, it was error to admit his testimony that speed of vehicle was 50 miles per hour, where there was complete absence of accurate measurements and of numerous other factors and physical facts which would necessarily have to be known and be taken into consideration in order to arrive at scientific determination of speed of vehicle; however, error was harmless where officer's testimony was merely cumulative of other competent evidence that speed was 50 miles per hour. Delta Rent-A-Car, Inc. v. Rihl, App. 4 Dist., 218 So.2d 469 (1969), certiorari denied 225 So.2d 535. Appeal And Error  1051(1); Evidence  555.8(2)

Where substance of rejected testimony was contained in the record and was merely cumulative, trial court did not err in its denial of defendant's proffer of testimony as to violence during previous labor unrest. Florida East Coast Ry. Co. v. Morgan, App. 3 Dist., 213 So.2d 632 (1968). Appeal And Error  1058(1)

Where testimony proffered by railroad was merely cumulative, trial court's denial of such proffer, if error, was harmless. Florida East Coast Ry. Co. v. Morgan, App. 3 Dist., 213 So.2d 632 (1968). Appeal And Error  1058(1)

Where testimony read into record from deposition of witness who had previously testified in person but who had been excused was cumulative of other testimony concerning cause of accident in yard conductor's action against railroad for injuries sustained when train suddenly moved, admission of testimony from deposition was not reversible error. Atlantic Coast Line R. Co. v. Hilborn, App. 3 Dist., 195 So.2d 596 (1967). Appeal And Error  1051(1)

Exclusion of plaintiff's proffered medical testimony, on ground that only two medical witnesses would be permitted, that plaintiff was unable to continue in occupation of railroad engineer was not prejudicial, where this evidence would merely have been cumulative to that testified to by two treating physicians. Stager v. Florida East Coast Ry. Co., App. 3 Dist., 163 So.2d 15 (1964), certiorari discharged 174 So.2d 540, certiorari denied 86 S.Ct. 162, 382 U.S. 878, 15 L.Ed.2d 119. Appeal And Error  1057(1)

Where plaintiff, in a wrongful death action against alleged owner of truck involved in fatal accident, had a right, irrespective of a conditional sales contract under which defendant purchased truck, to question defendant as to whether he maintained liability insurance on the truck at the time of the accident, as relevant on question of whether the truck was owned by defendant, but plaintiff failed to so question defendant, exclusion from evidence of the contract which contained an agreement by defendant to procure or maintain liability insurance on the truck until full purchase price was paid would not be deemed harmful error in view of fact reception of the contract was not a prerequisite to plaintiff's right to interrogate defendant on the question of liability insurance, and the contract would have been merely cumulative evidence of fact that defendant had purchased the truck prior to the accident, a fact already admitted by testimony of defendant. Hicks v. Land, App. 1 Dist., 117 So.2d 11 (1960), certiorari denied 120 So.2d 617. Appeal And Error  1056.1(5); Appeal And Error  1057(1)

Where evidence admitted is merely cumulative and favorable to the complaining party and is not forbidden by law, reversible error cannot be based thereon. Baugher v. Boley, 63 Fla. 75, 63 Fla. 87, 58 So. 980 (1912). Appeal And Error  1050.1(1)

head.head.info: 21. ---- Other testimony of same witness, other evidence establishing facts sought to be proved

para.paratext: Alleged error in the exclusion of offered testimony is of no avail, if the same testimony, or testimony to the same effect, had been, or was afterwards, allowed to be given by the witness. Vaughn's Seed Store v. Stringfellow, 56 Fla. 708, 48 So. 410 (1909); Atlantic Coast Line R. Co. v. Peeples, 56 Fla. 145, 47 So. 392 (1908); Stone v. White, 55 Fla. 510, 45 So. 1032 (1908); Gracy v. Atlantic Coast Line R. Co. 53 Fla. 350, 42 So. 903 (1907); Upchurch v. Mizell, 50 Fla. 456, 40 So. 29 (1905); Tischler v. Apple, 30 Fla. 132, 11 So. 273 (1892).

Any error in excluding physician's testimony as to possible causes of cirrhosis of liver was cured by his subsequent testimony. Eppinger & Russell Co. v. Sheely, 1928, 24 F.2d 153. Federal Courts  901.1

Where evidence which rejected records would have shown was presented otherwise through testimony of party seeking its entry, error if any was not harmful. Delano Hotel, Inc. v. Gold, App. 3 Dist., 126 So.2d 301 (1961). Appeal And Error  1058(2)

In action on note, defendant could not complain of ruling excluding testimony offered by him, where later in trial he was permitted to testify about such matter in manner which was at first excluded. Davis v. Woodward-Crowder Co., 118 Fla. 323, 160 So. 189 (1934). Appeal And Error  1058(2)

head.head.info: 22. ---- Same or similar evidence, other evidence establishing facts sought to be proved

para.paratext: An error in excluding evidence is harmless where it is admitted at another time or in another form. Watkins v. Sims, 81 Fla. 730, 88 So. 764 (1921); United Hardware-Furniture Co. v. Blue, 59 Fla. 419, 52 So. 364, 35 L.R.A.(N.S.) 1038 (1910); Morrison v. McKennon, 12 Fla. 552 (1869); Pons v. Hart, 5 Fla. 457 (1854).

In action for death of plaintiff's husband who was killed while unloading automobiles from box car, any error in admission, as against objection that it was cumulative, of gruesome photograph of mangled body of husband after its removal from place of accident was harmless, where other photographs had fully exemplified the locus and the sight presented by the crushed head and body of husband, and gruesome photograph showed nothing more than nature and extent of fatal injury and gave the jury some idea of result produced by loading device which fell on husband. Atlantic Coast Line R. Co. v. Gary, 57 So.2d 10 (1951). Appeal And Error  1051(1)

In action for injuries to moving picture theater patron struck by BB shot from air rifle fired through exit door by boys playing “cops and robbers”, testimony that for a period beginning 11 years and ending four years before accident, exit door was kept open and no injuries to patrons resulted was properly excluded especially where court admitted evidence that for several years there had been no accident from shooting into the theater. Central Theatres v. Wilkinson, 154 Fla. 589, 18 So.2d 755 (1944). Appeal And Error  1058(1); Evidence  145

Any error in excluding evidence affecting title of payee of note, which would put on holders burden of proving that they acquired title in due course, may be harmless, where proof is made that plaintiff is holder in due course. Bland v. Fidelity Trust Co., 71 Fla. 499, 71 So. 630 (1916). Appeal And Error  1058(1)

head.head.info: 23. ---- Similar testimony of other witnesses, other evidence establishing facts sought to be proved

para.paratext: Even if error had been committed in not allowing chiropractor to give testimony as to whether change in plaintiff's eyesight after automobile accident was result of automobile accident, such error was harmless, where plaintiff presented for consideration of jury testimony of an optometrist who opined that plaintiff's vision problems were probably related to automobile accident. Aiken v. Miller, App. 1 Dist., 298 So.2d 477 (1974). Appeal And Error  1058(3)

In widow's action against railroad to recover for death of decedent who was killed in collision at crossing, expert witness' testimony that crossing was dangerous because it lacked adquate warning devices to have alerted a driver in decedent's position was a conclusion as to a matter within realm of a jury's ordinary experience and understanding and, therefore, admission of such testimony was erroneous but such error was harmless where there was substantial nonopinion testimony in record which would support conclusion that train on crossing presented a dangerous condition. Seaboard Coast Line R. Co. v. Hill, App. 4 Dist., 250 So.2d 311 (1971), certiorari discharged 270 So.2d 359. Appeal And Error  1051(1); Evidence  507

Even if it was error to exclude owner's proffered testimony, in action by broker to recover commission, that mortgage banker would not give loan of $500,000, which was a condition of sale to be fulfilled by seller, had he known that sale price of the property was only $600,000, it was not prejudicial where substantially same information was elicited from banker prior to proffer. Edelstein v. Wilder, App. 3 Dist., 198 So.2d 665 (1967). Appeal And Error  1057(1)

In action for injuries by guest against owner of automobile sustained when riding with defendant's agent, admission of testimony of police officer who went to scene of accident relative to statements made by agent at police station few minutes after accident was not harmful error where such statements were established by other witnesses and were cumulative. Sea Crest Corp. v. Burley, 38 So.2d 434 (1949). Appeal And Error  1051(1)

head.head.info: 24. Preliminary proof lacking

para.paratext: Permitting state trooper to testify without proper foundation as to speed limit applicable to unposted intersection where accident occurred outside of limits of any municipality was reversible error. Boshnack v. World Wide Rent-A-Car, Inc., 195 So.2d 216 (1967). Appeal And Error  1050.4; Automobiles  243(7)

Court committed reversible error in permitting state tropper to testify without proper foundation as to speed limit applicable to unposted intersection where accident occurred outside of the limits of any municipality. World Wide Rent-A-Car, Inc. v. Boshnack, App. 1 Dist., 184 So.2d 467 (1966), quashed in part 195 So.2d 216. Appeal And Error  1050.4; Automobiles  243(7)

Admitting mortality tables in evidence in action for injuries sustained in automobile collision was not reversible error, in view of evidence of permanent disfigurement of face of plaintiff and that she earned a living as model and hostess. Klem's, Inc. v. Cline, 105 So.2d 881 (1958). Appeal And Error  1050.4

Where action on fire policy was defended on ground that property was burned for insurance and that insured was not real beneficial owner, uncertified lists of deeds and mortgages, offered for purpose of showing that insured's father was beneficial owner and that he carried all of his property in names of either his daughter or wife, were inadmissible in absence of showing that they were best evidence obtainable, and admission of lists was not rendered harmless because of failure to object as to that part of lists relating to property involved in litigation. Kight v. American Eagle Fire Ins. Co. of New York, 125 Fla. 608, 170 So. 664 (1936). Appeal And Error  1050.4

Error, if any, in admitting copy in evidence without requiring complainant to prove loss or destruction of original document, was harmless, where defendant thereafter testified that he had destroyed original. Zepatos v. Tragas, 114 Fla. 604, 154 So. 330 (1934) Appeal And Error  1050.4

An error in admitting a deed in evidence without proof of its execution is not ground for reversal where, under the pleadings and evidence, its introduction was immaterial and unnecessary to a proper disposition of the case. Matthews v. Lindsay, 20 Fla. 962 (1884) Appeal And Error  1050.4

head.head.info: 25. Prior consistent or inconsistent statements

para.paratext: Where there was no doubt that defendant, who testified in personal injury action that plaintiff's automobile struck defendant's automobile when plaintiff put her vehicle into reverse so as to avoid having it struck by railroad crossing arm, had signed prior inconsistent written statement that he did not think that there was a crossing arm at crossing, a prior consistent statement by defendant was not admissible, but admission of such statement was harmless error, in view of photographs establishing presence of crossing arms. Kellam v. Thomas, App. 4 Dist., 287 So.2d 733 (1974). Appeal And Error  1048(7); Witnesses  395

Where witness for taxicab company testified at trial that plaintiff was traveling 75 miles per hour on expressway prior to intersection collision with taxicab in which witness was passenger, refusal to permit plaintiff to introduce prior statement of witness that she could not correctly estimate speed of plaintiff's vehicle was prejudicial error. Wingate v. New Deal Cab Co., App. 1 Dist., 217 So.2d 612 (1969), appeal denied. Appeal And Error  1048(7); Witnesses  379(3)

In action against insurer for loss of insured jewelry, where the jewelry was in the exclusive control of the plaintiff and the facts surrounding the alleged loss were virtually within his exclusive knowledge, refusal to admit in evidence prior inconsistent statements of plaintiff, consisting of a sworn statement given by plaintiff to insurer's counsel pursuant to provisions of policy and a signed statement of the plaintiff, was reversible error. Central Mut. Ins. Co. v. Newman, App. 3 Dist., 117 So.2d 41 (1960). Appeal And Error  1048(7); Witnesses  379(4.1)

In action by parent against motorist to recover damages for negligent death of infant daughter resulting from automobile accident, refusal to permit defendant to introduce prior inconsistent statement made by eyewitness to fatal accident to impeach her testimony was not harmful error where it appeared that witness was taking sedatives and was suffering from shock at time statement was made. Winner v. Sharp, 43 So.2d 634 (1949). Appeal And Error  1048(7); Witnesses  379(11)

head.head.info: 26. Unsworn statements

para.paratext: Where defendant motorist was grossly negligent, admission of unsworn statement of clerk of criminal court which reflected that the defendant had entered plea of guilty to charge of reckless driving was harmless error. Bryant v. Haarala, App. 1 Dist., 245 So.2d 644 (1971). Appeal And Error  1050.1(8.1)

head.head.info: 27. Objections and motions--In general

para.paratext: If testimony is in response to direct questions by a party, the adverse party should object to the questions as propounded, and not wait until all the testimony is in, and then move to strike it. Wiconea Inv. Co. v. Pridgeon, 138 Fla. 540, 188 So. 597 (1939); Pittsburgh Steel Co. v. Streety, 61 Fla. 393, 401, 55 So. 67 (1911); Wilson v. Jernigan, 57 Fla. 277, 49 So. 44 (1909).

Statute that allowed a litigant to preserve, without renewing an objection, a claim of error for appeal based on the presentation at trial of evidence that had been excluded by the trial court in a definitive ruling on the record did not relieve litigants of the obligation to move for a mistrial in order to preserve the issue of entitlement to a new trial based on the presentation of the excluded evidence. Ocwen Financial Corp. v. Kidder, App. 4 Dist., 950 So.2d 480 (2007), rehearing denied. Appeal And Error  237(2)

Record failed to show that court committed reversible error in ruling on the many objections made to the admission of evidence. Harrison v. American Fire & Cas. Co., App. 4 Dist., 226 So.2d 28 (1969). Appeal And Error  1050.1(1)

Error, if any, in trial court's permitting alleged witness to express opinion as an expert regarding origin of fire, in action by insured against insurers on fire policies covering goods, furniture, and fixtures in insured's store, was cured by court's subsequent ruling that court had erroneously overruled insurers' motion to strike such testimony, and that jury should disregard such testimony. Home Ins. Co. v. Wiggins, App. 1 Dist., 147 So.2d 157 (1962), certiorari denied 152 So.2d 170. Appeal And Error  1048(2)

Objections to evidence should be timely as well as specific, and a party should not permit evidence to go in without objection and then move to strike it out if unfavorable to him. McMillan v. Reese, 61 Fla. 360, 55 So. 388 (1911). Trial  91

head.head.info: 28. ---- Motions to strike, objections and motions

para.paratext: A motion to strike testimony is available only when the testimony admitted is inadmissible, irrelevant, or immaterial. Williams v. Pringle, 61 Fla. 485, 54 So. 452 (1911); Florida East Coast Ry. Co. v. Lassiter, 59 Fla. 246, 52 So. 975 (1910); Platt v. Rowand, 54 Fla. 237, 45 So. 32 (1907).

Where improper testimony is given in answer to a proper question, the remedy is by motion to strike. Atlantic Coast Line R. Co. v. Shouse, 83 Fla. 156, 91 So. 90 (1922); Rentz v. Live Oak Bank, 61 Fla. 403, 55 So. 856 (1911); Jacksonville Elec. Co. v. Sloan, 52 Fla. 257, 42 So. 516 (1906).

Even though defendant's answer to interrogatory, based on hearsay evidence and constituting a self-serving declaration, would have been inadmissible upon seasonable objection on those grounds, it was not subject to the objection that plaintiffs had no right to cross-examine informants named in such answer where plaintiffs had opportunity in advance of trial to depose and cross-examine such informants, and hence court properly admitted it in evidence where this was the only objection made, and properly denied motion to strike the answer, not made until after defendants had rested their case. Boutwell v. Bishop, App. 1 Dist., 194 So.2d 3 (1967). Trial  84(5); Trial  92

Legal sufficiency of relevant document to authorize recovery cannot ordinarily be disposed of by motion to strike it from evidence. Ramsey v. City of Kissimmee, 111 Fla. 387, 149 So. 553 (1933). Trial  89

In ejectment action, defendant's evidence disclosing tax deed conveying property to third party, and judgment in another ejectment action between such party and defendant in favor of defendant was properly stricken. Burns v. McDaniel, 104 Fla. 526, 140 So. 314 (1932). Trial  89
Plaintiff's evidence, which varied from the allegations of the declaration, should have been stricken out on motion. Coons v. Pritchard, 69 Fla. 362, 68 So. 225 (1915). Trial  89
A motion to strike a witness' testimony is too general when not confined to the particular testimony objected to. Coons v. Pritchard, 69 Fla. 362, 68 So. 225 (1915). Trial  94

If a question is propounded to a witness which tends to elicit improper testimony, the opposite party should object to it and obtain a ruling on his objection, and, if improper testimony is given in response to a proper question, the proper method of removing it from the consideration of the jury is a motion to strike it, while, if improper testimony is given in response to an improper question to which no objection is made, a motion to strike is the recognized mode of removing it, but in such case the granting or refusing of the motion is in the discretion of the trial court. McMillan v. Reese, 61 Fla. 360, 55 So. 388 (1911). Trial  78

Where testimony offered has been theretofore admitted in evidence and afterwards properly stricken, it was not error to refuse to allow a repetition of it. United Hardware-Furniture Co. v. Blue, 59 Fla. 419, 52 So. 364 (1910). Trial  55

A motion to strike out evidence that had been introduced should be predicated on some irrelevancy, incompetency, or inadmissibility in the evidence itself, and where it has been introduced by a party and is pertinent so far as it goes, but which in the conception of the opposite party falls short for the want of proof of other necessary facts, the proper practice is to ask for an appropriate instruction. Wilson v. Johnson, 51 Fla. 370, 41 So. 395 (1906). Trial  78

If irrelevant or immaterial testimony be given in answer to a proper interrogatory, the appropriate remedy is by motion to strike the testimony, and not by objections to the interrogatory. Lakeside Press & Photo-Engraving Co. v. Campbell, 39 Fla. 523, 22 So. 878 (1897). Trial  78

head.head.info: 29. ---- Timeliness, objections and motions

para.paratext: Any initial attempt to call a matter to court's attention subsequent to trial, so that another trial would be required if trial judge then agreed, is necessarily untimely. Diaz v. Rodriguez, App. 3 Dist., 384 So.2d 906 (1980). New Trial  116

Appellate court must normally confine its review of objections to evidence to those grounds actually raised in trial court. Nat Harrison Associates, Inc. v. Byrd, App. 4 Dist., 256 So.2d 50 (1971). Appeal And Error  232(2)

Counsel has duty to object at time of opposing counsel's argument to jury if argument goes beyond realm of proper argument. H. I. Holding Co. v. Dade County, App. 3 Dist., 129 So.2d 693 (1961), certiorari denied 133 So.2d 646. Trial  131(2)

Trial court did not err in denying defendant's motion for mistrial because of improper argument to jury by petitioner's counsel, where defendant's counsel did not object at time argument was made, and where improper remarks were not highly prejudicial and inflammatory, and effect thereof could have been cured by timely objection and appropriate instruction to jury. H. I. Holding Co. v. Dade County, App. 3 Dist., 129 So.2d 693 (1961), certiorari denied 133 So.2d 646. Trial  131(2)

Where motion to strike out testimony was not made until after plaintiff had concluded his testimony in rebuttal, it was too late, and denial of the motion by the trial judge was not reversible error. Wicoma Inv. Co. v. Pridgeon, 137 Fla. 540, 188 So. 597 (1939). Trial  92

Objections and exceptions to the admission of incompetent evidence must be made when the testimony is offered, otherwise objections are waived. McMillan v. Reese, 61 Fla. 360, 55 So. 388 (1911). Trial  76
An objection to the admission of evidence comes too late if made in the first instance after verdict. Gallaher v. State, 17 Fla. 370 (1879). Trial  76
An objection comes too late after the evidence is before the jury. McKay v. Lane, 5 Fla. 268 (1853). Trial  76

head.head.info: 30. ---- Sufficiency, objections and motions

para.paratext: It is not error to overrule a general objection to the reception of evidence. Tampa Elec. Co. v. Charles, 69 Fla. 27, 67 So. 572 (1915); Atlantic Coast Line R. Co. v. Partridge, 58 Fla. 153, 50 So. 634 (1909); Gainesville & Gulf R. Co. v. Peck, 55 Fla. 402, 46 So. 1019 (1908); Seaboard Air Line Ry. v. Harby, 55 Fla. 555, 46 So. 590 (1908).

Capital defendant preserved for appellate review claim that it was error for the trial court to allow a police detective to testify during the penalty phase about the injuries sustained by a previous victim, where defendant filed pretrial motions to prohibit the State from using hearsay evidence at the penalty phase and to have related statute declared unconstitutional for violating his right to confront witnesses; defendant was not required to renew his objection to the penalty phase evidence in order to preserve his confrontation claim for appellate review. Franklin v. State, 965 So.2d 79 (2007), rehearing denied. Sentencing And Punishment  1789(3)

Claimed errors in cross-examination of plaintiff's essential medical witnesses in medical malpractice action were properly preserved for appellate review where plaintiff strenuously objected to offending questions both on specific grounds and on grounds which were apparent from context in which they were made. Simmons v. Baptist Hosp. of Miami, Inc., App. 3 Dist., 454 So.2d 681 (1984). Appeal And Error  232(2)
Where no proper objection was made to admission of exhibit, admission of exhibit was not error. Barkett v. Hardy, App. 3 Dist., 271 So.2d 782 (1973). Trial  105(2)

When one desires to make an objection to question propounded to a witness, ground of objection should be stated with specificity, unless ground for objection is clearly apparent. Nat Harrison Associates, Inc. v. Byrd, App. 4 Dist., 256 So.2d 50 (1971). Trial  82

Objection to hypothetical question, to effect that expert witness had to have more of a foundation and personal knowledge of particular factors involved in question as to speed of vehicle at time it was struck from the rear, was insufficient for want of specificity and would be disregarded on appeal. Nat Harrison Associates, Inc. v. Byrd, App. 4 Dist., 256 So.2d 50 (1971). Appeal And Error  231(6); Trial  82

Even though defendant's answer to interrogatory, based on hearsay evidence and constituting a self-serving declaration, would have been inadmissible upon seasonable objection on those grounds, it was not subject to the objection that plaintiffs had no right to cross-examine informants named in such answer where plaintiffs had opportunity in advance of trial to depose and cross-examine such informants, and hence court properly admitted it in evidence where this was the only objection made, and properly denied motion to strike the answer, not made until after defendants had rested their case. Boutwell v. Bishop, App. 1 Dist., 194 So.2d 3 (1967). Trial  84(5); Trial  92

Objections to evidence should be specific, clearly indicating not only the grounds of objection but the particular part of the document, or thing introduced, or statement of the witness to which the objection is deemed to be applicable. U.S. Fire Ins. Co. v. Dickerson, 82 Fla. 442, 90 So. 613 (1921). Trial  82

Objections to the admission of evidence should definitely and specifically point out the objectionable features of the evidence offered. Atlanta & St. A.B. Ry. Co. v. Kelly, 77 Fla. 479, 82 So. 57 (1919). Trial  82

Party objecting to competency of a witness or to proffered evidence should specifically state grounds of his objection, to apprise the court and his adversary of precise objection he intends to make. Caldwell v. People's Bank of Sanford, 73 Fla. 1165, 75 So. 848 (1917). Trial  82

An objection to the introduction of evidence should point out some fact or principle making it objectionable; otherwise, unless the evidence is wholly incompetent, the Supreme Court will not consider the objection. Mugge v. Jackson, 50 Fla. 235, 39 So. 157 (1905). Trial  83(1)
An objection that evidence offered is “not proper testimony for the jury” is too vague to be considered. Withers v. Sandlin, 36 Fla. 619, 18 So. 856 (1896). Trial  83(1)

Where opinion evidence was objected to, but the grounds were not stated, it cannot be urged on appeal that witness was not qualified to testify, or that the evidence was not relevant. Jacksonville, T. & K.W. Ry. Co. v. Lockwood, 33 Fla. 573, 15 So. 327 (1894). Trial  82

An objection to the admission or exclusion of evidence must be specific and state the grounds of the objection. Carter v. Bennett, 4 Fla. 283 (1852), error dismissed 56 U.S. 354, 15 How. 354, 14 L.Ed. 727. Trial  82

head.head.info: 31. ---- Failure to object, objections and motions

para.paratext: Where no objections are interposed to questions and the testimony is admitted without objection, the party failing to object cannot, as a matter of right, have the responsive testimony stricken out on motion, though it may be irrelevant or incompetent, and open to attack by proper objection. Wicoma Inv. Co. v. Pridgeon, 137 Fla. 540, 188 So. 597 (1939); Wilson v. Jernigan, 57 Fla. 277, 49 So. 44 (1909); Platt v. Rowand, 54 Fla. 237, 45 So. 32 (1907).

Defendant did not fail to preserve for appellate review issue concerning trial court's admission of collateral act evidence; issue was raised in pre-trial hearing, and defense counsel twice objected to admission of evidence. Zerbe v. State, App. 4 Dist., 944 So.2d 1189 (2006), rehearing denied. Criminal Law  1036.1(8)

To preserve an issue for appellate review, counsel generally is required to object contemporaneously with the offered testimony. Fittipaldi USA, Inc. v. Castroneves, App. 3 Dist., 905 So.2d 182 (2005), rehearing and rehearing en banc denied, review denied 918 So.2d 291. Appeal And Error  230

Daycare center's objection to admission in personal injury action of voluntary safety guidelines and standards that came into existence after minor was injured in fall from daycare center's playground equipment was not preserved for appellate review, where daycare center failed to make contemporaneous objection at trial to evidence. Castaneda ex rel. Cardona v. Redlands Christian Migrant Ass'n, Inc., App. 4 Dist., 884 So.2d 1087 (2004). Appeal And Error  230

Trial courts lack discretion to grant motion for new trial, even where based on circumstances tainted by misconduct, for unpreserved error that is not fundamental error. Celentano v. Banker, App. 4 Dist., 728 So.2d 244 (1998). New Trial  31; New Trial  32

Trial court lacked jurisdiction to grant new trial to plaintiff in personal injury action based on improper admission of prejudicial testimony, where error was not preserved for review, and was not fundamental. Celentano v. Banker, App. 4 Dist., 728 So.2d 244 (1998). New Trial  97; New Trial  98

In action by restaurant owner against deep fat fryer manufacturer for damages from fire that originated in allegedly defective fryer and totally destroyed restaurant, volunteer fire department captain's testimony on direct examination relating to requirement of county fire code, whether captain was reporting to state what he had read in code or had heard from others, was objectionable in first instance, and thus owner's failure to make timely objection resulted in such point on appeal not being properly reserved for review. Dowd v. Star Mfg. Co., App. 3 Dist., 385 So.2d 179 (1980), petition for review denied 392 So.2d 1373. Appeal And Error  230

Failure to object at trial contemporaneously with admission of contested evidence is waiver of right to appellate review of issue. DeLuca v. State, App. 4 Dist., 384 So.2d 212 (1980), petition for review denied 389 So.2d 1108. Criminal Law  1036.1(2)

Alleged misconduct during plaintiff's closing argument did not so pervade trial as to require new trial, where defendant did not object to remarks and trial court charged jury to disregard them. Tyus v. Apalachicola Northern R. Co., 130 So.2d 580 (1961). Trial  131(1); Trial  133.6(3.1)

In action on policy providing indemnity for total and permanent disability, where declaration alleged injury to be a disorder of the larynx, bronchial tubes, and adjacent parts, admission of testimony disclosing that insured probably also was afflicted with tuberculosis was not error, where no objection was made to evidence when offered. Equitable Life Assur. Soc. of U.S. v. Grubbs, 118 Fla. 210, 158 So. 879 (1935). Appeal And Error  882(9)

Where uncontroverted testimony not essentially illegal, is received without objection, it should be given its full, natural, probative force. Gracy v. Seaboard Air Line Ry., 69 Fla. 301, 68 So. 722 (1915). Trial  105(1)

Evidence introduced without objection is considered as received by consent, and, where such testimony is not irrelevant or immaterial, it is error to withdraw the same from the jury's consideration. W.U. Tel. Co. v. Merritt, 55 Fla. 462, 46 So. 1024, 127 Am.St.Rep. 169 (1908). Trial  105(1)

When evidence which may have been irrelevant or otherwise open to objection has been admitted without objection, the witness having been examined and cross-examined, it is not error to deny a motion to strike out such evidence after its tendency has been disclosed. Platt v. Rowand, 54 Fla. 237, 45 So. 32 (1907). Trial  91
A motion to strike testimony admitted without objection is properly overruled. Platt v. Rowand, 54 Fla. 237, 45 So. 32 (1907). Trial  96

Where it is not apparent from a question that the answer will be inadmissible, the question need not be objected to, to entitle the opposing party to move to strike out the answer. Skinner Mfg. Co. v. Douville, 54 Fla. 251, 44 So. 1014 (1907). Trial  91

head.head.info: 32. ---- Waiver, objections and motions

para.paratext: Defendant waived claim on direct appeal that mistrial was warranted when testimony was elicited that defendant's fingerprints were on file with automated fingerprint identification system, in trial for burglary and other offenses, where counsel withdrew his objection and motion. Thompson v. State, App. 2 Dist., 888 So.2d 89 (2004). Criminal Law  1036.1(8); Criminal Law  1044.1(5.1)

Physician, who was sued for medical malpractice following death from heart attack of emergency room patient whom physician had discharged, waived objections to videotaped testimony by cardiologist who reviewed patient's EKG to the extent that physician did not make specific objection at time of testimony, where both parties knew the videotaped testimony was trial testimony. Moyer v. Reynolds, App. 5 Dist., 780 So.2d 205 (2001), rehearing denied. Appeal And Error  230; Appeal And Error  231(6)

Where defendants acquiesced to trial court's preliminary indication of ruling concerning relevancy of testimony of witness by voluntarily withdrawing witness from the stand, did so without informing court that they wished to elicit particular testimony in question, and did not indicate grounds upon which that evidence was deemed pertinent and admissible, trial court was not given opportunity at trial to rule on contention that testimony was relevant, and such contentions could not be considered on appeal. Diaz v. Rodriguez, App. 3 Dist., 384 So.2d 906 (1980). Appeal And Error  231(7)

Where only objection at trial to admission of photocopy of check and judgment debtor's minute books was based on claimed violation of best evidence rule, objection to admission for lack of any testimonial predicate was waived. Hanisch v. Wilder, App. 3 Dist., 210 So.2d 491 (1968). Trial  84(3.1)
Plaintiff waived objection on ground of identification, when objection was not made at trial. Williamson v. Guerra, App. 1 Dist., 208 So.2d 302 (1968). Trial  105(1)

Objection to questions concerning insurance asked during voir dire examination was waived by failure to object or move for mistrial until after jury was accepted. Alvarez v. Mauney, App. 2 Dist., 175 So.2d 57 (1965). Trial  131(2)

Where testimony is admitted without objection and is not contradicted, it must be treated as received by consent and given all probative force its ordinary and usual meaning will afford. Vilas v. Vilas, 153 Fla. 102, 13 So.2d 807 (1943). Trial  105(1)
