Where a question is propounded to a witness and objected to by opposing counsel upon valid grounds, and is afterwards answered by the witness without objection or motion to strike, the original objection is considered waived. Atlanta & St. A.B. Ry. Co. v. Kelly, 77 Fla. 479, 82 So. 57 (1919). Trial  79

Failure to object that a sheriff's deed was inadmissible because the judgment and execution had not been first introduced was a waiver of the objection. Stokely v. Conner, 69 Fla. 412, 68 So. 452 (1915). Trial  105(4)

head.head.info: 33. ---- Foundation or predicate, objections and motions

para.paratext: An objection for lack of foundation, like its related objection, improper predicate, is not a specific ground of objection within the meaning of statute so as to preserve a ruling admitting evidence for appellate review. Jackson v. State, App. 4 Dist., 738 So.2d 382 (1999), rehearing denied, review denied 751 So.2d 1252, denial of post-conviction relief reversed 831 So.2d 722. Criminal Law  1043(2)

head.head.info: 34. Cure of defects or objections--In general

para.paratext: Improper admission of evidence on certain issue does not constitute reversible error where such issue is not submitted to jury for their determination. Maas Bros., Inc. v. Bishop, App. 2 Dist., 204 So.2d 16 (1967). Appeal And Error  1052(1)

In death action, admission in evidence of certain federal withholding certificates, which showed decedent's earnings in an employment from which he had apparently retired, was, if error, harmless in view of other elements proved and amount of verdict. Shearn v. Orlando Funeral Home, 82 So.2d 866 (1955). Appeal And Error  1050.1(11); Appeal And Error  1052(5)

In ejectment suit against tax deed grantee, error in refusing to admit tax deed in evidence as a muniment of title was harmless where verdict and judgment were in favor of tax deed holder. Mitchell v. Moore, 152 Fla. 843, 13 So.2d 314 (1943). Appeal And Error  1052(5)

Introduction in evidence of American Experience Table of Mortality was not reversible error, though plaintiff in personal injury suit failed to show conclusively that he sustained permanent injuries, in view of size of verdict for him and admission that recovery should be limited to compensation for loss of time and medical expenses; ends of justice being best served by entering remittitur and closing litigation. Atlanta & St. Andrews Bay Ry. Co. v. Pittman, 130 Fla. 624, 178 So. 297 (1938). Appeal And Error  1052(5)

In action for reasonable value of services rendered by attorney, admission of testimony that client had reputation of being worth $100,000 was error, although not prejudicial, where fee allowed by jury was not excessive. Baruch v. Giblin, 122 Fla. 59, 164 So. 831 (1935). Appeal And Error  1052(5)

If competent evidence in record is sufficient to sustain decree of trial court, it will not be disturbed on appeal because incompetent evidence appears in record. Holmberg v. Hardee, 90 Fla. 787, 108 So. 211 (1925). Appeal And Error  1052(5)

Error in the admission of evidence of the measure of damages is harmless where the amount recovered shows that it did not affect the verdict or judgment. Younglove v. Knox, 44 Fla. 743, 33 So. 427 (1902). Appeal And Error  1052(5)

head.head.info: 35. ---- Appellant not entitled to favorable decision, cure of defects or objections

para.paratext: Inasmuch as plaintiff would have been entitled to summary judgment without affidavit which was not timely filed, it was not reversible error to consider affidavit. Sherman v. Weintraub, App. 3 Dist., 132 So.2d 421 (1961). Appeal And Error  1052(8)

Any technical or conventional errors in admission of evidence are immaterial in personal injury action where evidence is not sufficient to establish defendant's negligence. Powell v. Wilson Lumber Co. of Florida, 115 Fla. 13, 155 So. 116 (1934). Appeal And Error  1068(3)
Error in improper admission of evidence is harmless where there was other sufficient evidence to justify decree rendered. Fisher v. Guidy, 106 Fla. 94, 142 So. 818 (1932). Appeal And Error  1052(8)

A new trial should not be granted where the relevant testimony duly sustains the verdict, though some irrelevant testimony has been admitted. City of Jacksonville v. Vaughn, 92 Fla. 339, 110 So. 529 (1926). Appeal And Error  1052(8)

head.head.info: 36. ---- Instructions, cure of defects or objections

para.paratext: In medical malpractice action, curative instruction given after one of plaintiff's expert medical witnesses had been subjected to cross-examination which inferred that witness was possible arsonist of his own medical office, apparently agreed to by both parties and given on day after offending testimony was elicited, neither cured sinister nature of error complained of nor constituted waiver of error by plaintiff. Simmons v. Baptist Hosp. of Miami, Inc., App. 3 Dist., 454 So.2d 681 (1984). Appeal And Error  883; Trial  133.6(2)

Even if error was committed in admitting “hearsay” evidence in guest's personal injury action arising out of automobile collision, error was harmless in view of fact that trial judge sustained objections to “hearsay” testimony and instructed jury to disregard any improper references by council to third vehicle, i.e., truck which was driven by one defendant and owned by another but which did not collide with vehicle in which guest was riding or with vehicle which collided with vehicle in which guest was riding. Riley v. Jackson, App. 3 Dist., 246 So.2d 625 (1971). Appeal And Error  1053(2)

Admission of testimony, in passenger's personal injury suit for negligent operation of defendant's bus, of compromise and settlement of another's claims arising out of accident constituted reversible error, and later striking of testimony and cautionary instructions did not cure the prejudicial effect of such testimony. Dade County v. Clarson, App. 3 Dist., 240 So.2d 828 (1970). Appeal And Error  1053(2); Evidence  219(3)

Trial court's refusal in minor's action to recover for broken nose sustained in accident involving automobile-motor scooter collision to admit mortality tables in evidence, if error, was harmless where jury was instructed that it might consider in rendering a verdict the duration of the injury and any future pain and suffering minor might reasonably be expected to suffer. Sundermeier v. Frauman, App. 4 Dist., 214 So.2d 780 (1968). Appeal And Error  1059

Even if admission of city ordinance providing that left turning vehicles shall pass to right of center of street before turning was error, bus company sued by pedestrian for injuries sustained when she was struck by left turning bus was not prejudiced where ordinance was clear and unambiguous and trial court gave sufficient instructions to jury to overcome any error. Jacksonville Coach Co. v. Decker, App. 1 Dist., 206 So.2d 476 (1968). Appeal And Error  1053(3)

Admission of expert's testimony that proximity of step to doors in store was not in compliance with good architectural practice, if error, was harmless where the matter of proximity was mentioned only once in presence of jury who was instructed that patron claimed to have slipped because of slickness of metal strip on stair and court instructions ignored the question of proximity of step to doors. Maas Bros., Inc. v. Bishop, App. 2 Dist., 204 So.2d 16 (1967). Appeal And Error  1053(3)

Error, if any, in admission of municipal ordinance requiring motorists to yield right-of-way to pedestrians in unmarked crosswalks in personal injury action by pedestrian against motorist was harmless where jury was told that rights of pedestrians and motorists on public streets were equal and reciprocal, that it was for jury to determine if ordinance was violated and that ordinance violation did not in itself establish negligence. Souvorin v. Lerich, App. 3 Dist., 180 So.2d 180 (1965), certiorari denied 188 So.2d 314. Appeal And Error  1053(3)

Testimony, in a wrongful death action, that defendant previously had killed another person, was improper and prejudicial, and in view of fact decedent was a college student discovered by defendant while apparently prowling defendant's motel premises at hour of about 5 a.m., adverse effect of such testimony would not be deemed adequately removed by an instruction that jury disregard such testimony. F.S.A. §§ 45.11, 768.02. Carbone v. Coblentz, App. 3 Dist., 132 So.2d 629 (1961). Appeal And Error  1050.1(7); Appeal And Error  1053(2); Death  60

In action for injuries sustained by automobile guest in collision with parked automobiles within city limits, any error in admitting in evidence city ordinance requiring that a vehicle be driven as nearly as practicable within a single lane, where roadway has been divided into clearly marked lanes, was rendered harmless by charge leaving question of violation of ordinance to jury, particularly where defendants did not except to charge or object to admission of ordinance in evidence on ground urged on appeal. Klem's, Inc. v. Cline, 105 So.2d 881 (1958). Appeal And Error  231(3); Appeal And Error  1053(3)

In action by pedestrian against city for injuries sustained when pedestrian stepped into alleged depression in sidewalk and fell admission of evidence that city repaired sidewalk after the accident was reversible error, though counsel for city in opening statement to jury stated that there was no hole in the sidewalk as contended by pedestrian, and error in the admission of such evidence was not cured by instruction that repair of sidewalk by city was not an admission that a defective and dangerous condition existed. City of Miami Blanton v. Butler, 81 So.2d 745 (1955). Appeal And Error  1053(4)

In action by realty broker to recover a commission under a parol listing contract allegedly made with broker by one of the defendants, medical testimony that such defendant was suffering from a severe aggitated mental depression, had a suicidal tendency, and that he had hallucinations and was in no condition to transact business, tended to confuse and mislead jury and admission of such evidence was prejudicial error, even though jury was instructed not to consider evidence of defendant's mental incapacity except as it related to the existence or nonexistence of the contract. Perper v. Edell, 44 So.2d 78 (1949). Appeal And Error  1053(2); Evidence  510

In action under guest statute for injuries suffered in automobile accident, admission of evidence tending to show payment of expenses of the trip was not harmful in light of pleadings and court's charge that plaintiff must establish gross negligence. Ake v. Birnbaum, 156 Fla. 735, 25 So.2d 213 (1945). Appeal And Error  1053(3)

Charge that purchaser on foreclosure of tax certificate was not entitled to recover in betterment proceeding moneys which may have been expended in permanent improvement of the property, or the amount which would be necessary to replace them, or what they might be worth to plaintiff in ejectment for purpose to which he intended to devote the property, but was entitled to recover such sum as would equal amount by which actual or reasonable market value of land was enhanced by reason of improvements, was sufficient to correct any errors which may have been committed by admission of evidence as to cost of improvements in betterment proceeding. McEwing v. McCulloch, 142 Fla. 844, 196 So. 851 (1940). Appeal And Error  1053(3)

In action against schoolbus driver for injuries suffered by pupil when struck by automobile while alighting from bus, wherein court fully instructed jury that driver had right to assume that automobile would stop before passing bus, exclusion of testimony tending to show driver's reliance on probability that automobile would stop was not error. Pendarvis v. Pfeifer, 132 Fla. 724, 182 So. 307 (1938). Appeal And Error  1059

Charge directing jury to disregard inadmissible testimony elicited or volunteered, or improper conduct of attorney, cures error and corrects irregularity. Wall v. Little, 102 Fla. 1015, 136 So. 676 (1931). Appeal And Error  1053(2)
Error in admitting evidence is rendered harmless by an instruction directing the jury not to consider it. Hendry v. Ellis, 64 Fla. 306, 60 So. 354 (1912). Appeal And Error  1053(2)

Any error in the admission of mortuary tables to show life expectancy of plaintiff was harmless, where the court charged that the tables were to be considered only in the event of a finding of permanent injury, caused by defendant's negligence. Louisville & N.R. Co. v. Croxton, 63 Fla. 223, 58 So. 369 (1912). Appeal And Error  1053(6)

head.head.info: 37. ---- Insurance, cure of defects or objections

para.paratext: Even if insurance is mentioned in a civil action, frequently curative instructions will correct the error; only where the impropriety is so egregious that such instructions cannot dissipate the prejudice should a mistrial be granted. Compania Dominicana de Aviacion v. Knapp, App. 3 Dist., 251 So.2d 18 (1971), certiorari denied 256 So.2d 6. Trial  133.2

Although evidence of insurance carried by a defendant is not properly to be considered by a jury, if insurance is inadvertently mentioned or volunteered, and the court upon objection immediately acts to caution the jury to disregard the testimony a mistrial need not be declared. Crowell v. Fink, App. 1 Dist., 167 So.2d 614 (1964). Trial  133.6(8)

Where subject of insurance coverage of a party has been inadvertently mentioned by witness during course of trial, it may become harmless error by appropriate charge at that particular time. Seminole Shell Co. v. Clearwater Flying Co., App. 2 Dist., 156 So.2d 543 (1963). Trial  133.6(8)

Inadvertent reference of plaintiff's witness to insurance, without objection by opposing counsel at that time, did not justify opposing counsel in attempting to elicit testimony as to whether or not plaintiff had been compensated by insurance, and belated instruction by court, at close of case, that question of insurance had nothing to do with issues with insufficient to cure error. Seminole Shell Co. v. Clearwater Flying Co., App. 2 Dist., 156 So.2d 543 (1963). Trial  129; Trial  133.6(8)

head.head.info: 38. ---- Preliminary proof lacking, cure of defects or objections

para.paratext: Error in admission of uncertified lists of deeds and mortgages, offered by insurer for purpose of showing that insured's father was beneficial owner of property was not rendered harmless by insured's subsequent testimony as to property contained in lists, where testimony was indefinite as to description of property, dates of instruments, dates of recordations, and as to parties. Kight v. American Eagle Fire Ins. Co. of New York, 125 Fla. 608, 170 So. 664 (1936). Appeal And Error  1052(4)

head.head.info: 39. ---- Striking out or withdrawal of question, cure of defects or objections

para.paratext: Refusal to strike testimony concerning condition of driver's seat in defendants' truck which struck and killed plaintiff's minor son while crossing intersection was not prejudicial error. Ryder Truck Rental, Inc. v. Cooper, App. 2 Dist., 159 So.2d 254 (1963), certiorari denied 165 So.2d 463. Appeal And Error  1047(3)

Where testimony was taken before special master who made no rulings on objections to questions, error, if any in chancellor's denial of motion to strike testimony as immaterial, irrelevant, or incompetent was harmless, there being adequate competent testimony to sustain final decree, not shown to be erroneous. Addis v. Hoagland, 150 Fla. 694, 8 So.2d 655 (1942). Appeal And Error  1047(3)

Error in refusing to strike testimony was not reversible, where there was ample additional evidence of facts established by such testimony. Stigletts v. McDonald, 135 Fla. 385, 186 So. 233 (1938). Appeal And Error  1047(3)

In an action for conversion of logs unlawfully cut from land in possession of plaintiff for 20 years under government patent, it was not reversible error to strike from the evidence a deed made 17 years before trial by plaintiff to a third party, under which defendants do not claim, and under which the third person has never been in possession. West v. Mayo, 63 Fla. 308, 59 So. 18 (1912). Appeal And Error  1047(3)

head.head.info: 40. ---- Subsequently admitted evidence, cure of defects or objections

para.paratext: Error in admitting buyer's office copy of order in buyer's action for breach of contract was cured by testimony showing seller received order. Tampa Shipbuilding & Engineering Co. v. General Const. Co., 1930, 43 F.2d 309. Federal Courts  896.1

In action, in which recovery was sought for personal injuries sustained in automobile accident, in which it was ordered that all discovery and physical examinations be completed prior to September 4 pretrial conference and in which trial was set for week of September 16, permitting physician to testify with regard to his September 14 examination of a plaintiff was not prejudicial, in view of fact that physician testified that plaintiff's condition had not appreciably changed since a prior examination of her. Colonnell v. Mitchels, App. 2 Dist., 317 So.2d 799 (1975). Appeal And Error  1052(2)

Where contents of hearsay statement improperly admitted into evidence were neither relevant nor material to any issue in case and were adequately explained and clarified by other testimony of same witness offered by opponents on surrebuttal, admission of statement was harmless error. Seaboard Coast Line R. Co. v. Magnuson, App. 4 Dist., 288 So.2d 302 (1974), certiorari denied 297 So.2d 30. Appeal And Error  1050.2; Appeal And Error  1052(3)

Error in the admission of evidence on behalf of plaintiff to establish an account is cured by defendant's evidence which without denying the correctness of the account seeks to show that it has been paid; this being an implied admission of the correctness of the account. Stephens Lumber Co. v. Cates, 62 Fla. 382, 62 Fla. 385, 56 So. 298 (1911). Appeal And Error  1052(2)

Where evidence, original admission of which was erroneous, was subsequently rendered admissible, error in its admission was harmless. Hinote v. Brigman, 44 Fla. 589, 33 So. 303 (1902). Appeal And Error  1052(3)

head.head.info: 41. ---- Withdrawal of issues, cure of defects or objections

para.paratext: In an action for injuries to a railroad switchman, it was not reversible error to permit a witness on cross-examination to state that the doctor who attended plaintiff was defendant's local surgeon, where the court's charged excluded injury to defendant in increased damages on account of such testimony, such testimony not going to the question of defendant's liability. Florida East Coast Ry. Co. v. Lassiter, 59 Fla. 246, 52 So. 975 (1910). Appeal And Error  1053(7)

head.head.info: 42. Offers of proof

para.paratext: Under Florida law, proffer by defense counsel of witness's prospective testimony at rape trial was adequate, even though witness did not personally testify at proffer, where defense counsel's oral proffer was detailed and encompassing, received by trial court without reservation, and overheard by prosecution without objection. Johnson v. Moore, M.D.Fla.2007, 493 F.Supp.2d 1236. Criminal Law  670

Orthodontist's failure to make proffer of article he wished to use to cross-examine patient's expert or of testimony establishing predicate of authoritativeness waived orthodontist's right to appellate review of trial court's alleged error of refusing to allow use of article for cross-examination unless expert was familiar with it. Fravel v. Haughey, App. 5 Dist., 727 So.2d 1033 (1999). Appeal And Error  206.2

Party was not excused from making offer of proof by virtue of fact that trial court's in limine order excluding evidence forbade any mention of evidence at trial; party could offer excluded evidence at trial outside presence of jury without violating order or, alternatively, could have relieved itself of obligation to make offer of proof at trial by developing adequate record of excluded evidence at hearing on motion in limine. Brantley v. Snapper Power Equipment, a Div. of Fuqua Industries, Inc., App. 3 Dist., 665 So.2d 241 (1995), rehearing denied. Appeal And Error  205; Trial  45(1)

Proffer at trial of industrial commission scaffold construction safety standard by offering into evidence commission pamphlet containing the safety regulations was not insufficient for want of proper form. Alford v. Meyer, App. 1 Dist., 201 So.2d 489 (1967), certiorari denied 209 So.2d 671. Trial  45(1)

Refusal of trial court to permit widow of deceased patient in action against osteopathic physicians for death of patient to make and complete proffer of proof of widow's medical expert after his evidence was excluded was prejudicial error. Musachia v. Terry, App. 3 Dist., 140 So.2d 605 (1962). Appeal And Error  1047(1); Trial  49

When proffer of proof is made by questioning witness out of presence of jury, witness should be allowed to answer questions put to him. Musachia v. Terry, App. 3 Dist., 140 So.2d 605 (1962). Trial  50

Evidence as to damages admitted on a proffer basis only cannot be given any weight in arriving at damages awarded. First Nat. Ins. Agency, Inc. v. Leesburg Transfer & Storage, Inc., App. 2 Dist., 139 So.2d 476 (1962). Trial  51

Where a trial court has sustained objection to a question asked of a witness, the party against whom the ruling was made should make a proffer of the proposed testimony so that the trial and appellate courts may be enabled to determine its competency. Green v. Hood, App. 2 Dist., 120 So.2d 223 (1960). Trial  45(1)

When witness is not permitted to answer question objected to, unless question plainly shows that answer would be relevant, party propounding question should make sufficient proffer of what he intends to prove by answer to question. Browder v. Da Costa, 91 Fla. 1, 109 So. 448 (1925). Trial  47(1)

Where objection to a question propounded to a witness is sustained, the party against whom the ruling is made should make a proffer of the proposed testimony, in order that the court may be enabled to decide upon its competency. Atlantic Coast Line R. Co. v. Shouse, 83 Fla. 156, 91 So. 90 (1922). Trial  47(1)

head.head.info: 43. Trial without jury--In general

para.paratext: Prejudicial error is not committed in admitting in evidence, in a suit in equity to cancel a patent and the deeds founded thereon, for the fraud of the homestead entryman, testimony showing the purchase of other homestead claims by the grantee, because it was not accompanied by evidence showing that such other transactions were false and fraudulent, since it will be presumed that, under such circumstances, the court gave to the testimony admitted no value or probative strength. J.J. McCaskill Co. v. U.S., U.S.Fla.1910, 30 S.Ct. 386, 216 U.S. 504, 54 L.Ed. 590. Federal Courts  451

When the court, in a court-tried case, admits testimony, it must weigh the testimony and is not free to disregard it as inadmissible. McCabe v. Hanley, App. 4 Dist., 886 So.2d 1053 (2004). Trial  382

Courts of Florida presume that, in nonjury cases, trial judges base their verdicts on admissible evidence and disregard inadmissible evidence. M. A. v. State, App. 2 Dist., 384 So.2d 740 (1980). Criminal Law  260.11(2)

Where there was sufficient testimony and evidence before the chancellor to find that island was in bay without reference to opinion testimony, permitting opinion evidence as to dividing line, even if improper, was not prejudicial error. South Venice Corp. v. Caspersen, App. 2 Dist., 229 So.2d 652 (1969). Appeal And Error  1054(1)

Errors, in ruling on admissibility of evidence in non-jury case are not ground for reversing judgment or granting new trial, unless such errors injuriously affect substantial rights of complaining parties. Leeb v. Read, App. 3 Dist., 190 So.2d 830 (1966). Appeal And Error  1054(1); New Trial  41(2)

Alleged error of chancellor in considering newspaper clippings referring to dispute over title to property was not ground for reversal, in absence of showing that chancellor did in fact consider such clippings and in view of fact that there was sufficient evidence without clippings to support chancellor's decision. City of Tarpon Springs v. Gerecter, App. 2 Dist., 155 So.2d 566 (1963). Appeal And Error  1054(1)

Where wife, who counterclaimed in husband's divorce action, sought merely alimony unconnected with divorce, Maine decree awarding her alimony was erroneously admitted in evidence and considered in making final decree, but error was not reversible. Brickel v. Brickel, App. 2 Dist., 122 So.2d 37 (1960). Appeal And Error  1054(1); Judgment  822(1)

Where evidence was adequate to support ultimate decision of chancellor declining specific performance of contractor for sale of realty, even if disputed testimony was disregarded, alleged error in admission of disputed testimony was not prejudicial error. Greenfield v. Bland, App. 2 Dist., 99 So.2d 727 (1958). Appeal And Error  1054(1)

Where action was tried without jury, alleged errors in admission of evidence held not to have injuriously affected rights of complaining party. Prince v. Aucilla River Naval Stores Co., 103 Fla. 605, 137 So. 886 (1931). Appeal And Error  1056.5

Where action was tried without jury, alleged errors in rejection of evidence did not injuriously affect rights of complaining party. Prince v. Aucilla River Naval Stores Co., 103 Fla. 605, 137 So. 886 (1931). Appeal And Error  1056.5

There being sufficient competent evidence to sustain a finding in a case tried by the court without a jury, admission of incompetent evidence is not a ground for reversal. Ray v. Pollock, 56 Fla. 530, 47 So. 940 (1908). Appeal And Error  1054(1)

The erroneous admission of testimony in a chancery case does not necessitate a reversal, where, ignoring the objectionable testimony, there still remains sufficient evidence to support the chancellor's finding and decree. Patrick v. Kirkland, 53 Fla. 768, 43 So. 969, 125 Am.St.Rep. 1096, 12 Am.Ann.Cas. 540 (1907). Appeal And Error  1054(1)

head.head.info: 44. ---- Effect of decision, trial without jury

para.paratext: In action wherein county port authority sought to recover for damages to a drawbridge caused by defendant's tug, admission of a prior opinion, which was entered by a federal court and enacted for exoneration from a limitation of liability brought by owners of tailing tug, was not prejudicial error, where action was tried before court without a jury and where court's finding of fact and decision were in no way based on opinion in prior case. Belcher Towing Co. v. Board of County Com'rs of Dade County, App. 3 Dist., 233 So.2d 456 (1970). Appeal And Error  1054(3)

Admitting over objection improper evidence, rejection of which would not have caused court to arrive at different conclusion is harmless error. Rice v. Jessup, 92 Fla. 750, 110 So. 126 (1926). Appeal And Error  1054(3)

Where a decree rendered by a probate court is correct, the ruling of that court, sustaining an objection to testimony that had been submitted, even if erroneous, may be harmless, and not warrant a reversal of the probate decree by the circuit court on appeal. Landin v. Oerting, 61 Fla. 652, 55 So. 843 (1911). Appeal And Error  1056.5

head.head.info: 45. Aircraft accidents

para.paratext: There was no reversible error in refusing to admit portions of deposition by investigator of Federal Aviation Agency who had investigated accident out of which plaintiff's action for damages to aircraft arose. Seminole Shell Co. v. Clearwater Flying Co., App. 2 Dist., 156 So.2d 543 (1963). Appeal And Error  1056.1(10)

head.head.info: 46. Boundary disputes

para.paratext: Where resurveys which attempted to establish true boundary line were made without effort to retrace original plat survey and did not tie in with original plat survey, there was material or harmful error and judgment in ejectment based on such survey would be reversed. Akin v. Godwin, 49 So.2d 604 (1950). Appeal And Error  1050.1(3.1)

Any errors in admitting evidence of common title in boundary dispute were harmless, where record did not show parties did not claim under same title. Johnson v. Reynolds, 97 Fla. 591, 121 So. 793 (1929). Appeal And Error  1050.1(3.1)

head.head.info: 47. Breach of warranty

para.paratext: In action against cold storage warehouse company for breach of implied warranty to keep meat safely under refrigeration, admission of evidence that temperature in warehouse was allowed to rise shortly after condemnation of meat by State Agriculture Department was not error or harmful to defendant. Dixie Frozen Foods & Storage v. Cox, 158 Fla. 88, 27 So.2d 672 (1946). Appeal And Error  1050.1(5); Warehousemen  34(6)

head.head.info: 48. Commercial paper--Admission of evidence

para.paratext: Any error in considering affidavit concerning immaterial subject of intervening bankruptcy of pledgor in response to affidavit opposing motion for summary judgment for pledgee on notes pledged by payee thereof as security for indebtedness to pledgee was harmless, since pledgee was not proceeding against pledgor-bankrupt, but to reduce to judgment pledged notes for mutual benefit of pledgor and pledgee. Fontainebleau Hotel Corp. v. James Talcott, Inc., App. 3 Dist., 164 So.2d 264 (1964), certiorari denied 169 So.2d 385. Appeal And Error  1050.1(10)

head.head.info: 49. ---- Exclusion of evidence, commercial paper

para.paratext: In action on note by executors of estate of holder, maker's counterclaim demanding compensation for legal services performed for decedent during time decedent was an administrator and cotrustee of a testamentary trust was not a proper charge against decedent personally, and trial court's refusal to admit documents supporting maker's claim did not result in harmful error. Grayson v. Fishlove, App. 3 Dist., 266 So.2d 38 (1972). Appeal And Error  1056.1(4.1)

head.head.info: 50. Damages--Admission of evidence

para.paratext: In action arising out of accident in which car occupied by plaintiffs was struck from behind by defendant's car, evidence as to earnings allegedly lost by plaintiff driver as a commission salesman due to necessity that he spend more time at home with his wife, who was injured in the accident, was not admissible with regard to his claim for loss of services of wife; admission of such evidence was error requiring reduction of award on such claim from $10,000 to $5,000 in order to reflect amount due under proper measure of damages. Lewis v. Gauzens, App. 3 Dist., 318 So.2d 174 (1975). Appeal And Error  1050.1(6); Damages  172(1)

Permitting patient who brought malpractice action against physician and surgeon to introduce into evidence more than $6,000 in medical bills was not reversible error. Variety Children's Hospital v. Osle, App. 3 Dist., 292 So.2d 382 (1974). Appeal And Error  1050.1(6)

In action for damages to automobile truck, fixing amount of damages on basis of replacement of broken parts together with labor therefor, in absence of objection to evidence relating to such costs, or charge that amount allowed by jury was unreasonable or greater than cost of replacement or was otherwise excessive was harmless, if error. Independent Ice & Cold Storage Co. v. Tampa Sand & Material Co., 126 Fla. 846, 171 So. 797 (1937). Appeal And Error  1050.1(6)

head.head.info: 51. ---- Exclusion of evidence, damages

para.paratext: Refusal, in action in which recovery was sought for injuries sustained as result of intersectional collision and in which liability was admitted but issue was raised as to damages, to admit photographs and testimony, which related to force of impact of vehicles, as relevant evidence as to extent of injuries sustained was reversible error. Traud v. Waller, App. 3 Dist., 272 So.2d 19 (1973). Appeal And Error  1056.1(7); Damages  166(1)

head.head.info: 52. Death actions

para.paratext: Where insurer defended actions on life policies on ground that insured committed suicide, exclusion, on ground that they were “privileged communications”, of statements made by insured on day before his death to attorney, in course of a general conversation, to effect that he intended to “go west” or “they'd find him in the river”, constituted reversible error. Modern Woodmen of America v. Watkins, 1942, 132 F.2d 352. Federal Courts  903

Testimony, in a wrongful death action, that defendant previously had killed another person, was improper and prejudicial, and in view of fact decedent was a college student discovered by defendant while apparently prowling defendant's motel premises at hour of about 5 a.m., adverse effect of such testimony would not be deemed adequately removed by an instruction that jury disregard such testimony. Carbone v. Coblentz, App. 3 Dist., 132 So.2d 629 (1961). Appeal And Error  1050.1(7); Appeal And Error  1053(2); Death  60

In death action, admission in evidence of certain federal withholding certificates, which showed decedent's earnings in an employment from which he had apparently retired, was if error, harmless in view of other elements proved and amount of verdict. Shearn v. Orlando Funeral Home, 82 So.2d 866 (1955). Appeal And Error  1050.1(11); Appeal And Error  1052(5)

head.head.info: 53. Deeds and conveyances--Admission of evidence

para.paratext: Reference, in opinion portion of trial court's decree, to court's taking judicial knowledge of certain realty sales, was not ground for reversal of decree refusing injunction against tax collection, where examination of decree as whole showed that such knowledge of sales did not enter into court's determination. Harbond, Inc. v. Anderson, App. 2 Dist., 134 So.2d 816 (1961). Appeal And Error  1047(1)

In suit involving question of whether transactions in controversy were deeds or mortgages, testimony as to similar transactions between one of the parties and other persons not parties to the transactions in controversy was admissible and any error in admitting such evidence was harmless where remaining evidence amply supported finding that transactions in question were mortgages and not deeds. Smith v. Biscayne Park Estates, 42 So.2d 442 (1949). Appeal And Error  1051(1); Evidence  130

head.head.info: 54. ---- Exclusion of evidence, deeds and conveyances

para.paratext: In suit to cancel deed executed by married woman, excluding testimony of notary public which did not contradict official certificate of acknowledgment, and which tended to show facts of acknowledgment transaction, was reversible error. Pritchett v. Brevard Naval Stores Co., 126 Fla. 156, 170 So. 610 (1936). Acknowledgment  62(1); Appeal And Error  1056.1(4.1)

Where pleadings raised issue as to whether deed was obtained by fraud and undue influence, excluding grantee's testimony as to consideration for deed, if error, was harmless, where ten cent revenue stamp noted in deed indicated relatively small consideration, and reservation of life estate in grantor and grantees' obligation to pay accrued taxes and keep up insurance indicated nature and value of consideration. Hazen v. Robinson, 123 Fla. 392, 167 So. 1 (1936). Appeal And Error  1056.1(4.1)

head.head.info: 55. Dog bite cases

para.paratext: Where admission which was admissible as exception to hearsay rule and which had bearing upon issue of defendants' ownership of dog which bit plaintiff was improperly excluded and where there was no other testimony in record concerning ownership of dog, exclusion constituted error prejudicial to the plaintiff appellant. McKay v. Perry, App. 2 Dist., 286 So.2d 262 (1973). Appeal And Error  1056.1(10)

head.head.info: 56. Employee injuries

para.paratext: Error in admitting for impeachment purposes a report indicating that employee suing for alleged herniation of two cervical discs and 25 percent permanent partial disability had suffered whiplash injury some three and one-half months prior to occurrence giving rise to the action was prejudicial to employee, considering facts that a principal defense centered around prior similar injury and that record was devoid of any other probative evidence of prior injury. Stafford v. Southern Bell Tel. & Tel. Co., App. 2 Dist., 179 So.2d 232 (1965), certiorari discharged 190 So.2d 339. Appeal And Error  1050.1(6)

In action for injuries from dermatitis caused by use of chromate, frequent altercations between counsel, considered cumulatively, with errors in admission of certain evidence, and errors in permitting calling of witnesses, were prejudicial and required a new trial on question of liability as well as on question of damages. Seaboard Air Line R. Co. v. Ford, 92 So.2d 160 (1955). Appeal And Error  1048(2); Appeal And Error  1050.1(7); Appeal And Error  1060.1(1); Appeal And Error  1178(6)

In action against railroad for injuries to employee, letter written by Veterans' Administration official to union official and correspondence regarding it between railroad's attorney and physician, wherein attorney expressed amusement at Veterans' Administration diagnosis, were not admissible in absence of evidence that railroad had any connection with writing of Veterans' Administration letter or its subject matter, or of any conspiracy to defeat employee's claim, and admission thereof was prejudicial where counsel frequently referred adversely to amusement expressed in letters. Seaboard Air Line R. Co. v. Strickland, 88 So.2d 519 (1956). Appeal And Error  1050.1(6); Evidence  357

Where evidence was in record from which jury could have found that employee's injuries received while engaged in repairing defendant's storm damaged electrical equipment were caused by defendant's faulty engineering design of equipment involved, error, if any, in admission of evidence to effect that defendant replaced all equipment similar to that involved in accident immediately after accident, was immaterial. Florida Power & Light Co. v. Brinson, 67 So.2d 407 (1953). Appeal And Error  1050.1(7)

head.head.info: 57. Highways and roads

para.paratext: Admitting evidence of settlement of claims of motor scooter driver and his father against defendant city was prejudicial error in suit against city for motor scooter passenger's death which arose from out of the same accident and in which the driver was a witness. Jordan v. City of Coral Gables, 191 So.2d 38 (1966). Appeal And Error  1050.1(10); Evidence  219(3)

Admission of photographs showing damages to road built by contractor from hurricane and rain which had been declared disaster by federal government and used by municipality to obtain federal disaster relief was error prejudicial to contractor who sued for final payment and damages under road construction contract. L. L. Hall Const. Co. v. Town of Indialantic, App. 2 Dist., 162 So.2d 544 (1964). Appeal And Error  1050.1(11); Evidence  359(3)

head.head.info: 58. Insurance cases--Admission of evidence

para.paratext: Error, if any, in admission of expert testimony, in action by insured against insurers on fire policy covering goods, furniture, and fixtures in insured's store, that cardboard box placed on energized electric hot plate would catch fire and commence to burn within thirty seconds was harmless and not justification for reversal of judgment for insured, in view of nature of testimony. Home Ins. Co. v. Wiggins, App. 1 Dist., 147 So.2d 157 (1962), certiorari denied 152 So.2d 170. Appeal And Error  1050.1(12)

In suit on accident policy, admission of affidavit of claim and proof of claim for benefits, offered to establish compliance with terms of policy, if erroneous, was harmless error, as against contention that insurer had made no denial of proper proof. Police & Firemen's Ins. Ass'n v. Hines, 134 Fla. 298, 183 So. 831 (1938). Appeal And Error  1050.1(5)

head.head.info: 59. ---- Exclusion of evidence, insurance cases

para.paratext: In actions on life policies, where evidence left in no doubt that insurer regarded as material answers in which applicant denied existence of prior stomach ailment and medical treatment within past five years, exclusion of medical examiner's opinion that applications would have been denied if examiner had known of applicant's prior treatment for cardio spasm was harmless, since the opinion, if admitted, would not have been conclusive of the materiality of the answers but would only have been evidentiary. Metropolitan Life Ins. Co. v. Madden, 1941, 117 F.2d 446. Federal Courts  901.1

In action on policy insuring against loss resulting from theft of automobile, wherein there was evidence that alleged thief was actual owner from whom automobile had been stolen by a third party, and evidence that alleged thief had sold automobile to third party, declaration of alleged thief containing statement about suit by alleged thief against third party for robbery of automobile and that verdict therein had been awarded to alleged thief, and pleas and judgments in such suit, were essential to full understanding of issues and exclusion thereof was harmful error. State Assur. Underwriters of Provident Fire Ins. Co. v. Miller, 58 So.2d 532 (1952). Appeal And Error  1056.1(9); Evidence  116; Judgment  744

In suit to reform and recover on fire policy, any error in exclusion of evidence of breach of sole and unconditional ownership clause of policy was harmless where excluded evidence was considered by Supreme Court. Royal Ins. Co. v. Smith, 158 Fla. 472, 29 So.2d 244 (1947). Appeal And Error  1056.1(9)

head.head.info: 60. Invasion of privacy

para.paratext: Where whole force and trend of defendant's evidence, in action for damages for invasion of plaintiff's right of privacy, was to exalt and praise defendant and to establish her great prominence, which was not an issue, which evidence tended to confuse jury and withdraw its consideration from issue as to whether plaintiff was the one concerning whom there was a general and legitimate public interest rather than defendant, a reversal of a judgment for defendant was required. Cason v. Baskin, 159 Fla. 31, 30 So.2d 635 (1947). Appeal And Error  1050.1(7)

head.head.info: 61. Labor and materials

para.paratext: In action to recover for building materials furnished defendant in construction of a residence, if refusal of trial court to permit introduction of defendant's plea of payment and the support of it by certain canceled checks which were proffered in evidence was error, it was not harmful because it appeared that when defendant proffered canceled checks trial court agreed to permit any of them to be introduced on showing that they were used in payment of items on which plaintiff's suit was predicated. Wood v. Wagner, 55 So.2d 537 (1951). Appeal And Error  1056.1(6)

In action against drainage district for services rendered, taking judicial notice of unpleaded chancery order, outside record in case, appointing receiver of defendant, was reversible error. Cassels v. Ideal Farms Drainage Dist., 156 Fla. 152, 23 So.2d 247 (1945). Appeal And Error  1047(1); Evidence  43(3); Pleading  6

head.head.info: 62. Landlord and tenant cases

para.paratext: In tenant's action against landlords for damages for their breach of $225 per month lease of commercial building to be used as restaurant and dance hall, it was prejudicial error to refuse to admit testimony of tenant's expert real estate broker that fair market value of lease at time of its breach was sum of $350 per month. McCone v. Adams, App. 1 Dist., 239 So.2d 859 (1970). Appeal And Error  1056.1(6); Evidence  522

In statutory proceeding for unlawful detainer by transferee of the grantee of landlord against tenant, wherein it was made to appear that landlord had relinquished all interest that he had in the realty, and wherein there was no showing by tenant as to when his lease from landlord expired, it was not reversible error to sustain objections to questions to tenant relative to landlord's consent or nonconsent to the payment of rent by the tenant to the transferee. Gray v. Callahan, 143 Fla. 673, 197 So. 396 (1940). Appeal And Error  1056.1(4.1); Landlord And Tenant  291(12)

head.head.info: 63. Malpractice actions

para.paratext: Refusal, in malpractice action against hospital and surgeon, to allow expert pathology witness to testify on behalf of surgeon, who alleged that hospital pathologists were negligent in not keeping two cysts removed from patient's breasts separate during dissection, that it was a deviation from acceptable standard of care for pathologists to dissect specimens from single container without attempting to ascertain from which breast each specimen came was not reversible error. Variety Children's Hospital v. Osle, App. 3 Dist., 292 So.2d 382 (1974). Appeal And Error  1056.1(10)

head.head.info: 64. Motor vehicle accidents--Admission of evidence

para.paratext: In action for injuries received in automobile accident, admission of evidence that plaintiff had been receiving welfare benefits for her children, for purpose of rebutting plaintiff's testimony regarding her motivation to return for work, was prejudicial error. Williams v. Pincombe, App. 4 Dist., 309 So.2d 10 (1975). Appeal And Error  1050.1(6); Damages  182

It was reversible error to admit, over objections, testimony by officer as to what another officer orally relayed to him as to speed of test automobile, used in making experimental accidental test run. Smith v. Frisch's Big Boy, Inc., App. 2 Dist., 208 So.2d 310 (1968). Appeal And Error  1050.1(10); Evidence  317(2)

Permitting defendant, over timely objection by plaintiffs to answer her counsel's question as to whether she had received a traffic ticket as result of accident was prejudicial error warranting new trial in action arising out of the accident. Volk v. Goetz, App. 4 Dist., 206 So.2d 250 (1967). Appeal And Error  1050.1(4); Automobiles  243(1)

In action for injuries sustained in collision between automobile and tractor which occurred in automobile's proper lane of travel, admission of testimony of highway patrolman as to point of impact was harmless. Alterman Transport Lines, Inc. v. McCahon, App. 3 Dist., 168 So.2d 707 (1964). Appeal And Error  1050.1(12)

In action for injuries sustained when defendants' automobile allegedly came out of side street at high rate of speed and collided with automobile in which plaintiff was riding, trial judge did not commit harmful error in admitting into evidence a traffic code provision, which did not make specific speed criteria of unlawful act but which made speed greater than was reasonable and prudent under conditions existing unlawful, even if there was no evidence as to excessive speed of automobile in which plaintiff was riding. Driscoll v. Morris, App. 3 Dist., 114 So.2d 314 (1959). Appeal And Error  1050.1(4)

In action for damages sustained by plaintiff when his automobile, while traveling on a multilaned through street was struck by defendant's taxicab as it was crossing the through street from an intersecting stop street, trial court prejudicially erred in admitting into evidence subsection of a city ordinance providing that operator of a vehicle shall not overtake and pass another vehicle proceeding in the same direction at any intersection of highways, in view of fact such ordinance did not apply to multilaned highways. Wallace v. Taxicabs of Tampa, Inc., App. 2 Dist., 112 So.2d 574 (1959). Appeal And Error  1050.1(4); Automobiles  243(1)

In action by father of fatally injured automobile guest against mother of automobile driver, who failed to negotiate curve, admission of testimony of police officer, who made certain tests at place where accident occurred, as to critical speed of a certain type automobile rounding the curve in question, was not prejudicial error. Myers v. Korbly, App. 2 Dist., 103 So.2d 215 (1958). Appeal And Error  1050.1(12)

In action by pedestrian against owner of truck for injuries sustained by pedestrian when struck by truck while attempting to cross street at intersection, improper admission of testimony of investigating officers that they did not arrest truck driver for a violation of any traffic ordinances of city as result of their investigation of the accident was reversible error, where there was a direct conflict in the evidence at the trial on the vital question whether truck driver drove through a red traffic light. Eggers v. Phillips Hardware Co., 88 So.2d 507 (1956). Appeal And Error  1050.1(4)

Material error is not shown in admitting photographs of the place where automobile collision occurred, where it was explained that changes had been made in the terrain and it clearly appeared that no harm could reasonably have resulted from such admissions. Nelson v. McMillan, 151 Fla. 847, 10 So.2d 565 (1942). Appeal And Error  1050.1(11)

In action for injuries sustained in automobile collision at street intersection, permitting proof of ordinance as to right of way on certain streets by testimony of a policeman instead of by the ordinance was not harmless error, where under evidence existence of valid ordinance creating and authorizing regulation relating to right of way was of first importance. Douglass v. Sapotnick, 126 Fla. 753, 171 So. 765 (1937). Appeal And Error  1050.1(9)

head.head.info: 65. ---- Exclusion of evidence, motor vehicle accidents

para.paratext: Where plaintiff in his case in chief was prevented by trial court from putting in all his proof as to place of motorcycle accident resulting in death of plaintiff's son, exclusion of evidence offered by plaintiff to rebut defendant's evidence that accident happened at a different place was reversible error. Raker v. Clark Dredging Co., 1935, 75 F.2d 146. Federal Courts  901.1

Where plaintiff, in a wrongful death action against alleged owner of truck involved in fatal accident, had a right, irrespective of a conditional sales contract under which defendant purchased truck, to question defendant as to whether he maintained liability insurance on the truck at the time of the accident, as relevant on question of whether the truck was owned by defendant, but plaintiff failed to so question defendant, exclusion from evidence of the contract which contained an agreement by defendant to procure or maintain liability insurance on the truck until full purchase price was paid would not be deemed harmful error in view of fact reception of the contract was not a prerequisite to plaintiff's right to interrogate defendant on the question of liability insurance, and the contract would have been merely cumulative evidence of fact that defendant had purchased the truck prior to the accident, a fact already admitted by testimony of defendant. Hicks v. Land, App. 1 Dist., 117 So.2d 11 (1960), certiorari denied 120 So.2d 617. Appeal And Error  1056.1(5); Appeal And Error  1057(1)

In action against executor of estate of deceased motorist for injuries sustained by plaintiff as a result of head-on collision between automobile in which plaintiff was riding as a passenger and automobile driven by defendant's decedent, of which there was no disinterested eyewitness, excluding testimony of plaintiff as to location and course of decedent's automobile prior to collision, showing negligence of decedent on theory that Dead Man's Statute precluded examination of plaintiff concerning such matters, constituted reversible error. Day v. Stickle, App. 3 Dist., 113 So.2d 559 (1959), certiorari denied 115 So.2d 414. Appeal And Error  1056.1(5); Witnesses  159(2)

Where defendant, though he held title to automobile driven and allegedly purchased by codefendant employee, denied ownership thereof in action for injury to motorcyclist in collision with automobile, evidence that title holder carried insurance against liability for damage resulting from negligent operation of automobile was relevant and admissible under exception to general rule, and exclusion of such evidence required reversal of judgment on verdict directed in favor of title holder solely on ground of lack of evidence of such ownership as would entail liability for negligent operation of automobile. Barnett v. Butler, App. 2 Dist., 112 So.2d 907 (1959). Appeal And Error  1056.1(5); Automobiles  243(2)

head.head.info: 66. Negligence--Admission of evidence

para.paratext: In action for death of railroad employee, admitting evidence showing railroad employees' custom and practice of ignoring crossing signals and charging that such practice could be deemed a waiver of railroad's right to expect that its employees would adhere to safety precautions did not constitute reversible error. Jacksonville Terminal Co. v. Hodge, App. 1 Dist., 260 So.2d 521 (1972), certiorari denied 93 S.Ct. 311, 409 U.S. 980, 34 L.Ed.2d 243. Appeal And Error  1050.1(7)

In personal injury action, there was no reversible error in admitting testimony of physician bearing on question of permanent disability of plaintiff, despite failure of plaintiff to furnish a report thereon as required by rule, where such testimony was cumulative to that of two other doctors on the subject, and since the matter of rejection of such testimony in those circumstances was one as to which the trial court had a measure of discretion. Bill Kelley Chevrolet, Inc. v. Kerr, App. 3 Dist., 258 So.2d 280 (1972). Appeal And Error  970(2); Appeal And Error  1050.1(7)

Admission into evidence, over defendant's objection, of testimony that city made changes in meter boxes after plaintiff's foot slipped into one of them was prejudicial error, and fact that a witness for city was questioned on direct examination as to moving of meters did not authorize cross-examination of the witness as to repair of the meter boxes after the accident. City of Niceville v. Hardy, App. 1 Dist., 160 So.2d 535 (1964), certiorari denied 166 So.2d 150. Appeal And Error  1050.1(7); Municipal Corporations  818(11); Witnesses  269(6)

head.head.info: 67. ---- Exclusion of evidence, negligence

para.paratext: Exclusion, in action arising from automobile-train collision against railroad for negligence in operation of its train, and negligently maintaining and controlling its railroad crossing in a dangerous and hazardous condition by permitting trees and other growth to obstruct the vision of oncoming trains, of evidence of a prior accident which involved the same crossing, which occurred at about same time in evening under similar weather conditions, and which occurred two weeks prior to accident at issue, was reversible error; it was properly within the province of the jury to consider the prior accident and it became material in determining whether railroad was at fault. Perret v. Seaboard Coast Line R. Co., 299 So.2d 590 (1974). Appeal And Error  1056.1(10); Railroads  347(4)

head.head.info: 68. Partnership cases

para.paratext: Refusal to permit attorney to testify as to oral statements concerning partnership arrangement made in his presence and that of defendant and cross-claiming codefendant on ground of attorney-client privilege, if error, was harmless, in action for determination by declaratory decree of ownership of certain shares of stock. Hewitt v. Price, App. 3 Dist., 222 So.2d 247 (1969), certiorari denied 225 So.2d 919. Appeal And Error  1056.1(4.1)

In suit to have existence of a partnership to operate a five and ten cent store adjudicated and for a receiver and an accounting, where plaintiff was not relying on written agreement entered into by parties to establish partnership, but on a subsequent parol agreement, refusal to permit plaintiff to prove by parol contents of lost letters written by defendant for purpose of showing that plaintiff failed to make additional payments called for in written agreement because of false representations as to lack of prosperity of the business, if error, was harmless. Nahmod v. Nelson, 147 Fla. 564, 3 So.2d 162 (1941). Appeal And Error  1056.1(4.1)

head.head.info: 69. Pedestrian injuries--Admission of evidence

para.paratext: Admission into evidence, in action for death of six-year-old girl killed by county garbage truck when she was walking along path normally used by pedestrians, of county ordinances for the purpose of defining sidewalk and prohibiting driving on sidewalk, did not constitute reversible error. Metropolitan Dade County v. Dillon, App. 3 Dist., 305 So.2d 36 (1974), certiorari denied 317 So.2d 442. Appeal And Error  1050.1(4)

Admission of accident report, made by injured pedestrian to police officer, in pedestrian's action for personal injuries was improper, but under the circumstances, was not reversible error. Williams v. Scott, App. 2 Dist., 153 So.2d 18 (1963). Appeal And Error  1050.1(11); Privileged Communications And Confidentiality  373

In action by pedestrian against city for injuries sustained when pedestrian stepped into alleged depression in sidewalk and fell, admission of evidence that city repaired sidewalk after the accident was reversible error, though counsel for city in opening statement to jury stated that there was no hole in the sidewalk as contended by pedestrian, and error in the admission of such evidence was not cured by instruction that repair of sidewalk by city was not an admission that a defective and dangerous condition existed. City of Miami Beach v. Wolfe, 83 So.2d 774 (1955). Appeal And Error  1050.1(7); Appeal And Error  1053(4); Municipal Corporations  818(11)

head.head.info: 70. ---- Exclusion of evidence, pedestrian injuries

para.paratext: In action involving issue as to whether defendant-motorist had had last clear chance to avoid hitting plaintiff-pedestrian, who was crossing four-lane highway in dark when struck by automobile, it was error to reject proffered testimony of traffic expert as to time it took for plaintiff to cross range of defendant's vision and as to stopping time of defendant's automobile; and such exclusion of evidence could not be held to have been harmless in view of fact that it had not been necessary for defendant to come to complete stop to avoid harm to plaintiff, who had lacked but a single step, with no slackening of speed, of achieving safety after his hazardous crossing. Mathews v. Carlson, App. 3 Dist., 130 So.2d 625 (1961). Appeal And Error  1056.1(5); Evidence  514(2)

head.head.info: 71. Railroad cases--Admission of evidence

para.paratext: In action against railroad company to recover for injuries and death resulting from crossing collision, the admission of testimony as to failure of crossing signal light to operate on occasions previous to and following the accident, which evidence was introduced for purpose of refuting the asserted perfection and infallibility of the lights, was not reversible error. Atlantic Coast Line R. Co. v. Smith, 1943, 135 F.2d 40. Federal Courts  896.1

No harmful error to railroad and conductor resulted from reception of evidence, charges, or remarks of plaintiff's counsel in suit for injuries sustained by one struck by moving railroad equipment when, according to whose version of evidence was believed, he was either asleep under box car or taking short cut across freight yard. Seaboard Air Line R. Co. v. McCutcheon, App. 3 Dist., 158 So.2d 577 (1963), certiorari denied 165 So.2d 178. Appeal And Error  1050.1(7); Appeal And Error  1060.1(1); Appeal And Error  1064.1(5)

In action against railroad under Federal Employers' Liability Act for injury to chair car attendant when train, traveling at speed of 75 to 78 miles per hour, was hit by truck, and derailed, admitting in evidence ordinance of city in which accident occurred, prohibiting operation of trains at speed in excess of 35 miles per hour, and charging jury that violation of ordinance was prima facie evidence of negligence constituted error requiring reversal of judgment for plaintiff. Florida East Coast Ry. Co. v. Pollack, App. 3 Dist., 154 So.2d 346 (1963). Appeal And Error  1050.1(7); Appeal And Error  1064.1(9); Labor And Employment  2880; Labor And Employment  2897

In action by motorist against railroad trustee for injuries to person and property sustained when, in absence of railroad watchman or automatic signals or gates, automobile driven by plaintiff collided with train at crossing, which, under municipal ordinance, was to be guarded by a watchman or the automatic devices, admission of evidence concerning mayor's apparent verbal attempt, in conversation with railroad superintendent, to countermand the ordinance and refusal to grant motorist's requested charge that ordinance was in effect constituted reversible error. Trabulsy v. Loftin, 76 So.2d 143 (1954). Appeal And Error  1050.1(7); Appeal And Error  1067; Evidence  417(3); Railroads  351(5)

In action for injuries to pedestrian struck by defendant's locomotive at railroad crossing as result of catching his foot in flangeway between rail and plank, admission of testimony of plaintiff's witness, who was experienced carpenter and tramroad builder familiar with particular crossing, that it was dangerous to pedestrians in his opinion, to rebut testimony of defendants' employees that crossing was in good condition, was not error harmful to defendant. Loftin v. Dagley, 152 Fla. 831, 13 So.2d 311 (1943). Appeal And Error  1050.1(12)

In actions for injuries resulting from collision between truck and defendants' freight train at railroad crossing, where question of plaintiffs' right to recover was close one under evidence, error in admitting rebuttal testimony of plaintiff's witnesses as to negligent operation of trains at such crossing on subsequent occasions was not harmless to defendant, as plaintiffs might not have prevailed without such testimony even under statute creating presumption of railroad company's negligence and comparative negligence statute. Powell v. Horne, 149 Fla. 240, 5 So.2d 451 (1942). Appeal And Error  1050.1(7)

In action against railroad for injury to land from overflow allegedly caused by insufficiency of culverts in embankment to permit natural passage of heavy rains, no harmful error was committed in admitting photographs of the embankment to show the condition of the culverts, where the embankments had been partially removed at time photographs were taken but condition of culverts was unchanged. Atlantic Coast Line R. Co. v. Saffold, 130 Fla. 598, 178 So. 288 (1938). Appeal And Error  1050.1(11)

Admitting city ordinance regulating speed of trains, if error, was harmless, where other evidence disclosed excessive speed at time of collision with automobile. Atlantic Coast Line R. Co. v. Lamphear, 109 Fla. 25, 146 So. 847 (1933). Appeal And Error  1050.1(11)

In death action, admitting evidence that defendant's engineer had killed two other men since deceased was prejudicial error. Florida East Coast Ry. Co. v. Young, 104 Fla. 541, 140 So. 467 (1932). Appeal And Error  1050.2

In subrogation suit by insurer of truck against railroad allegedly liable for fire loss, testimony of city fire chief relating to probability of overturned automobile commencing to burn and giving incidents was prejudicial error. Atlantic Coast Line R. Co. v. Campbell, 104 Fla. 274, 139 So. 886 (1932). Evidence  527

head.head.info: 72. ---- Exclusion of evidence, railroad cases

para.paratext: Where railway's own rule with respect to speed limit was not clear in its language with respect to applicability of limit, trial court did not commit reversible error in refusing to admit evidence that rule was applicable or in failing to stop railway's counsel from arguing to jury that limit was not applicable. Hodge v. Jacksonville Terminal Co., App. 1 Dist., 170 So.2d 481 (1964). Appeal And Error  1056.1(10); Appeal And Error  1060.1(2.1)

In action for death of railroad flagman as result of falling under defendant's moving freight train in attempting to board caboose at front end, trial court's rejection of defendant's evidence that train conductor told deceased, three weeks before tragedy that it was unsafe practice to catch front end of caboose to board train, was not reversible error, in absence of showing that such practice was contrary to any rule of defendant; such evidence being remote and unrelated to deceased's death. Atlantic Coast Line R. Co. v. Edenfield, 45 So.2d 204 (1950). Appeal And Error  1056.1(10)

head.head.info: 73. Real estate brokers' actions

para.paratext: Reception of evidence of alleged conspiracy between vendor and others through whom title eventually passed to prospective purchaser whom broker had originally produced, depriving broker of his fee, was not prejudicial to vendor even though conspiracy count had been dismissed as to him, where he was also being sued for broker's fee on breach of brokerage contract theory, and conspiracy count was not dismissed as to remaining defendants. Willis v. Clark, App. 2 Dist., 135 So.2d 260 (1961). Appeal And Error  1050.1(7)

In suit involving agent's real estate commission, wherein there were material conflicts in the evidence as to whether real estate agent was given a definite listing with definite terms by owner and whether agent had found a willing purchaser, refusal to require agent, who had testified when he was called as witness for owner that agent then had in his possession in the court room a written contract with prospective purchaser and that such contract contained certain terms, to produce contract, was reversible error, as against contention that contract was immaterial and that rules with reference to notice had not been complied with. Nottingham v. Schulhof, 61 So.2d 912 (1952). Appeal And Error  1047(5); Evidence  368(4)

In broker's action for commission for procuring purchaser of realty, admission of evidence as to which objections were well grounded was not reversible error, in view of entire record. Stewart v. Manget, 136 Fla. 710, 187 So. 695 (1939). Appeal And Error  1050.1(5)

head.head.info: 74. Ships and shipping

para.paratext: Refusal to admit exhibit allegedly revealing prior dealings between one defendant and corporation controlled by president of plaintiff corporation and demonstrating indebtedness on which defendant's claim against ship was based was not error, in view of reviewing court's examination of tendered document which showed it to be entirely irrelevant to defendant's claim. Pickard v. Maritime Holdings Corp., App. 3 Dist., 161 So.2d 239 (1964). Appeal And Error  1056.1(4.1)

head.head.info: 75. Trusts and trustees

para.paratext: In action wherein plaintiff sought and obtained decree holding that certain lands, title to which was in defendants, were held by them in a resulting trust for plaintiff, trial court committed prejudicial error in ruling for plaintiff upon finding that preponderance of evidence favored him rather than requiring that evidence favoring him be so clear, positive and unequivocal as to dispel from mind of trier of facts all reasonable doubts as to existence of trust. Estey v. Vizor, App. 3 Dist., 113 So.2d 576 (1959). Appeal And Error  1047(1); Trusts  89(5)

In suit to set aside trust agreement, error in exclusion of beneficiaries' testimony pursuant to dead man's statute was not prejudicial. Murrey v. Barnett Nat. Bank of Jacksonville, 74 So.2d 647 (1954). Appeal And Error  1056.1(8)

head.head.info: 76. Vendor and purchaser cases

para.paratext: In action to establish seller's right to amount which had been deposited in escrow in connection with sale of realty, in view of evidence bearing on central issue of compliance with one condition by seller, refusal to admit letter written to optionee by attorney for seller, if error, was harmless error. Specialty Restaurant Corp. v. Village of Four Winds Corp., App. 3 Dist., 273 So.2d 102 (1973). Appeal And Error  1056.1(6)

head.head.info: 77. Water pollution cases

para.paratext: In suit to recover damages to enjoyment of land resulting from pollution of adjacent waters by a municipal sewage disposal plant, admission of evidence to establish damage resulting from bites of mosquitoes propagated because of filth from plant did not constitute prejudicial error, where record, without taking into account damages alleged to have accrued by reason of mosquito bites, would have supported a verdict for a larger amount than that awarded. City of Lakeland v. Douglass, 143 Fla. 771, 197 So. 467 (1940). Appeal And Error  1050.1(6)

head.head.info: 78. Zoning cases

para.paratext: In equitable proceeding by landowners against city to enjoin enforcement of zoning ordinance prohibiting landowners' construction of multiple level parking garage with stores along street, error, if any, in admitting certain expert testimony concerning lease and in refusing to allow testimony relating to leases on comparable property as basis for establishing market value was inconsequential and harmless. Rott v. City of Miami Beach, 94 So.2d 168 (1957). Appeal And Error  1050.1(12)

head.head.info: 79. Divorce cases

para.paratext: Testimony by former wives of man with whom ex-wife and child lived concerning his ability to provide proper environment for raising child and his relationship with his own child was relevant to ex-husband's action to modify child custody, and exclusion of testimony was reversible error, where man had pervasive presence in lives of ex-wife and child, and nature of environment at his house was critical factor in determining whether custody should be changed. O'Shea v. O'Shea, App. 1 Dist., 585 So.2d 405 (1991). Child Custody  632; Child Custody  923(4)

head.head.info: 80. Damages

para.paratext: Question of compensation due landowner for severance damages in eminent domain proceeding was for jury, where posttrial proffer of testimony to effect that design of bridge and roadway with respect to which property was taken was flawed, leading to negative downstream consequences to remaining property was sufficient to invoke exception to general rule against award of severance damages in event of partial taking, and where state had objected to proffer of such testimony and evidence at trial. West's F.S.A. RCP Rule 1.450(b); Taylor v. State, Dept. of Transp., App. 2 Dist., 701 So.2d 610, 22 Fla. L. Weekly D2513 (1997). Eminent Domain  221

head.head.info: 81. Harmless error

para.paratext: The admission of evidence in certain cases was harmless, or not reversible error. Porter v. Carroll, 84 Fla. 62, 92 So. 809 (1922); Investment Co. v. Trueman, 63 Fla. 184, 57 So. 663 (1912); Williams v. Hampton, 57 Fla. 272, 49 So. 506 (1909).

The exclusion of evidence in certain cases was harmless, or not reversible error. Atlantic Coast Line R. Co. v. Shouse, 92 Fla. 156, 91 So. 90 (1922); Atlantic Coast Line R. Co. v. Turman, 80 Fla. 285, 86 So. 199 (1920); First Nat. Bank v. Williams, 77 Fla. 840, 82 So. 296 (1919); Vaughan's Seed Store v. Stringfellow, 56 Fla. 708, 48 So. 410 (1909).

Trial court's refusal to admit into evidence testimony and written memorandum of daycare center employee in charge of safety issues at daycare center was harmless error in personal injury action arising from injuries minor received in fall from daycare center's playground equipment, even though portion of memorandum was admissible because it dealt with cause of accident, where information was admitted at trial through portion of employee's deposition read to jury. Castaneda ex rel. Cardona v. Redlands Christian Migrant Ass'n, Inc., App. 4 Dist., 884 So.2d 1087 (2004). Appeal And Error  1058(1)

Exclusion of testimony of attorney concerning conversation between attorney and alleged client constituted prejudicial error requiring reversal where alleged client herself disavowed attorney-client relationship, conversation took place in presence of adverse party to litigation, and excluded testimony could materially affect outcome of case. Dionise v. Keyes Co., App. 3 Dist., 319 So.2d 614 (1975). Appeal And Error  1056.1(2); Privileged Communications And Confidentiality  116; Privileged Communications And Confidentiality  158

Error of circuit judge in taking judicial notice of another suit pending before and decided by circuit court was harmless where entire record of earlier case, although not introduced in evidence, was included in record on appeal and there was no showing of any prejudice to petitioner by procedure; although there was conflict with its prior decision Supreme Court would not disturb decision of trial court and of District Court of Appeal. Mennella Plastering, Inc. v. Adobe Brick & Supply Co., Inc., 273 So.2d 1 (1973). Appeal And Error  1047(1)

In obscenity case, any error in trial court's excluding expert testimony on issue of redeeming social value and testimony that, although film was hard-core pornography, it did not violate contemporary community standards was harmless where film had been viewed by trial judge and by appellate court and was found to be hard-core pornography. Art Theatre Enterprises, Inc. v. State ex rel. Gerstein, App. 3 Dist., 260 So.2d 267 (1972). Appeal And Error  1056.4

Any error in excluding testimony proffered by plaintiff in action on alleged bailment contract was harmless, where complete delivery to defendant essential to bailment was lacking and no breach of duty by defendant was established. Florida Small Business Corp. v. Miami Shipyards Corp., App. 3 Dist., 175 So.2d 46 (1965). Appeal And Error  1056.6

Exclusion of plaintiff's tendered evidence was not harmful error where evidence would not have established prima facie case for claimed estoppel. Boyeff v. Savard, App. 3 Dist., 136 So.2d 260 (1962). Appeal And Error  1056.6

In adjacent property owners' suit to restrain boat yard operator from conducting his activities so as to constitute a public and private nuisance wherein Chancellor allowed county resources and development board to intervene Chancellor's rejection of proffered testimony to effect that, while board had no direct interest in litigation, it had indirect interest contemplated by its charter in promotion of business in county was harmful neither to development board nor to defendant, since final decree did not restrain defendant economically. Milling v. Berg, App. 2 Dist., 104 So.2d 658 (1958). Appeal And Error  1056.4

Where all evidence including that rejected failed to furnish sufficient basis for a judgment in favor of party offering rejected evidence, refusal to receive such evidence, if error, was harmless. Hopkins v. McClure, 45 So.2d 656 (1950). Appeal And Error  1056.6
On appeal, procedural irregularities in submitting evidence may be immaterial. Coleman v. Williams, 146 Fla. 45, 200 So. 207 (1941). Appeal And Error  1050.1(1)

In action of ejectment, error, if any, in refusing to allow plaintiffs to prove payment of taxes on property in controversy by plaintiffs' agent, was not prejudicial to plaintiffs, especially where jury would not have been justified in finding for plaintiffs even if evidence of payment of taxes by agent had been before jury. Blitch v. Sapp, 142 Fla. 166, 194 So. 328 (1940). Appeal And Error  1056.6

Exclusion of evidence, even if error, was harmless, where result would have been the same had the evidence been admitted. Rance v. Hutchinson, 131 Fla. 460, 179 So. 777 (1938). Appeal And Error  1056.1(1)

Where plaintiff's whole evidence as tendered was insufficient to sustain recovery under count upon which case eventually went to trial, alleged errors in rulings on evidence were immaterial. Boyd v. University Athletic Ass'n, 117 Fla. 188, 157 So. 576 (1934). Appeal And Error  1047(1)

Any technical or conventional errors in rejection of evidence are immaterial in personal injury action where evidence is not sufficient to establish defendant's negligence. Powell v. Wilson Lumber Co. of Florida, 115 Fla. 13, 155 So. 116 (1934). Appeal And Error  1068(3)

Technical error committed by a trial court in the reception or rejection of evidence does not necessarily constitute harmful error. It is injury resulting from error that warrants an appellate court in reversing a judgment of the trial court. Butler v. State, 94 Fla. 163, 113 So. 699 (1927).

Errors assigned on admission of evidence, which are technical and not fundamental, and are harmless in view of entire record, will not cause reversal. City of Jacksonville v. Vaughn, 92 Fla. 339, 110 So. 529 (1926). Appeal And Error  1050.1(1)
Where verdict is sustained by the evidence, harmless errors in rulings on evidence are not cause for reversal. Graham v. Holmes, 73 Fla. 85, 74 So. 5 (1917). Appeal And Error  1047(1)

head.head.info: 82. Review

para.paratext: Sex offender failed to preserve for appellate review his claim that the trial court erred when it allowed clinical psychologist to testify as to why a witness might not recall a sexual assault incident that occurred during childhood, where offender objected to the testimony at trial on the basis that psychologist did not interview witness, and on appeal offender argued that psychologist's testimony was irrelevant and constituted improper bolstering. Marshall v. State, App. 4 Dist., 915 So.2d 264 (2005). Mental Health  467

Appellants challenging award of attorneys fees failed to preserve issue of whether trial court should have cut off further testimony, where appellants' attorney failed to proffer the testimony he was seeking to present. Ketterson v. Estate of Bruns, App. 4 Dist., 711 So.2d 613 (1998). Appeal And Error  205

As general rule, if proffer of evidence which trial court refused to admit is not made, appellate court cannot determine propriety of excluding evidence; however, proffer is unnecessary where offer would be useless ceremony, or evidence is rejected as class, or where court indicates such offer would be unavailing. O'Shea v. O'Shea, App. 1 Dist., 585 So.2d 405 (1991). Appeal And Error  205

Proffer of testimony by former wives of man with whom ex-wife and child lived concerning his ability to provide proper environment for raising child and his relationship with his own child was not necessary for appellate court to determine propriety of excluding evidence, where substance of evidence sought was apparent from context within which questions were asked, and trial court limited testimony of former wives as a class. O'Shea v. O'Shea, App. 1 Dist., 585 So.2d 405 (1991). Child Custody  904

Appellant's points urging error as result of trial court's ruling upon admissibility of certain testimony and denying motion for new trial did not present reversible error where no violation of an established rule of law was shown and rulings made were within special province of trial judge. Pan Am. Bancshares, Inc. v. Trask, App. 3 Dist., 278 So.2d 313 (1973). Appeal And Error  1050.1(1); Appeal And Error  1072

Where incompetent evidence has been allowed, in favor of the prevailing party, as to a material point not clearly established by competent evidence, it is ground for reversal. Mizell v. Travelers' Ins. Co., 44 Fla. 799, 33 So. 454 (1902). Appeal And Error  1050.1(2)

Accomplices and co-defendants - Incriminating acts and statements 164

Competency of witnesses, examination of witnesses
Connection and relationship of crimes, other offenses

Curing defects or objections - Accomplices and co-defendants 206
Curing defects or objections - Admissions by accused 208
Curing defects or objections - Exclusion of similar evidence 210
Curing defects or objections - Favorability to accused 211

Curing defects or objections - Other evidence of guilt 214
Curing defects or objections - Otherwise established facts 215
Curing defects or objections - Prior or subsequent admission of same evidence 216
Curing defects or objections - Prior or subsequent examination of same witness 217
Curing defects or objections - Subsequent propriety of evidence 218
