analysis.entry.analysis.line: Wrongfully obtained evidence - Searches and seizures 149

head.head.info: 111. In general, criminal cases

para.paratext: Where no fundamental rights have been violated and evidence of guilt is sufficient, technical errors in ruling on admission of testimony will not cause a reversal. Ballard v. State, App., 323 So.2d 297 (1975); Mahone v. State, App., 222 So.2d 769 (1969); Ruiz v. State, App., 199 So.2d 478 (1967), certiorari denied 88 S.Ct. 2068, 392 U.S. 910, 20 L.Ed.2d 1368.

General rule is that whether material evidence which could have been received as part of the case in chief should be admitted in rebuttal lies solely within the discretion of the trial court, and prejudice to defendant occurs only if a prosecution witness goes beyond rebuttal and injects fresh issues on which the defendant is denied the right to present evidence. U. S. v. Sadler, 1974, 488 F.2d 434, certiorari denied 94 S.Ct. 2642, 417 U.S. 931, 41 L.Ed.2d 234. Criminal Law  684; Criminal Law  1168(2)

Conviction will not be reversed for errors in rulings on admissibility of evidence or in procedural matters generally, where evidence of guilt is strong and no fundamental rights of defendant were violated and it appears that errors, if any, were not prejudicial. Bowden v. State, App. 2 Dist., 137 So.2d 621 (1962). Criminal Law  1166.6; Criminal Law  1169.1(1)

Judgment should not be reversed or new trial granted for errors in rulings on admission or rejection of evidence, in giving or refusing charges, or in any other matter of procedure or practice, unless it appears from consideration of entire cause that such errors injuriously affect substantial rights of complaining party. Driggers v. State, 90 Fla. 324, 105 So. 841 (1925). Criminal Law  1169.1(1)

head.head.info: 112. Prejudicial effect, criminal cases

para.paratext: Error, if any, in the admission of evidence not prejudicial to the accused will not warrant a reversal. Farley v. State, 88 Fla. 159, 101 So. 239 (1924); Scott v. State, 87 Fla. 12, 99 So. 245 (1924); Ellis v. State, 83 Fla. 322, 91 So. 192 (1922); Ward v. State, 83 Fla. 311, 91 So. 189 (1922); Sykes v. State, 78 Fla. 167, 82 So. 778 (1918); Hicks v. State, 75 Fla. 311, 78 So. 270 (1918); McKinney v. State, 74 Fla. 25, 76 So. 333 (1917); Nichols v. State, 64 Fla. 381, 60 So. 181 (1912).

Errors in the rejection of evidence, not prejudicial to the accused, will not warrant a reversal. Farley v. State, 88 Fla. 159, 101 So. 239 (1924); Ellis v. State, 83 Fla. 322, 91 So. 192 (1922); Ward v. State, 83 Fla. 311, 91 So. 189 (1922); Douglass v. State, 53 Fla. 27, 43 So. 424 (1907).

Evidentiary rulings did not constitute prejudicial error where they concerned nonessential matters and did not prevent defendants from presenting matters important to their defense and did not tend to prejudice defendants before the jury. Lopez v. State, App. 3 Dist., 264 So.2d 69 (1972), certiorari denied 268 So.2d 161. Criminal Law  1168(1)

In deciding whether the erroneously admitted evidence was prejudicial, testimony must be considered in light of entire transcript. Coppolino v. State, App. 2 Dist., 223 So.2d 68 (1968), appeal dismissed 234 So.2d 120, certiorari denied 90 S.Ct. 2242, 399 U.S. 927, 26 L.Ed.2d 794. Criminal Law  1169.1(1)

In order to be a ground for reversal an error in the rejection or admission of evidence must be such as to have been prejudicial to defendant. State v. Wadsworth, 210 So.2d 4 (1968). Criminal Law  1169.1(1); Criminal Law  1170(1)

head.head.info: 113. Constitutional error, criminal cases

para.paratext: Court cannot declare constitutional error harmless unless it can declare with confidence beyond reasonable doubt that record excludes possibility that evidence complained of might have contributed to conviction. Blackburn v. Cross, 1975, 510 F.2d 1014, rehearing denied 517 F.2d 464. Criminal Law  1169.1(1)

Where independent evidence of guilt is overwhelming, constitutional error can be rendered harmless. Sullivan v. State, 303 So.2d 632 (1974), certiorari denied 96 S.Ct. 3226, 428 U.S. 911, 49 L.Ed.2d 1220, rehearing denied 97 S.Ct. 190, 429 U.S. 873, 50 L.Ed.2d 154, stay denied 104 S.Ct. 450, 464 U.S. 109, 78 L.Ed.2d 210. Criminal Law  1169.2(1)

head.head.info: 114. Harmless error, criminal cases

para.paratext: In view of weight of evidence against pilot of airplane which carried 400 pounds of marijuana into country, and error in admission of incriminating statement allegedly made by defendant on arrest and any error in refusing evidentiary hearing on charge that Government suppressed evidence that pilot landed at place without customs facilities because airplane was low on fuel was harmless beyond reasonable doubt. U. S. v. Gattie, 1975, 511 F.2d 608. Criminal Law  1168(1); Criminal Law  1169.12

Evidentiary presumption allowing an inference of guilt from possession which is contained in statute governing offense of dispensing and distributing a narcotic not in or from the original stamped container and which has recently been invalidated by Supreme Court as applied to possession of cocaine has practical value only where evidence shows that defendant merely possessed narcotics and, thus, where testimony of government agent alone is sufficient to prove elements of crime, use of presumption would be superfluous and would probably constitute harmless error. U. S. v. Ferra, 1970, 427 F.2d 1348. Criminal Law  1168(1); Internal Revenue  5291.1

In determining whether error in admission of evidence was harmless, court, considering proceedings as whole, would determine whether evidence in other respects was evenly balanced or one-sided and whether court could say that error did not influence jury or had but very slight effect. U. S. v. Cohen, 1969, 418 F.2d 68. Criminal Law  1169.1(1)

Any error in trial court's admission of evidence that defendant belonged to group known as “Zombie Boys” was harmless, in murder trial, given other evidence introduced at trial. Laflipe v. State, App. 3 Dist., 888 So.2d 104 (2004). Criminal Law  1169.11

Trial court's erroneous admission of police officer's testimony that he received a tip that defendant was processing and dealing in heroin from his home was harmless in prosecution for attempted trafficking in heroin, possession of marijuana, and possession of drug paraphernalia; error could not have affected verdict in light of defendant's admissions to a police officer, his knowledge that contraband was hidden under insoles of visitor's shoes, and the evidence of drug dealing in the home. Alvelo v. State, App. 5 Dist., 866 So.2d 1240 (2004), rehearing denied. Criminal Law  1169.1(9)

Admitting detective's irrelevant testimony about ability to see without his eyeglasses and his participation in reenactment of the crime was harmless in capital murder prosecution; three surviving witnesses saw or heard the defendant kill the victims, two of them identified the defendant as the shooter, and the defendant had wallet and guns tying him to the murders and rented storage unit for the stolen stereo equipment. (Per curiam with two judges concurring and two judges concurring in the result.) Rimmer v. State, 825 So.2d 304 (2002), rehearing denied, certiorari denied 123 S.Ct. 567, 537 U.S. 1034, 154 L.Ed.2d 453, denial of post-conviction relief affirmed 59 So.3d 763. Criminal Law  1169.1(10); Criminal Law  1169.9

Trial court was technically in error in assuming that defendant carried burden of proving facts upon which any objection to admissibility of fingerprint testimony was founded, but such error was harmless. Dargans v. State, App. 2 Dist., 259 So.2d 782 (1972). Criminal Law  334; Criminal Law  1168(1)

Error, if any, in admission of testimony, in oral discussion of counsel, in charges given, in refusal of others, and in other matters of procedure, was not ground for reversal where not harmful. Jarrell v. State, 135 Fla. 736, 185 So. 873 (1939). Criminal Law  1169.1(1); Criminal Law  1171.1(2.1); Criminal Law  1172.1(1)

Error, if any, in not requiring state to elect between proof of shooting or cutting of deceased's throat as proximate cause of death, was harmless, where jury could reasonably infer from state's evidence that death resulted from concurrence of shooting and cutting. McCall v. State, 113 Fla. 469, 152 So. 19 (1934). Criminal Law  1168(2)
Technical errors in rulings on evidence are not ground for reversal, where it is clear the errors were harmless. Owens v. State, 65 Fla. 483, 62 So. 651 (1913). Criminal Law  1168(1)

head.head.info: 115. Outcome or result of case, error not affecting, criminal cases

para.paratext: Error in admission of evidence, which does not materially affect the result, is harmless. Smith v. State, 74 Fla. 44, 76 So. 334 (1917); Barton v. State, 72 Fla. 408, 73 So. 230 (1916).

A conviction will not be reversed for the exclusion of evidence which would not have affected the result. Edington v. State, 81 Fla. 634, 88 So. 468 (1921); Wallace v. State, 41 Fla. 547, 26 So. 713 (1899).
Technical errors do not warrant reversal, where result of trial is manifestly correct. Bell v. State, 65 Fla. 505, 62 So. 654 (1913). Criminal Law  1168(1)

head.head.info: 116. Guilt, sufficiency of evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Alleged errors in rulings on evidence are not ground for reversal, where the evidence leaves no room for reasonable doubt of defendant's guilt. Crane v. State, 76 Fla. 236, 79 So. 806 (1918); Sandlin v. State, 76 Fla. 368, 79 So. 714 (1918).

Alleged errors relating to the weight of testimony, the credibility of witnesses, and the admission or rejection of testimony, which do not weaken the effect of admitted testimony nor reach the legality of the trial itself, are not ground for reversal where evidence leaves no room for reasonable doubt of defendant's guilt. Edington v. State, 81 Fla. 634, 88 So. 468 (1921); Rhodes v. State, 65 Fla. 541, 62 So. 653 (1913); Goff v. State, 60 Fla. 13, 17, 53 So. 327 (1910).

Alleged errors in admission of testimony not affecting legality of trial itself are not ground for reversal where other evidence as a whole leaves no room for reasonable doubt of accused's guilt. Casso v. State, App., 182 So.2d 252 (1966); Driggers v. State, 90 Fla. 324, 105 So. 841 (1925).

Alleged errors in rejecting testimony which did not weaken effect of admitted testimony, and which do not reach legality of trial itself, will not be considered grounds for reversal, where evidence leaves no room for reasonable doubt of accused's guilt. Driggers v. State, 90 Fla. 324, 105 So. 841 (1925); Barton v. State, 72 Fla. 408, 73 So. 230 (1916).

Reservation of ruling in jury case on motion for acquittal made at close of government's case does not constitute harmful error if evidence is sufficient to sustain conviction when government rests. Cooper v. U.S., 1963, 321 F.2d 274, certiorari denied 84 S.Ct. 482, 375 U.S. 964, 11 L.Ed.2d 414, rehearing denied 84 S.Ct. 657, 376 U.S. 929, 11 L.Ed.2d 627. Criminal Law  1168(1)

Where, one week prior to trial, defendant filed motion to suppress any oral or written confessions or statements and immediately attempted to obtain hearing thereon, trial judge committed error in refusing to hear motion before proceeding with trial, but error was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt, in view of other overwhelming evidence establishing defendant's guilt. McDonnell v. State, App. 4 Dist., 292 So.2d 420 (1974), remanded 336 So.2d 553. Criminal Law  413.60; Criminal Law  1168(1)

In a criminal case, where proof of guilt of accused is inconclusive, errors of procedure in the admission of evidence cannot be considered harmless. Porter v. State, 84 Fla. 552, 94 So. 680 (1922). Criminal Law  1169.1(1)

head.head.info: 117. Examination of witnesses, criminal cases--In general

para.paratext: Defendant failed to demonstrate that trial judge's decision to limit the number of character witnesses to three was a prejudicial abuse of discretion particularly in view of fact there was no contradictory testimony. U. S. v. Squella-Avendano, 1973, 478 F.2d 433. Criminal Law  1168(2)

Severe and prejudicial limitations imposed by trial court on defense counsel's efforts to question witnesses during both direct and cross-examination concerning testimony elicited by State deprived defendant of fair trial and mandated reversal of his convictions. Mantici v. State, App. 3 Dist., 406 So.2d 99 (1981). Criminal Law  1170.5(1); Witnesses  224; Witnesses  268(1)

Prosecutor's conduct which departs from prescribed procedure governing questions and answers directed to prior convictions may warrant reversal of conviction, but where that conduct is forestalled by proper objection which is sustained, conviction may not be reversed. Sweetser v. State, App. 3 Dist., 258 So.2d 287 (1972), certiorari denied 261 So.2d 839. Criminal Law  1168(1)

Where each of three prosecutions for grand larceny involved only one check and in each instance check had been signed only by co-owner who testified, convictions were not required to be reversed on theory that each co-owner, in whom ownership of money and nonconsent was laid, should have testified in order to show nonconsent. Cross v. State, App. 2 Dist., 237 So.2d 324 (1970). Criminal Law  1168(2)

Restriction on defense counsel in examination of witnesses at pretrial hearing on motion to suppress evidence was not reversible error, where no evidence on point in issue was admitted or proffered. Romanello v. State, App. 1 Dist., 160 So.2d 529 (1964), certiorari denied 168 So.2d 148, certiorari denied 85 S.Ct. 1541, 381 U.S. 915, 14 L.Ed.2d 436. Criminal Law  1168(1)
The trial court's refusal to permit examination of a certain witness as to the res gestae did not require reversal. Pride v. State, 151 Fla. 473, 10 So.2d 806 (1942). Criminal Law  1170(1)

Where during trial evidence showed that in jail on another floor of courthouse there was person who could give testimony for defendant but it was not shown that accused had made reasonable effort to procure attendance of the person as a witness, refusal to require sheriff to produce the witness was not harmful error. Whitefield v. State, 137 Fla. 552, 188 So. 361 (1939). Criminal Law  1168(2)

head.head.info: 118. ---- Competency of witnesses, examination of witnesses, criminal cases

para.paratext: Although it is not a crime for interested witness to seek to testify as to communications or transactions with the deceased person nor is it a crime for witness to seek to testify as to “hearsay,” unless such offered testimony falls within one of the recognized exceptions, such is not admissible in evidence and if the trial court, over timely objection, admits such and if it is relevant, material and prejudicial then a conviction based thereon will, upon timely appeal, be reversed. Horn v. State, App. 1 Dist., 298 So.2d 194 (1974), certiorari denied 308 So.2d 117. Criminal Law  419(1.5); Criminal Law  1168(3); Criminal Law  1169.1(9); Witnesses  125

Where, in prosecution of father for rape of nine year old daughter, her answers revealed that she was still in first grade in school, had never been taught difference between lies and the truth, had never gone to church, and did not know what an oath was, and after arrest of father, daughter had been delivered into custody of relatives who were antagonistic to the father, and aggressive prosecuting attorney repeatedly asked leading questions of daughter, judgment of conviction would be reversed by supreme court and new trial would be granted. Bell v. State, 93 So.2d 575 (1957). Criminal Law  1168(3); Criminal Law  1170.5(1); Witnesses  45(2); Witnesses  243

The mere fact that an officer has a jury in charge, without more, does not disqualify him from being a witness in the criminal case; whether such procedure will constitute reversible error depends upon the facts and circumstances disclosed by the record. Rhone v. State, 93 So.2d 80 (1957). Criminal Law  1168(3); Witnesses  68

In murder prosecution, allowing young girl, who had not been shown to clearly realize obligation of oath, to testify, was not reversible error where defendant's counsel did not propound questions to ascertain her qualifications. Norris v. State, 108 Fla. 191, 145 So. 761 (1933). Criminal Law  1168(3)

Error, if any, in admitting a child's testimony was harmless where the verdict was sustained by evidence of unquestioned competency. Robinson v. State, 70 Fla. 628, 70 So. 595 (1916). Criminal Law  1168(3)

head.head.info: 119. ---- Cross-examination and re-examination of witnesses, criminal cases

para.paratext: Primary consideration in deciding whether a party has opened the door to comments on cross-examination is whether the witness's answer is responsive to the question asked; if it is, then it is considered invited error. Cartwright v. State, App. 4 Dist., 885 So.2d 1010 (2004). Criminal Law  1137(5)

Victim's testimony in burglary trial that defendant had marijuana in his possession while in victim's residence was responsive to question asked on cross-examination and, thus, was invited error, where defendant asked victim whether it was true that he got rid of defendant's clothes and shoes that were left behind after defendant was arrested rather than turning items over to authorities. Cartwright v. State, App. 4 Dist., 885 So.2d 1010 (2004). Criminal Law  1137(5)

Defendant's failure to proffer testimony he sought to elicit from witness rendered defendant's claim challenging trial court's refusal to allow him to cross-examine witness unpreserved for review; without proffer it was impossible for appellate court to determine whether trial court's ruling was erroneous and, if erroneous, what effect error might have made on result. Finney v. State, 660 So.2d 674 (1995), rehearing denied, certiorari denied 116 S.Ct. 823, 516 U.S. 1096, 133 L.Ed.2d 766, denial of post-conviction relief affirmed 831 So.2d 651. Criminal Law  1036.2

Since the right to ask any particular question on cross-examination when it relates to a collateral matter is normally within discretion of trial court, any denial of an objection to the question normally is not considered so prejudicial as to require reversal. Gelabert v. State, App. 5 Dist., 407 So.2d 1007 (1981). Criminal Law  1153.18(2)

In prosecution for aggravated assault and improper exhibition of a dangerous weapon, which charges were based on defendant allegedly threatening a deputy with a knife when the deputy entered defendant's home, evidence of defendant's relationship with his estranged son and whether he had ever threatened him with a weapon or not was completely collateral to any of the various issues encompassed within the two charges; therefore, trial court improperly permitted cross-examination of defendant on that issue. Gelabert v. State, App. 5 Dist., 407 So.2d 1007 (1981). Witnesses  270(2)

In criminal prosecution, cross-examination of two state witnesses regarding their knowledge of defendant's nonviolent nature was improper in light of fact that there were no facts elicited by the state upon direct examination relative to the defendant's propensity for violence. Buford v. State, 403 So.2d 943 (1981), certiorari denied 102 S.Ct. 1037, 454 U.S. 1163, 71 L.Ed.2d 319, certiorari denied 102 S.Ct. 1039, 454 U.S. 1164, 71 L.Ed.2d 320. Witnesses  269(2.1)

Even if defense counsel had not “opened the door” to redirect by asking certain questions on cross-examination, the error in permitting the redirect was harmless since had the witness been excused without establishing some point the prosecutor deemed vital to his case the simple expedient of recalling the witness would have cured the oversight, even if it had required reopening, particularly absent showing of prejudice. Harnum v. State, App. 2 Dist., 384 So.2d 1320 (1980). Criminal Law  1170.5(5)

Despite contention that defendant in aggravated battery prosecution was deprived of right of cross-examination when trial court sustained objection to questions propounded on cross-examination of victim when victim asserted Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination, record revealed that defendant was not prejudiced thereby. Godwin v. State, App. 1 Dist., 312 So.2d 457 (1975), certiorari denied 330 So.2d 17. Criminal Law  1170(1)

Sustaining state's objection to question on cross-examination of witness who testified regarding defendant's pistol allegedly used in homicide whether witness was a “suspect”, and refusing defendant's proffer that witness had spent five hours in jail under “suspicion” for the crime did not constitute reversible error, where proffer did not include showing that witness was still suspected of the crime or that state had made concessions to witness in exchange for his testimony, and there was other testimony regarding the pistol. Roberts v. State, 164 So.2d 817 (1964). Criminal Law  1168(2); Criminal Law  1170.5(5)

Any error in refusing to direct a verdict of acquittal at the close of state's case for failure to prove venue was harmless, where subsequent cross-examination of accused disclosed that act of intercourse allegedly constituting offense charged was consummated in county where venue was laid. Roberts v. State, 154 Fla. 36, 16 So.2d 435 (1944). Criminal Law  1168(1)

head.head.info: 120. ---- Exclusion or separation of witnesses, examination of witnesses, criminal cases

para.paratext: Conversation between witness and sponsoring counsel at recess during cross-examination, if a violation of the witness sequestration rule, was harmless error under the circumstances of this case because it had no effect upon any substantial right of the defendants. U. S. v. Quesada, 1975, 512 F.2d 1043, certiorari denied 96 S.Ct. 356, 423 U.S. 946, 46 L.Ed.2d 277. Criminal Law  1168(2)

Trial court's inquiry of potential defense witness, in determining whether to exclude testimony of witness based on sequestration violation, was insufficient to meet requirements of Atkinson, which requires court, when faced with a sequestration violation, to determine whether violation of rule was with knowledge, connivance, or consent of defendant or his counsel. McKinzie v. State, App. 1 Dist., 845 So.2d 316 (2003). Criminal Law  665(5)

Trial court did not err in refusing to permit testimony of a defense witness whose identity was not disclosed to state prior to trial, where the court, upon being informed of the situation, initially ruled that the witness would be allowed to testify if she promptly appeared for questioning before the prosecuting attorney, the witness failed to appear at the agreed time, defendant made no attempt to proffer the witness' testimony in support of his claim that he was prejudiced by the exclusion, and record did not otherwise indicate what her testimony would have been. Nava v. State, App. 4 Dist., 450 So.2d 606 (1984), cause dismissed 508 So.2d 14. Criminal Law  629.5(2)

Defendant, who has failed to properly disclose a witness to state prior to trial and who seeks to have such witness testify at trial, has burden to demonstrate a lack of substantial procedural prejudice to state and must demonstrate the prejudice he would suffer by exclusion of the witness who would allegedly testify in his favor through a proffer, or some other means, on the record of the nature of the testimony of the witness; failure to so establish on the record the nature of the testimony precludes assertion on appeal that the exclusion of the witness' testimony was error. Nava v. State, App. 4 Dist., 450 So.2d 606 (1984), cause dismissed 508 So.2d 14. Criminal Law  629.5(8); Criminal Law  670

Disqualification of two alibi witnesses from testifying due to any violation of sequestration order was reversible error in criminal proceeding in which claimed alibi was heart of accused's defense, absent a finding that the violation was with knowledge, connivance, or consent of accused or his counsel. Atkinson v. State, App. 4 Dist., 317 So.2d 807 (1975), certiorari denied 330 So.2d 21. Criminal Law  665(5); Criminal Law  1168(2)

Trial court's refusal of defendant's request for sequestration of witnesses rule was arbitrary and justified reversal of conviction of driving while under the influence of an intoxicating beverage where trial court made no determination or inquiry as to which witnesses the rule should apply or whether any witnesses were law enforcement officers or had personal interest in outcome of case but simply denied request because matter was said to be in its discretion. Dade County v. Callahan, App. 3 Dist., 259 So.2d 504 (1971), certiorari denied 265 So.2d 50. Criminal Law  665(1); Criminal Law  1168(2)

Denial, as untimely, of defendant's motion to exclude state's witnesses because of its failure to comply with rule for exchange of list of witnesses known to the parties, without making adequate inquiry into all of the surrounding circumstances, was reversible error. Angell v. State, App. 3 Dist., 254 So.2d 27 (1971). Criminal Law  696(6); Criminal Law  1168(3)

Permitting officer to testify as to identity of defendants and as to date of alleged robbery after rule excluding witnesses was invoked was not prejudicial abuse of discretion. Smith v. State, App. 3 Dist., 243 So.2d 602 (1971). Criminal Law  1168(2)

In larceny prosecution, wherein defendant asked for imposition of rule for separation of witnesses, it was prejudicial error to permit witness whose funds defendant was accused of appropriating to testify after such witness admitted that he had been shown and read a copy of prior testimony. Young v. State, App. 3 Dist., 99 So.2d 304 (1957). Criminal Law  665(3); Criminal Law  1168(2)

In prosecution for larceny of an automobile, refusing to permit mother of accused to testify in support of defense of alibi after defendant had invoked rule as to exclusion of witnesses and mother of accused remained in courtroom throughout trial was not reversible error, in view of record. Lang v. State, 137 Fla. 128, 187 So. 786 (1939). Criminal Law  1168(2)

The matter of exempting or refusing to exempt a witness from the operation of a rule excluding all witnesses from presence in the courtroom during the trial, until they are individually called to testify, is largely within the discretion of the trial court, and is not cause for reversal, unless the discretion is flagrantly abused, to the patent prejudice of the party complaining of the ruling. Robinson v. State, 80 Fla. 736, 87 So. 61 (1920). Criminal Law  1168(2)

head.head.info: 121. ---- Rebuttal, examination of witnesses, criminal cases

para.paratext: No reversible error was shown in admitting testimony of state rebuttal witness whose name had not been previously disclosed. Thomas v. State, App. 3 Dist., 296 So.2d 503 (1974), certiorari denied 305 So.2d 204. Criminal Law  1168(1)

On a criminal trial no error was committed in refusing to permit defendant to testify in rebuttal of the testimony of a state witness, where it appears that such excluded evidence, instead of rebutting the testimony of the state, tallied with and corroborated it. Davis v. State, 54 Fla. 34, 44 So. 757 (1907). Criminal Law  1170(1)

head.head.info: 122. Cumulative evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Where defendant, on trial for possession with intent to distribute and for distribution of heroin, had opened a door by his cross-examination of undercover agent to whom sales were allegedly made, agent's response that only the defendant and his codefendant could corroborate defendant's presence at the sales of heroin, which defendant claimed was an improper comment on defendant's failure to testify, was only cumulative of what undercover agent had been testifying to and the prejudicial effect, if any, of the alleged improper response was slight in view of the overwhelming evidence of guilt. U. S. v. Bell, 1975, 510 F.2d 1095. Criminal Law  1169.2(2)

Improper admission of evidence does not constitute reversible error where such evidence is merely cumulative of other competent evidence to the same effect. Culberson v. State, App. 2 Dist., 210 So.2d 248 (1968), certiorari denied 218 So.2d 171. Criminal Law  1169.2(1)

head.head.info: 123. Documentary and physical evidence, criminal cases--In general

para.paratext: Where trial court asked each juror if he or she remembered examining exhibit containing inadmissible statement by defendant admitting that he had been previously arrested for carrying a concealed weapon and no one answered affirmatively and court then instructed jury to disregard anything that they might have seen on the exhibit in question, there was no error in either the procedure or court's conclusion that the trial process had not been irretrievably tainted, and defendant having made a conscious choice not to move for a mistrial might not on appeal complain of trial court's failure to declare one and, even if the set of circumstances constituted error, it was harmless beyond reasonable doubt. U. S. v. Calles, 1973, 482 F.2d 1155. Criminal Law  1044.1(5.1); Criminal Law  1169.1(10); Criminal Law  1169.5(3)

In prosecution for knowingly causing a stolen motor vehicle to be transported in interstate commerce in violation of the Dyer Act, trial judge did not abuse his discretion in refusing to admit into evidence a copy of the registration certificate of the automobile which defendant allegedly stole since the action of the trial judge caused little if any harm to defendant by reason of the fact that he was permitted to testify as to the contents of the registration certificate. U. S. v. Gonzalez, 1972, 466 F.2d 1286. Criminal Law  1170(1)

Even if government sought, in prosecution for four counts of possession of government checks knowing them to have been stolen from United States mail and four counts of uttering same checks, to establish that checks in question were placed in mail by introducing inadmissible affidavits to that effect by custodians of records of Treasury Department, such would not have been prejudicial to defendant. U. S. v. Gossman, 1972, 455 F.2d 967. Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

In action for injuries sustained in automobile accident, trial court did not err by admitting into evidence diagram drawn during trial by defendant and subsequently altered by plaintiff's counsel. Fuller v. Rinebolt, App. 4 Dist., 382 So.2d 1239 (1980). Trial  39

In action for injuries sustained in automobile accident, trial court's comment upon diagram drawn by defendant did not improperly lead jury to believe that diagram was correct representation of intersection where accident occurred. Fuller v. Rinebolt, App. 4 Dist., 382 So.2d 1239 (1980). Trial  29(2)

In robbery prosecution, admission of physical evidence offered by state did not constitute harmful error despite claimed variance of the proofs. Martin v. State, App. 3 Dist., 218 So.2d 195 (1969). Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

Requiring defendant, at trial, to show his chest, was not reversible error, where robbery victims had testified that scar had been observed on defendant's exposed chest at time of alleged offense. Grays v. State, App. 3 Dist., 217 So.2d 133 (1969). Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

Permitting prosecution witness to use notebook to refresh his independent memory without requiring that notebook be made available to defense during cross-examination, was prejudicial error depriving defendant of his right to confrontation. Minturn v. State, App. 3 Dist., 136 So.2d 359 (1962). Criminal Law  662.4; Criminal Law  1168(2)

head.head.info: 124. ---- Marking and offering exhibits, documentary and physical evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Any error in admitting exhibit marked “2” was not prejudicial, although prosecutor, in offering exhibits, referred to them as numbers 1, 3, and 4, where judge and clerk referred to admission of exhibits 1 through 4 and there was no objection to failure to name exhibit 2 or indication that defendants were misled. U. S. v. Graham, 1972, 464 F.2d 1073, certiorari denied 93 S.Ct. 341, 409 U.S. 987, 34 L.Ed.2d 252. Criminal Law  1168(2)

Permitting the marking of previously identified tangible evidence upon resting of case by State was not harmful error where no objection as to admissibility was made as to irregularity in time sequence for introduction and where marking in evidence was done in front of jury before which evidence had been previously identified, notwithstanding that marking in evidence at that time might have been technical error. Rodriguez v. State, App. 3 Dist., 237 So.2d 772 (1970), certiorari denied 240 So.2d 644. Criminal Law  1168(2)

head.head.info: 125. ---- Blood samples and tests, documentary and physical evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Viable explanations other than murder defendant's guilt existed as to why defendant refused to submit to a gunpowder residue test, including desires to seek safe harbor and to choose safest possible path devoid of negative consequences, and thus evidence of her refusal could be excluded from admission at trial, where defendant was informed that test would be brief and noninvasive, defendant was not told of any adverse consequences of her refusal to take test, defendant was given impression test was optional, defendant was not yet a suspect, had not been arrested, and was not in custody at time of refusal, and refusal was partially motivated by desire to speak with counsel. Menna v. State, 846 So.2d 502 (2003). Homicide  1013

As results of blood tests performed upon blood taken from defendant while he was not under arrest constituted the chief evidence against him in prosecution for manslaughter in causing death by motor vehicle while intoxicated, error in admitting such evidence was prejudicial. Shores v. State, App. 1 Dist., 233 So.2d 434 (1970). Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

Even if taking of defendant's blood by hospital authorities, and its delivery to police and its use in evidence constituted unlawful search and seizure, error in its use was harmless in view of strong conclusive evidence in support of verdict and judgment of guilty. Dampier v. State, App. 1 Dist., 180 So.2d 183 (1965). Criminal Law  1169.1(8)

head.head.info: 126. ---- Business records and files, documentary and physical evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Since corporate records admitted in prosecution of taxpayer for purpose of showing that stock transfer between corporation and taxpayer was a sham, were similar in form and tenor to documents which were already in evidence and which also failed to list taxpayer as either an officer or director, and both an employee of corporation and an officer testified that in the realm of their duties they had never any knowledge of taxpayer having authority of an officer or director of corporation, documents were merely cumulative of other evidence that taxpayer was not an officer or director and any error in their admission was harmless. U. S. v. Ragano, 1975, 520 F.2d 1191, rehearing denied 526 F.2d 815, certiorari denied 96 S.Ct. 3192, 427 U.S. 905, 49 L.Ed.2d 1199. Criminal Law  1169.2(7)

Improper admission in prosecution for filing false income tax returns and attempted income tax evasion of investigatory report compiled by accounting firm engaged by defendant's employer to audit his accounts following his discharge was harmless beyond reasonable doubt where information contained in the report was wholly cumulative, even though report was referred to in closing argument. U. S. v. Burrell, 1974, 505 F.2d 904. Criminal Law  1169.2(7)

In prosecution for misapplication of funds of bank, for making false entries and for conspiracy, where bank files were received in evidence for authentication purposes only and defendants were never afforded opportunity to object to any particular record from standpoint of relevancy or materiality but court, over objection, reversed prior ruling and transmitted files to jury which was then considering its verdict, and prejudicial material was contained in files, reversal of conviction was required. U. S. v. Ashcom, 1970, 428 F.2d 1362. Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

Admission, in prosecution for wilfully and knowingly making and subscribing false corporate tax return, of corporate records, part of which were not positively identified by newly appointed secretary-treasurer, was not prejudicial error where documents came from corporate files and counsel admitted that authenticity of documents could have been established by other appropriate witnesses. U.S. v. Jernigan, 1969, 411 F.2d 471, certiorari denied 90 S.Ct. 262, 396 U.S. 927, 24 L.Ed.2d 225. Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

head.head.info: 127. ---- Charts and graphs, documentary and physical evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: In criminal proceeding, where special agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation had advised district attorney during trial and had testified, permitting agent to retake stand to exhibit charts, which presented, in compact and chronologic form, isolated pieces of evidence for purpose of destroying defendant's claim that he was innocent tool of professional criminal was error but was not prejudicial in view of instructions given and facts that charts were not offered as independent evidence and that agent did not purport to testify as witness in respect to them. Elder v. U.S., 1954, 213 F.2d 876, certiorari denied 75 S.Ct. 223, 348 U.S. 901, 99 L.Ed. 707, rehearing denied 75 S.Ct. 300, 348 U.S. 922, 99 L.Ed. 723. Criminal Law  667(1); Criminal Law  1168(2)

head.head.info: 128. ---- Clothing and wearing apparel, documentary and physical evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Where defendant in prosecution for aggravated assault had made timely motion for bill of particulars and for discovery but a shirt worn by the victim was not listed on the bill nor made known to defendant until it was offered into evidence, overruling defendant's objections to admission of the shirt was prejudicial error entitling him to a new trial. Garcia v. State, App. 3 Dist., 268 So.2d 575 (1972), certiorari denied 273 So.2d 81. Criminal Law  1169.1(10); Indictment And Information  121.5

In homicide prosecution, there was no prejudicial error in admitting deceased's clothes in evidence, even though state attorney did not state specific purpose for which clothes were offered, where it was apparent from testimony with reference to identification what that purpose was. North v. State, 65 So.2d 77 (1952), certiorari granted 74 S.Ct. 108, 346 U.S. 864, 98 L.Ed. 375, affirmed 74 S.Ct. 376, 346 U.S. 932, 98 L.Ed. 423, rehearing denied 74 S.Ct. 513, 347 U.S. 924, 98 L.Ed. 1078. Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

head.head.info: 129. ---- Commercial paper, documentary and physical evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Even if admission of five money orders, which were not specifically listed in indictment charging conspiracy to transport United States postal money orders in interstate commerce, was error, error was harmless, where there was more than sufficient evidence of conspiracy even without money orders. U. S. v. Bullock, 1971, 451 F.2d 884. Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

head.head.info: 130. ---- Contracts, documentary and physical evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: In prosecution for failure to pay federal cabaret excise tax, errors or near errors in admitting contracts of musicians who had played at defendant's establishment to prove existence of “cabaret,” charts drawn by government agent based on defendant's sales figures to demonstrate that certain sales were subject to tax, and cabaret tax returns and Florida sales tax returns for periods immediately preceding and following period covered by indictment to demonstrate pattern of fraudulent conduct, required that very close case be reversed and remanded for new trial. Baines v. U. S., 1970, 426 F.2d 833. Criminal Law  1169.1(10); Criminal Law  1169.11

head.head.info: 131. ---- Hair samples, documentary and physical evidence, documentary and physical evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: In murder trial, error in admitting lock of hair, not properly identified, into evidence was harmless to defendant, where evidence of his guilt was so convincing as to preclude acquittal and require conviction of first-degree murder. Goddard v. State, 143 Fla. 28, 196 So. 596 (1940). Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

Testimony by detective that he recovered only two hairs from the victim's body and by FBI expert that he received and tested several hairs did not demonstrate the probability of evidence tampering in capital murder prosecution; the detective stated that he was not positive about the number, and the expert could not give an exact figure. Murray v. State, 838 So.2d 1073 (2002), rehearing denied, appeal after new trial 3 So.3d 1108, certiorari denied 130 S.Ct. 396, 175 L.Ed.2d 273. Criminal Law  404.20

An indication of evidence tampering from an unexplained discrepancy concerning bottle of lotion that police officer placed in bag with murder victim's nightgown, but that was not in bag received by analyst, rendered hairs recovered from nightgown inadmissible in capital murder prosecution. Murray v. State, 838 So.2d 1073 (2002), rehearing denied, appeal after new trial 3 So.3d 1108, certiorari denied 130 S.Ct. 396, 175 L.Ed.2d 273. Criminal Law  404.20

head.head.info: 132. ---- Medical records, documentary and physical evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Any error in admitting medical records containing notation that defendant had been interviewed by officers and had refused to make statement without attorney was not harmful where defendant joined in seeking admission and no specific reference was made to notation, which could be discovered only through reading many pages of hospital records. U. S. v. Roberts, 1972, 470 F.2d 1190. Criminal Law  1137(5); Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

head.head.info: 133. ---- Motion pictures, documentary and physical evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Admission, in prosecution for attempted breaking and entering of furniture store with intent to commit felony, of motion picture showing defendant in back seat of police vehicle handcuffed, burglar's tools, and general scene of event was not prejudicial error, where motion pictures showed nothing to inflame jury and was fair and accurate portrayal of people, things, and matters present at time in question. Kimbrough v. State, App. 1 Dist., 219 So.2d 122 (1969). Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

head.head.info: 134. ---- Newspapers and periodicals, documentary and physical evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Any error, in prosecution for interstate transportation of gambling paraphernalia, in admitting newspaper clipping which was found in defendant's pocket and which described arrest of another person of same name on lottery charges was not reversible. U. S. v. Scaglione, 1971, 446 F.2d 182, certiorari denied 92 S.Ct. 284, 404 U.S. 941, 30 L.Ed.2d 254. Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

head.head.info: 135. ---- Photographs, documentary and physical evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Prosecutor's reference in closing argument to photographs of defendant, which were introduced during the trial, as “mug shots,” and the introduction of the photographs which showed front and profile view was reversible error even if identification numbers on photographs were concealed. Rucker v. State, App. 3 Dist., 307 So.2d 830 (1974), vacated 330 So.2d 470, on remand 335 So.2d 361. Criminal Law  438(3); Criminal Law  1169.1(10); Criminal Law  1171.3; Criminal Law  2144

Where defendant admitted victim's death, how death occurred, her identity and that bullet went into brain and did not come out, admission of numerous gruesome photographs depicting victim's body and wounds was reversible error. Beagles v. State, App. 1 Dist., 273 So.2d 796 (1973). Criminal Law  438(7); Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

Permitting introduction of photographs bearing likeness of defendant was not ground for reversal, where victim identified defendant from the photographs and then clearly made an in-court identification of defendant as being the robber and testified that she knew him because he had been frequent visitor to the robbed store over a period of time prior to the robbery. Branam v. State, App. 2 Dist., 265 So.2d 555 (1972), certiorari dismissed 270 So.2d 742. Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

Admission of photographs was not prejudicial to defendant whose only defense was a claimed accidental discharge of death weapon. Milledge v. State, App. 3 Dist., 262 So.2d 906 (1972). Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

Where 22 of 45 photographs introduced into evidence by prosecution in murder prosecution showed all or portions of partially decomposed torso of victim and were without question of a gory and gruesome nature, admission was prejudicial error. Young v. State, 234 So.2d 341 (1970). Criminal Law  438(7); Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

Admission of purported area photograph of scene of shooting which was not identified by person who made it was harmless in view of abundance of other evidence of physical surrounding at time and place in question. Darty v. State, App. 2 Dist., 161 So.2d 864 (1964), certiorari denied 168 So.2d 147. Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

In prosecution for murder in second degree, photograph taken in hospital by police officer showing decedent lying on hospital operating table with point of entry of bullet into his body being visible was admissible to show jury point where bullet penetrated and also to demonstrate that shot was fired from such a distance as to refute claim of powder burns such as might have appeared if shooting had occurred in close confines of a struggle as claimed by defendant, and any error in admission of decedent's photograph in that photograph may have been so gruesome or hideous as to arouse passion of jury was harmless in view of sufficient evidence, aside from photograph, to support defendant's conviction. Cullaro v. State, App. 2 Dist., 97 So.2d 40 (1957). Criminal Law  438(7); Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

Any error in admission of deceased's photograph in that the photograph may have been so gruesome or hideous as to arouse passion of jury was harmless where there was ample evidence aside from the photograph to support defendant's conviction for second-degree murder. Webb v. State, 62 So.2d 410 (1953). Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

head.head.info: 136. ---- Signatures, documentary and physical evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Fact that signatures of defendant charged with causing forged money orders to be transported in interstate commerce, used for comparison purposes by government's handwriting expert, were taken from fingerprint cards obtained in connection with unrelated offenses, was not reversible error where there was no testimony in jury's presence of the nature of or existence of unrelated offenses, and where identification of fingerprint cards was made outside jury's presence, after which the signatures were excised from both cards and these alone were displayed to the jury. Newsom v. U. S., 1968, 402 F.2d 835. Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

head.head.info: 137. ---- Tape recordings, documentary and physical evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Tape recording of such poor quality as to make conversation unintelligible should not have been admitted and its admission was reversible error since jurors might have speculated upon various isolated portions which could be understood. Carter v. State, App. 1 Dist., 254 So.2d 230 (1971), certiorari denied 257 So.2d 260. Criminal Law  438.1; Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

Where transcription of defendant's tape recorded statement was properly authenticated by person who took statement and who verified that transcript was same evidence as the recording, trial court's allowing publication of statement by that person to the jury but not admission of transcript into evidence was not reversible error over claim that transcription was not the best evidence. Grimes v. State, 244 So.2d 130 (1971). Criminal Law  1169.1(1)

head.head.info: 138. ---- Transcripts, documentary and physical evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Permitting jurors to use copies of excluded typewritten transcript of recorded conversation between state's witness and one defendant charged with violation of lottery laws as aid in following rendition of admitted recording, which was partially inaudible and unintelligible, was not prejudicial error with respect to other defendant, where sum of evidence against such other defendant indisputably proved that he was directly engaged in illegal activity charged. Brady v. State, App. 2 Dist., 178 So.2d 121 (1965). Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

head.head.info: 139. ---- Video tape, documentary and physical evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: If previously taken and preserved testimony of witness, who was unable to be present at trial, was admissible, its submission by video tape, as distinguished from written transcript of questions and answers, did not result in harmful error. Hutchins v. State, App. 3 Dist., 286 So.2d 244 (1973), certiorari denied 293 So.2d 717. Criminal Law  1169.1(1)

head.head.info: 140. ---- Weapons, documentary and physical evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Error, if any, in admitting gun which was used in killing in question and was discovered under defendant's mattress was harmless, where eyewitness testified to fact that defendant killed victim, and there was no reasonable basis upon which different verdict could have been reached. Russell v. State, App. 3 Dist., 270 So.2d 462 (1972). Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

Where deputy sheriff walked into courtroom with knife and piece of broomstick open to view in his hands while jury was being qualified or selected and where state did not introduce the exhibits into evidence in murder prosecution arising from fight involving broom and butcher knife, error had been committed, but where jurors stated under oath that items did not make a meaningful impression upon their minds, where defense counsel did not request court to admonish the jury and where objectionable evidence had already been removed from view when called to attention of trial judge, error was not prejudicial. King v. State, App. 2 Dist., 258 So.2d 21 (1972). Criminal Law  663; Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

Defendant failed to demonstrate that harmful error had been committed by admitting into evidence gun found in his automobile when he was arrested and by admitting into evidence photographic identification by one of police officers, in robbery prosecution. Grier v. State, App. 3 Dist., 241 So.2d 735 (1970). Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

head.head.info: 141. Hearsay, criminal cases

para.paratext: Even if testimony of government agent concerning statements already admitted into evidence in testimony of declarant had been used to prove facts asserted in the out-of-court statements, any error in admission of such evidence was not prejudicial as declarant in all cases was present, gave testimony which was identical to that of the agent and was subject to vigorous cross-examination. U. S. v. Rodriguez, 1975, 509 F.2d 1342. Criminal Law  1169.1(9)

Hearsay testimony that is neither “crucial” nor “devastating” for purposes of determining whether there has been violation of the confrontation clause may nevertheless amount to reversible error under standard applicable to nonconstitutional error. U. S. v. Arias-Diaz, 1974, 497 F.2d 165, rehearing denied 504 F.2d 760, certiorari denied 95 S.Ct. 1445, 420 U.S. 1003, 43 L.Ed.2d 761, certiorari denied 95 S.Ct. 1446, 420 U.S. 1003, 43 L.Ed.2d 761. Criminal Law  1169.1(9)

In narcotics prosecution, any possible error concerning unobjected to, volunteered hearsay testimony was harmless beyond reasonable doubt in view of total evidence produced at trial. U. S. v. Anderson, 1973, 485 F.2d 239, certiorari denied 94 S.Ct. 1487, 415 U.S. 958, 39 L.Ed.2d 573. Criminal Law  1169.1(9)

Where, following recess in suppression hearing, witness stated under oath that the Government had intimidated him and in response to judge's questions witness affirmed that his earlier testimony had been truthful and was not affected by intimidation except for one particular and witness was unavailable at trial, such testimony should have been admitted at trial as an exception to the hearsay rule; however, error in excluding testimony was not reversible, in view of overwhelming evidence of guilt and lack of any significant exonerating effect of amendment testimony on original testimony. U. S. v. Curry, 1973, 471 F.2d 419, certiorari denied 93 S.Ct. 2150, 411 U.S. 967, 36 L.Ed.2d 688. Criminal Law  543(1); Criminal Law  1170(1)

In prosecution for conspiracy to receive, conceal, sell and dispose of stolen work of art transported in interstate commerce, and upon substantive count, where hearsay portions of rebuttal evidence were secondary and incidental to admissible portions and were of little if any weight on issue whether longtime FBI informer who testified for defense had arrangement vel non with FBI agents who directly denied such arrangement, admission of such hearsay portions in absence of objection was not plain error but harmless error. U. S. v. Cohen, 1969, 418 F.2d 68. Criminal Law  1036.5

Defendant's pretrial motion to bar State from using any hearsay evidence during penalty phase that would violate his right of confrontation, together with renewal of motion at inception of hearing and objections to hearsay testimony were sufficient to preserve challenge to hearsay evidence for appellate review. Rodgers v. State, 948 So.2d 655 (2006), rehearing denied, certiorari denied 128 S.Ct. 59, 552 U.S. 833, 169 L.Ed.2d 50. Criminal Law  1036.5

Police officer's hearsay testimony regarding prior accusations made by victim against defendant was reversible error, in trial for child molestation. Fleitas v. State, App. 3 Dist., 867 So.2d 512 (2004), appeal after new trial 3 So.3d 351, rehearing denied, review denied 14 So.3d 241, certiorari denied 130 S.Ct. 502, 175 L.Ed.2d 356. Criminal Law  1169.1(9)

The issue of whether the necessary state of mind is present for a statement to be admissible as an excited utterance is a preliminary fact for the court to determine. Stoll v. State, 762 So.2d 870 (2000), rehearing and/or clarification denied. Criminal Law  413.62

Defendant's failure to proffer any inconsistency between victim's trial testimony and her oral statements to police made oral statements inadmissible hearsay in robbery prosecution. Fernandez-Carballo v. State, App. 3 Dist., 590 So.2d 1004 (1991). Criminal Law  419(4)

Although it is not a crime for interested witness to seek to testify as to communications or transactions with the deceased person nor is it a crime for witness to seek to testify as to “hearsay,” unless such offered testimony falls within one of the recognized exceptions, such is not admissible in evidence and if the trial court, over timely objection, admits such and if it is relevant, material and prejudicial then a conviction based thereon will, upon timely appeal, be reversed. Horn v. State, App. 1 Dist., 298 So.2d 194 (1974), certiorari denied 308 So.2d 117. Criminal Law  419(1.5); Criminal Law  1168(3); Criminal Law  1169.1(9); Witnesses  125

Error, if any, in receiving testimony of 10-year-old child's mother, in prosecution for lewd assault upon a female under 14 years without intent to commit rape, as to statements made to her by the child following incident in question was not ground for reversal, where such statements constituted cumulative evidence and were merely corroborative of child's trial testimony which was sufficient to support conviction. Fitter v. State, App. 3 Dist., 261 So.2d 512 (1972). Criminal Law  1169.2(6)

Admission, over defendant's objection, of testimony of police officer, based upon information from two unidentified sources, that vehicle used in one of robberies on night in question was owned by defendant's wife was prejudicial error, even if ownership of vehicle was matter of public record in that defendant was deprived of an opportunity to challenge competency and reliability of such unidentified witnesses. Webb v. State, App. 4 Dist., 253 So.2d 715 (1971). Criminal Law  419(1.5); Criminal Law  1169.1(9)

Where shooting victim's mother was notified immediately of shooting occurring around 7:30 p.m. and saw her son at hospital around 9:30 p.m. before he had been interviewed, and victim was very concerned and disturbed about fate of defendant, asked the questions and died less than 30 hours after being shot, refusal to admit as part of the res gestae victim's exculpatory statement to his mother that shooting was an accident was reversible error. Appell v. State, App. 4 Dist., 250 So.2d 318 (1971), certiorari denied 257 So.2d 257. Criminal Law  366(5); Criminal Law  1170(1)

Testimony by private detective as to conversation he heard between his employee and defendant by means of a secret transmitter in purse of employee who went to defendant's apartment, told him she had an unwanted pregnancy, and received an internal pelvic examination was received in violation of right of privacy preserved by Fourth Amendment to United States Constitution, which is applicable to state proceedings, and of state constitutional prohibition against illegal search and seizure, and was improperly admitted at defendant's trial for practicing medicine without a license, and this constituted prejudicial error. Hajdu v. State, App. 3 Dist., 189 So.2d 230 (1966), certiorari denied 196 So.2d 923. Criminal Law  392.13(2); Criminal Law  1169.1(8)

In prosecution for receiving stolen goods, admission of hearsay evidence prejudicial to defendant was reversible error where duly objected to. Alvarez v. State, 75 Fla. 286, 78 So. 272 (1918). Criminal Law  1169.1(9)
Admission of hearsay and irrelevant testimony, which was manifestly prejudicial to accused was ground for reversal. Watkins v. State, 69 Fla. 355, 68 So. 176 (1915). Criminal Law  1169.1(1)

head.head.info: 142. Immaterial or incompetent evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Any error in asking defendant, charged with assaulting a federal officer, about his failure to file tax returns was immaterial and harmless where evidence of guilt was strong. U. S. v. Barnett, 1974, 492 F.2d 790. Criminal Law  1169.1(7)

Admission of defendant's wife's statement that she had told defendant that he was going to get in trouble “messing” with his brother and “those counterfeits” was prejudicial error as to defendant, even though statement was made in presence of defendant and even if wife was a co-conspirator, where statement was made after defendant's arrest. U. S. v. Williams, 1971, 447 F.2d 894. Criminal Law  424(2); Criminal Law  1169.1(7)

In proceeding in which accused was convicted of assault with intent to commit robbery, admission of testimony that officer had advised alleged victim that he would have to take polygraph examination to check the validity of his complaint was prejudicial error, in view of fact that state's entire case depended on victim's credibility and that his credibility had been severely impaired, during cross-examination, by an admission that he had been convicted of a felony and by eliciting testimony inconsistent with his prior statements. Crawford v. State, App. 4 Dist., 321 So.2d 559 (1975), approved 339 So.2d 214. Criminal Law  1169.1(7); Witnesses  414(1)

Permitting State's witness to testify as to conversation, which allegedly occurred between defendant and his nephew, which witness overheard and in which defendant spoke of having turned down State's offer to plead guilty to charge of manslaughter of his wife because of confidence in his ability to convince jury that the shooting was an accident, was prejudicial error where only purpose of evidence was to discredit defendant's anticipated defense of accident and the State's case was not a strong one; statement attributed to defendant was wholly immaterial and irrelevant to issue being tried. Owens v. State, App. 4 Dist., 273 So.2d 788 (1973). Criminal Law  338(1); Criminal Law  1169.1(7)

In prosecution of a principal and an accessory before the fact for obtaining money by false pretenses, the admission of immaterial testimony that a strange man had been seen walking between railroad depot and the garage where accessory had been working was harmless, where the other evidence clearly established the principal's guilt. Elliott v. State, 77 Fla. 611, 82 So. 139 (1919). Criminal Law  1169.1(7)

head.head.info: 143. Irrelevant evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Admission of evidence, irrelevant because relating to remote facts, is not per se reversible error, unless shown misleading or confusing. Nelson v. State, 99 Fla. 1032, 128 So. 1 (1930); Griswold v. State, 77 Fla. 505, 82 So. 44 (1919).

A judgment of conviction in a criminal case will not be reversed because of the admission of evidence which was clearly not prejudicial to defendant, although it may have been irrelevant. Wooldridge v. State, 49 Fla. 137, 38 So. 3 (1905); Wilson v. State, 47 Fla. 118, 36 So. 580 (1904); Davis v. State, 47 Fla. 26, 36 So. 170 (1904); Caldwell v. State, 43 Fla. 545, 30 So. 814 (1901); Wallace v. State, 41 Fla. 547, 26 So. 713 (1899).

A judgment of conviction in criminal case will not be reversed because of admission of evidence which was clearly not prejudicial to defendant, although it may have been irrelevant or immaterial; it is the corollary rule that admission of irrelevant evidence prejudicial to defendant over his objection is reversible error. Farnell v. State, App. 2 Dist., 214 So.2d 753 (1968). Criminal Law  1169.1(7)

Objections to evidence for irrelevancy and immateriality will not be considered on appeal if the evidence admitted was harmless. Griswold v. State, 77 Fla. 505, 82 So. 44 (1919). Criminal Law  1169.1(1)
The admission of irrelevant evidence prejudicial to defendant over his objection is reversible error. Wolf v. State, 72 Fla. 572, 73 So. 740 (1917). Criminal Law  1169.1(1)

head.head.info: 144. Opinions and conclusions, criminal cases--In general

para.paratext: If it was error for trial court to admit opinion testimony to the effect that certain automobiles were new rather than used, the error was not prejudicial, in prosecution for automobile information disclosure violation, in view of properly received evidence indicating new status of the automobiles, and in view of fact that during cross-examination by defendant's counsel a customs official was permitted to answer that the automobiles were considered as new for tariff purposes. All Nations Trading Co. v. U. S., 1964, 338 F.2d 501. Criminal Law  1169.9

In murder prosecution in which witness had stated that he had determined that accused killed deceased, trial court's sustaining of objection to question as to whether witness had formed a fixed opinion of the guilt or innocence of accused did not injuriously affect accused's rights. Brown v. State, 61 So.2d 640 (1952), certiorari denied 73 S.Ct. 654, 345 U.S. 913, 97 L.Ed. 1347. Criminal Law  1170(1)

head.head.info: 145. ---- Expert testimony, opinions and conclusions, criminal cases

para.paratext: Exclusion of question affecting qualifications of expert witness for government was not prejudicial, in view of showing beyond question by another witness that packages in evidence contained cocaine. Harrison Narcotic Law, 38 Stat. 785 as amended. Vamvas v. U.S., 1926, 13 F.2d 347. Criminal Law  1169.9

In light of the very closely drawn issues, fact that cause of the prosecutrix' injuries about the face were subject to reasonable conflicting claims and in view of fact that defendants' motion to strike opinion testimony was denied, admission of physician's opinion that prosecutrix was raped constituted reversible error. Farley v. State, App. 4 Dist., 324 So.2d 662 (1975), certiorari denied 336 So.2d 1184. Criminal Law  473; Criminal Law  1169.9

In prosecution for second-degree murder, admission of opinion of pathologist that, based upon ten-minute examination of photograph, which depicted defendant's wounds but which was of such poor quality that such wounds could hardly be observed except by use of magnifying glass and light, such wounds were self-inflicted to “a medical certainty” was prejudicial error. Johnson v. State, App. 1 Dist., 314 So.2d 248 (1975). Criminal Law  486(10); Criminal Law  1169.9

Where defendant neither offered an amendment to hypothetical questions tendered by the prosecution nor offered one of her own, but merely objected to them on ground that they did not reflect all the facts in evidence, error, if any, in overruling her objections was harmless. Christiansen v. State, App. 3 Dist., 280 So.2d 41 (1973). Criminal Law  1169.9

It was reversible error to permit ballistics expert to testify as to markings on bullet which corresponded to markings on pistol with which it was charged the defendant accused of second-degree murder was armed, where state could not produce bullet for examination by defendant's own expert. Johnson v. State, App. 3 Dist., 249 So.2d 470 (1971), certiorari discharged 280 So.2d 673. Criminal Law  483; Criminal Law  1169.9

Record on appeal in prosecution for unlawful possession of counterfeit driver's licenses failed to establish ground for reversal or abuse of trial court's discretion in permitting a Florida highway patrolman to qualify as an expert and give his opinion as to counterfeit driver's licenses. Koran v. State, App. 3 Dist., 213 So.2d 735 (1968), certiorari denied 222 So.2d 26, certiorari denied 91 S.Ct. 1603, 402 U.S. 948, 29 L.Ed.2d 118. Criminal Law  478(1); Criminal Law  1169.9

Where no evidence was introduced in murder prosecution that manila paper had characteristics essentially similar to human skin that would render results of test firing of murder weapon into manila paper at varying distances a proper predicate for hypothetical question propounded to ballistics expert concerning distance from which weapon must be fired to produce particular effect on human skin, trial court committed reversible error by permitting expert, over defendant's objection, to answer hypothetical question. Roberts v. State, App. 1 Dist., 189 So.2d 543 (1966). Criminal Law  485(1); Criminal Law  1169.9

In homicide prosecution, trial court did not commit reversible error in permitting expert witness to testify that, in his opinion, bruises and contusions upon body of deceased were caused by an assault, principally by blunt force, and that method of assault was most consistent with strangulation. North v. State, 65 So.2d 77 (1952), certiorari granted 74 S.Ct. 108, 346 U.S. 864, 98 L.Ed. 375, affirmed 74 S.Ct. 376, 346 U.S. 932, 98 L.Ed. 423, rehearing denied 74 S.Ct. 513, 347 U.S. 924, 98 L.Ed. 1078. Criminal Law  1169.9

Permitting chief of fire department, who qualified as expert, to testify that in his opinion fire had been set by use of gasoline, was not prejudicial error in arson prosecution. Sawyer v. State, 100 Fla. 1603, 132 So. 188 (1931). Criminal Law  1169.9

head.head.info: 146. ---- Nonexpert testimony, opinions and conclusions, criminal cases

para.paratext: A prosecutor's intimation during argument as to her investigation of case, her opinion as to defendant's guilt, her assessment of victim's credibility, is patent reversible error. Fleitas v. State, App. 3 Dist., 867 So.2d 512 (2004), appeal after new trial 3 So.3d 351, rehearing denied, review denied 14 So.3d 241, certiorari denied 130 S.Ct. 502, 175 L.Ed.2d 356. Criminal Law  1171.3

Permitting assistant state attorney to testify regarding investigation of instant case, her opinion regarding defendant's guilt, and assessment of victim's credibility, and that defendant had committed many other uncharged crimes, was patently reversible error, in trial for multiple counts of child molestation. Fleitas v. State, App. 3 Dist., 867 So.2d 512 (2004), appeal after new trial 3 So.3d 351, rehearing denied, review denied 14 So.3d 241, certiorari denied 130 S.Ct. 502, 175 L.Ed.2d 356. Criminal Law  1170.5(1)

Where in a murder prosecution defendant's sanity is at issue, admission of opinions by nonexpert witnesses as to defendant's mental condition, not based upon detailed facts, is not reversible error, where the court instructs the jury, that they are admitted for “what they are worth.” Hall v. State, 78 Fla. 420, 83 So. 513 (1919). Criminal Law  1169.9

Unless it appears to an appellate court that some injustice has been done a defendant by permitting ordinary witness to give his opinion or conclusion, it will not interfere. Kersey v. State, 73 Fla. 832, 74 So. 983 (1917). Criminal Law  1169.9

head.head.info: 147. Wrongfully obtained evidence, criminal cases--In general

para.paratext: Error in allowing government witness to testify, because his identity had been disclosed to government agents in defendant's financial ledger, which had been ordered suppressed, was harmless error beyond a reasonable doubt where witness' testimony was merely cumulative of that of other witnesses, who participated in illegal melting of silver from United States currency at defendant's direction and who observed defendant participating in the operation. U. S. v. Resnick, 1973, 483 F.2d 354, certiorari denied 94 S.Ct. 370, 414 U.S. 1008, 38 L.Ed.2d 246. Criminal Law  1169.1(8)

Where officer without a warrant kicked in hotel room door after he did not gain admittance when he went to hotel room to investigate hotel window smashing incident and occupants of room escaped through window beneath which second officer found stolen jewelry which had been thrown out the window while officer was kicking down door, jewelry was thrown out of window as direct result of improper initial entry and its admission in evidence was reversible error. Fletcher v. Wainwright, 1968, 399 F.2d 62. Criminal Law  392.39(2); Criminal Law  1169.1(8)

Where there was overwhelming evidence to sustain finding that defendant motorist was guilty of manslaughter by culpable negligence as to death of person struck when automobile swerved into group of persons sitting on grass, error, if any, in admission of results of blood test taken after accident without warnings to defendant as to her rights in case of criminal charges was harmless. McKissack v. State, App. 3 Dist., 243 So.2d 14 (1971). Criminal Law  1169.1(8)

head.head.info: 148. ---- Arrests, wrongfully obtained evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Denial of motion to suppress evidence taken from defendant at time of his arrest without a warrant was not harmful error where the arrest was lawful, items taken from defendant were of so little importance that it was not likely that they influenced verdict and where defendant, when he testified, did not ever refer to occasion of his arrest and what was taken from him by search. Dorsey v. U.S., 1949, 174 F.2d 899, certiorari denied 70 S.Ct. 479, 338 U.S. 950, 94 L.Ed. 586, certiorari denied 71 S.Ct. 116, 340 U.S. 878, 95 L.Ed. 639. Criminal Law  1169.1(8)

Even if police extended their search of defendant's apartment beyond permissible limits, in view of fact that at least some of ammunition found in the apartment was within plain view of police officers making arrest, any error in connection with trial court's refusal to suppress the ammunition was harmless. Santiago v. State, App. 3 Dist., 314 So.2d 246 (1975), certiorari denied 328 So.2d 844. Criminal Law  1169.1(8)

Where police officer, while arresting defendant, violated statute permitting arresting officer to break open a door to building occupied by person to be arrested, exhibits seized on search incidental to arrest were illegally seized, and admission of them into evidence in subsequent criminal prosecution constituted reversible error, in absence of testimony establishing an exception which would justify noncompliance with statute. Urquhart v. State, App. 2 Dist., 211 So.2d 79 (1968). Arrest  71.1(7); Criminal Law  392.17(2); Criminal Law  1169.1(8)

Evidence established that primary purpose of police officers who made arrest and conducted search was to discover evidence to be used against defendant charged with conducting a lottery and that search of premises without warrant was not an incident of arrest, and hence reversible error was committed when trial judge denied defendant's motion to suppress such evidence. Chapman v. State, App. 3 Dist., 158 So.2d 578 (1963). Criminal Law  392.49(4); Criminal Law  1168(1)

Where accused moved to suppress evidence allegedly obtained through unlawful arrest and search, and court, after hearing considerable testimony in support of motion, declined to hear further testimony, denied motion, and proceeded with trial, and accused obtained rulings regarding admissibility of evidence offered during trial, accused could not complain of court's refusal to have heard the further testimony, since accused's rights were fully protected by the rulings at trial. Sanchez v. State, 133 Fla. 160, 182 So. 645 (1938). Criminal Law  1168(2)

head.head.info: 149. ---- Searches and seizures, wrongfully obtained evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Defendant's son-in-law, who was a deputy sheriff and was requested by defendant's stepmother to enter unoccupied home of defendant for purpose of obtaining and forwarding certain stock certificates owned by defendant's father, and who, while he was within home, undertook a side venture of looking behind a mirror and there discovered certificates which were shown to have been stolen with certain bonds, was acting in his capacity as a law enforcement officer, rather than exclusively as a son-in-law on a family mission, and, absent a search warrant, search and seizure was violative of Fourth Amendment, and admission of testimony concerning certificates to establish scienter on charge of aiding and abetting the forging and passing of bonds was prejudicial error. U. S. v. Clarke, 1971, 451 F.2d 584. Criminal Law  392.15(6); Criminal Law  1169.1(8); Searches And Seizures  33

Even if there was an unlawful search of vehicle of defendant in which airline coupon was found, so that motion to suppress the coupon should have been granted, error in admission of the coupon, if any, was harmless to defendant beyond a reasonable doubt where evidence of defendant's participation in bank robbery was overwhelming. U. S. v. Manning, 1971, 440 F.2d 1105, certiorari denied 92 S.Ct. 125, 404 U.S. 837, 30 L.Ed.2d 69. Criminal Law  1169.1(8)

Where nothing in record of prosecution for receiving and concealing property of United States known to have been embezzled and stolen, indicated what specific items were removed from locked personal effects of accused in illegal search, conviction was reversed. Holzhey v. U.S., 1955, 223 F.2d 823. Criminal Law  1169.1(8)
Where conviction was based upon evidence obtained by an unreasonable search and seizure, such conviction could not stand. Drayton v. U.S., 1953, 205 F.2d 35. Criminal Law  1169.1(1)

Even though general allegation of defendant that he sought to suppress all tangible items of property and other evidence seized by police from defendant, his automobile or his premises did not comply with requirements of rule prescribing contents of motion to suppress, where matter of noncompliance was not properly brought to attention of trial judge in his determination as to legal sufficiency of motion to suppress, appellate court would not reverse on basis of such noncompliance. State v. Hinton, App. 4 Dist., 305 So.2d 804 (1975). Criminal Law  1168(1)

Where defendant filed written motion to suppress between mistrial and subsequent jury trial but did not call motion to attention of trial court until after jury had been impanelled and case commenced, at which time trial court indicated it would rule on motion when occasion arose during trial, and where trial judge then found that there had been no illegal search and seizure, failure to consider the motion and rule thereon prior to commencement of second trial did not constitute reversible error. Kemp v. State, App. 3 Dist., 271 So.2d 777 (1973). Criminal Law  1168(1)

Testimony of officer regarding stereo, which was found in defendant's residence and which was identified as stereo purchased with forged check was not product of an unlawful search and admission thereof was not reversible error, where defendant, who had been arrested at entrance of his residence, had invited officers to enter residence. Aldridge v. State, App. 3 Dist., 220 So.2d 431 (1969). Criminal Law  392.42(3); Criminal Law  1169.1(8); Searches And Seizures  197

Admission in evidence in robbery prosecution of items of clothing taken from defendant's bedroom was not reversible error on ground of an illegal search and seizure where there was sufficient testimony from which it could be found that defendant voluntarily consented to having his home searched. Yant v. State, App. 3 Dist., 154 So.2d 908 (1963). Criminal Law  1169.1(8)

Defendant convicted of unlawful sale and possession of marijuana was not entitled to reversal of conviction on ground that trial court erred in admitting into evidence certain evidence and testimony obtained during search and seizure. Perez v. State, App. 3 Dist., 151 So.2d 686 (1963). Criminal Law  1169.1(8)

Failure of trial judge to require state to disclose such information as it had relative to individual assertedly signing affidavit upon which search warrant was issued vitiated all evidence obtained thereunder, and ensuing conviction and sentence were required to be reversed. Baker v. State, App. 3 Dist., 150 So.2d 729 (1963). Criminal Law  392.16(2); Criminal Law  1169.1(8)

head.head.info: 150. ---- Wiretapping, wrongfully obtained evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Where Government's proof merely showed that the initials of the then Attorney General were placed on interception order authorization to support the application for an extension order by the Attorney General's executive assistant and neither the Attorney General nor such executive assistant could remember specific oral directive from the Attorney General for the executive assistant to initial the order for the Attorney General, executive assistant's specific prior approval was insufficient, requiring reversal of conviction which partially rested on information obtained under such extension of tap. U. S. v. Crabtree, 1975, 507 F.2d 1230. Criminal Law  1169.1(8); Telecommunications  1461

Where there was more than ample evidence that defendant was guilty of using wire communication facility to transmit wagering information in interstate commerce while being engaged in gambling business, even if identity of two government witnesses had been obtained as a result of illegal wiretaps, admission of their testimony could have had only de minimus bearing on question of guilt or innocence and was not ground for reversal of conviction. U. S. v. Marder, 1973, 474 F.2d 1192. Criminal Law  1169.1(8)

head.head.info: 151. Scientific evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Given testimony of State's witnesses at Frye hearing that errors in Florida Department of Law Enforcement (FDLE) database had caused sufficient concern that reexamination of entire database was ordered and that, pending completion of reexamination, only Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) database was to be used, it was incumbent on State to demonstrate that, notwithstanding that concern, FDLE database was generally accepted in scientific community, and since State failed to make this showing, trial court erred when it admitted population frequency statistics derived from FDLE database, and this error was not harmless.
