Bevil v. State, App. 1 Dist., 875 So.2d 1265 (2004), rehearing denied. Criminal Law  388.2

Any doubt as to admissibility of novel scientific evidence under Frye should be resolved in a manner that minimizes the chance of a wrongful conviction. Bevil v. State, App. 1 Dist., 875 So.2d 1265 (2004), rehearing denied. Criminal Law  388.1

In reaching decision regarding general acceptance of novel scientific evidence under Frye, court may examine expert testimony, scientific and legal writings, and judicial opinions. Bevil v. State, App. 1 Dist., 875 So.2d 1265 (2004), rehearing denied. Criminal Law  388.1

head.head.info: 152. Character or reputation of accused, criminal cases

para.paratext: Even if admission, in prosecution for wilfully importing marijuana, possession of marijuana with intent to unlawfully distribute it and for acting as an aider and abettor, of testimony as to modus operandi and earlier events transpiring in surveillance of dock area at which defendant was seen taking delivery of marijuana was error, it was harmless, in view of overwhelming other evidence of guilt. U. S. v. Baity, 1972, 464 F.2d 570. Criminal Law  1169.1(6)

Even though it could be argued that answer by Government agent to effect that he was trying to get in touch with “those who were known to the Sheriff's Department * *” may have been responsive to question posed by defense counsel, volunteering by the witness, without being responsive to any question, that he has a list of persons known to Sheriff's Department and to agents that were working in the area would not justify Government's voluntary inquiry of the agent as to whether defendants in narcotics prosecution were on that list; by allowing such an inquiry the Government successfully put in evidence testimony relating to general bad reputation or character which the defendants had not themselves put in issue, which constituted prejudicial error. U. S. v. Brown, 1971, 451 F.2d 1231. Criminal Law  376; Criminal Law  1169.1(6)

It was reversible error to admit in prosecution for assault to commit rape a newspaper clipping, found in defendant's wallet, stating that defendant had been acquitted in Pennsylvania of assaulting a 15-year-old girl, since newspaper clipping was not a part of res gestae and had no relevance or material bearing on the essential aspects of crime for which he was being tried. Mason v. State, App. 2 Dist., 286 So.2d 17 (1973). Criminal Law  376; Criminal Law  1169.1(6)

Where defendants in arson prosecution had not first put their character in evidence, attack by state upon character of defendants through showing, via its witnesses and over defendants' objections, that defendants were drug addicts constituted reversible error. Machara v. State, App. 4 Dist., 272 So.2d 870 (1973), certiorari denied 277 So.2d 535. Criminal Law  376; Criminal Law  1169.1(6)

Defendant in murder prosecution was not prejudiced by testimony of victim's mother to effect that defendant was prejudiced toward Negroes. Robles v. State, 210 So.2d 441 (1968). Criminal Law  1169.1(6)

Admission in evidence, in prosecution for manslaughter by intoxicated motorist, of defendant's propensity to purchase, several times a week, miniature bottles of vodka, if error, was harmless where record established clear, convicing and uncontradicted evidence of defendant's guilt. State v. Wadsworth, 210 So.2d 4 (1968). Criminal Law  1169.1(6)

Admission of testimony showing defendant's bad character was reversible error where defendant had not put character in issue. Dixon v. State, App. 2 Dist., 191 So.2d 94 (1966). Criminal Law  376; Criminal Law  1169.1(6)

Refusal to permit defendant charged with second degree murder of his wife and her paramour to put on testimony as to defendant's character and reputation in the community for violence or nonviolence entitled defendant to new trial. Norman v. State, App. 3 Dist., 156 So.2d 186 (1963), certiorari denied 165 So.2d 463. Criminal Law  1170(1)

It was error for trial court to admit, in rebuttal of proof of defendant's good character, which he had placed in issue, evidence of specific acts of bad conduct but admission was not prejudicial or harmful to rights of defendant, where record left no room for reasonable doubt that defendant was guilty. Olsen v. State, 75 So.2d 281 (1954). Criminal Law  380; Criminal Law  1169.1(6)

head.head.info: 153. Defenses, criminal cases--In general

para.paratext: It was prejudicial error to deprive jury in grand larceny prosecution of proffered but excluded evidence of defendant, whose defense was that he had no intent to defraud or steal from city and that his failure to pay for doors charged to city was an oversight on his part of other similar purchases defendant had made and charged to city and later paid for where state had introduced similar factual evidence pertaining to other purchases made by defendant and charged to city. Sharp v. State, App. 1 Dist., 221 So.2d 217 (1969). Criminal Law  396(1); Criminal Law  1170(1)

head.head.info: 154. ---- Insanity, defenses, criminal cases

para.paratext: Where admissibility of psychiatrist's testimony as to sanity of defendant at time of the offense was not conditioned by trial court on requirement that prosecution call as a witness the psychologist who had examined and tested defendant extensively and who was present at trial and available to testify, government's failure to call psychologist whose report testifying psychiatrist, who only participated in a brief examination of defendant, had access to was not of itself reversible error. U. S. v. Harper, 1972, 460 F.2d 705. Criminal Law  1168(2)

The trial court committed reversible error in excluding testimony of two psychiatrists who defendant attempted to call as expert witnesses to support insanity defense to charges of rape, kidnapping, robbery and entering without breaking with intent to commit a felony. Simonds v. State, App. 2 Dist., 304 So.2d 525 (1974), certiorari denied 316 So.2d 293. Criminal Law  474; Criminal Law  1170(1)

Ruling which had effect of requiring defendant, as a predicate to use of psychiatric testimony concerning his sanity, to take the stand and abridge his constitutional rights against self-incrimination was reversibly erroneous. Jones v. State, 289 So.2d 725 (1974). Criminal Law  393(1); Criminal Law  1170(1)

head.head.info: 155. ---- Entrapment, defenses, criminal cases

para.paratext: Sustaining objections to defendant's questions regarding his conversations with informer who could not be located at time of trial and whom defendant sought to subpoena to testify on entrapment issue was not reversible error, if error at all. U. S. v. Rodriguez, 1973, 474 F.2d 587. Criminal Law  1170(1)

head.head.info: 156. ---- Self defense, defenses, criminal cases

para.paratext: Sustaining prosecutor's objection to introduction of defendant's signed statement to police that he acted in self-defense did not constitute harmful error, despite claim that it operated to deny defendant due process in that statement was crucial to his defense, where verdict was otherwise supported by evidence. Lawrence v. State, App. 3 Dist., 303 So.2d 70 (1974). Criminal Law  1170(1)

Where accused's wife as a witness for state gave testimony at variance with accused's claim of self-defense, refusal to permit investigator to testify that at time he first interviewed wife she told him that she saw the deceased make a move as though he had a weapon was error, but did not require reversal under circumstances. Mahone v. State, App. 3 Dist., 222 So.2d 769 (1969). Criminal Law  1170(1); Witnesses  379(2)

head.head.info: 157. Identification evidence, criminal cases--In general

para.paratext: Where identification testimony of one witness was erroneously admitted and where prosecuting attorney in closing argument disparaged identification testimony of second witness, the alleged victim in the case sub justice, and relied upon combined effect of testimony by all identification witnesses to establish reliability, erroneous admission of testimony could not be said to be harmless beyond reasonable doubt though evidence against defendant was quite convincing. Blackburn v. Cross, 1975, 510 F.2d 1014, rehearing denied 517 F.2d 464. Criminal Law  1169.1(5)

If the procedures used by the police in obtaining the out-of-court identification were not unnecessarily suggestive, the court need not consider whether the procedure gave rise to substantial likelihood of misidentification. Fitzpatrick v. State, 900 So.2d 495 (2005), revised on rehearing. Criminal Law  339.8(1)

Factors to be considered in evaluating likelihood of misidentification, for purposes of determining admissibility of out-of-court identification, include opportunity of the witness to view the criminal at the time of the crime, the witness' degree of attention, the accuracy of the witness' prior description of the criminal, the level of certainty demonstrated by the witness at the confrontation, and the length of time between the crime and the confrontation. Fitzpatrick v. State, 900 So.2d 495 (2005), revised on rehearing. Criminal Law  339.8(1)

Error in trial court's admission of victim's statement to detective several days after shooting that defendant was shooter was reversible error in trial for attempted murder, where statement was introduced through law enforcement witness, victim's credibility was at heart of trial, and there was no physical, corroborative evidence against defendant. Peterson v. State, App. 4 Dist., 874 So.2d 14 (2004), rehearing denied. Criminal Law  1170.5(1)

The test for suppressing an out-of-court identification is (1) whether the police used an unnecessarily suggestive procedure to obtain the out-of-court identification; and (2) if so, considering all the circumstances, whether the suggestive procedure gave rise to a substantial likelihood of irreparable misidentification. State v. Jones, App. 3 Dist., 849 So.2d 438 (2003), review granted 857 So.2d 196, review dismissed 889 So.2d 806. Criminal Law  339.8(2.1)

The test for suppression of an out-of-court identification is two-fold: (1) whether the police used an unnecessarily suggestive procedure to obtain the out-of-court identification; and (2) if so, considering all the circumstances, whether the suggestive procedure gave rise to a substantial likelihood of irreparable misidentification. Rimmer v. State, 825 So.2d 304 (2002), rehearing denied, certiorari denied 123 S.Ct. 567, 537 U.S. 1034, 154 L.Ed.2d 453, denial of post-conviction relief affirmed 59 So.3d 763. Criminal Law  339.8(2.1)

The factors to be considered in evaluating the likelihood of misidentification of the defendant in an out-of-court identification include the opportunity of the witness to view the criminal at the time of the crime, the witness' degree of attention, the accuracy of the witness' prior description of the criminal, the level of certainty demonstrated by the witness at the confrontation, and the length of time between the crime and the confrontation. Rimmer v. State, 825 So.2d 304 (2002), rehearing denied, certiorari denied 123 S.Ct. 567, 537 U.S. 1034, 154 L.Ed.2d 453, denial of post-conviction relief affirmed 59 So.3d 763. Criminal Law  339.8(1)

Any fact which in the course of ordinary affairs tends to satisfy a person of average judgment as to the identity of an individual is admissible as evidence bearing on that issue. State v. Fischer, App. 5 Dist., 387 So.2d 473 (1980). Criminal Law  339

The opinion, belief, judgment or impression of an ordinary, nonexpert witness as to the identification of a person or object is admissible in evidence if based on the knowledge of the witness. State v. Fischer, App. 5 Dist., 387 So.2d 473 (1980). Criminal Law  452(3)

In mask cases where the facial features of the attacker are covered, and in voice identification cases where the witness never sees the attacker, the witness is permitted, based on his or her observations or perception, to identify the alleged attacker. State v. Fischer, App. 5 Dist., 387 So.2d 473 (1980). Criminal Law  453

Evidence offered on issue of identification, in order to be admissible, need not in itself constitute clear or irrefutable proof. State v. Fischer, App. 5 Dist., 387 So.2d 473 (1980). Criminal Law  339

Identification testimony based on tactile impressions gained during assault was admissible for evaluation by jury as they saw fit, whether it pertained to the in-court or the out-of-court identification, where witness was no casual observer, but the victim of one of the most personally humiliating of all crimes and, aside from fact she had an ample opportunity to investigate the features of her attacker, as well as his general body build, she was able to give a specific and detailed description that pointed to a determined effort to gain perception as to her attacker's identity and, upon confrontation with defendant, demonstrated an unwavering high level of certainty. State v. Fischer, App. 5 Dist., 387 So.2d 473 (1980). Criminal Law  339.10(10)

Introduction, in murder and robbery prosecution, of identification evidence of second man involved in criminal episode in addition to evidence of identification of defendant was not prejudicial error. Gilbert v. State, App. 3 Dist., 311 So.2d 384 (1975). Criminal Law  1169.1(5)

Even if error was committed in rape prosecution with regard to admission of testimony that identification of an accused was made by victim's companion as well as by victim and with regard to admission of letter, which was purportedly sent to victim by an accused and which stated that the “Thing I want to say I can't say then because I don't want to condemn myself so. So please I am trying to beg you understand me and come to my aid--I'm very sorry,” such error was harmless where such evidence was cumulative and the other evidence against accused was overwhelming. Williams v. State, App. 3 Dist., 307 So.2d 843 (1975). Criminal Law  1169.2(2); Criminal Law  1169.2(7)

Error, in exclusion of evidence which related to identification of defendant by victim, the place of identification and manner thereof, was prejudicial. C. A. W. v. State, App. 1 Dist., 295 So.2d 329 (1974). Criminal Law  1170(1)

Notwithstanding impropriety of police procedure relating to identification witness and narrow circumscription of cross-examination of state witnesses when effort was made to obtain description of area searched by investigating officer, conviction was affirmed where a reviewing court could, beyond any reasonable doubt, declare record to demonstrate defendant's guilt. Settle v. State, App. 2 Dist., 288 So.2d 511 (1974), certiorari denied 295 So.2d 627. Criminal Law  1169.1(5); Criminal Law  1170.5(5)

Error, if any, permitting identification of murder victim by her brother was harmless, where existence of a family of the victim was otherwise revealed. Smith v. State, App. 3 Dist., 284 So.2d 461 (1973), certiorari denied 290 So.2d 64. Criminal Law  1168(2)

Error, if any, in allowing murder victim's mother to testify for the purpose of identifying the victim even though other witnesses not related to victim were available was harmless whre jury was in proper possession of knowledge that victim was survived by his mother, and the mother formed essential link in chain of custody of victim's clothing and her testimony concerning same and the finding of knife closed in pocket of the clothing tended to discount defendant's self-defense assertion. Scott v. State, App. 4 Dist., 256 So.2d 19 (1971). Criminal Law  1169.1(5)

Testimony of physician, who had treated a patient with name similar to that of defendant at hospital on date accident occurred, was not prejudicial error notwithstanding that doctor could not identify defendant as named individual he had treated where there was other evidence from which trier of fact could determine if person treated by physician was defendant; identity of name alone was not necessary as identity could be shown by other facts and circumstances. Ricks v. State, App. 3 Dist., 242 So.2d 763 (1971). Criminal Law  1169.1(5)

Where defendant's guilt of charged first-degree murder was so clear and convincing that identity testimony by deceased's brother could not have harmed defendant, there was no showing in record that such testimony had any prejudicial effect, and no showing that other witnesses were available to prosecution to identify victim's body, allowing testimony that deceased was witness' brother was not reversible error. Abram v. State, App. 1 Dist., 242 So.2d 215 (1970), certiorari denied 245 So.2d 870. Criminal Law  1169.1(5)

Allowing both wife and sister of deceased to testify as to their relationship to deceased was prejudicial error, in homicide prosecution, even if it was necessary to call one of the witnesses to prove identity of deceased. Gibson v. State, App. 1 Dist., 191 So.2d 58 (1966). Criminal Law  338(6); Criminal Law  1169.1(3)

Admission of testimony as to matters other than those relating solely to identification of defendant as one of participants in robbery, in view of stipulation that crime had been committed, was not prejudicial to defendant where in order for jury to properly evaluate degree of reliance to be placed upon witnesses' identification of defendant it was necessary that jurors be apprised of circumstances surrounding commission of offense and opportunities available to witnesses to observe participants. Yant v. State, App. 3 Dist., 154 So.2d 908 (1963). Criminal Law  1169.1(4)

Where no question as to identity of defendant was involved in prosecution for conducting lottery, any error in refusing to exclude testimony that defendant was known to witness by another name, on ground that such testimony was hearsay and tended to prejudice jury against defendant, was not harmful error under facts of case. McCain v. State, App. 2 Dist., 151 So.2d 841 (1963), certiorari denied 157 So.2d 817. Criminal Law  1169.1(9)

head.head.info: 158. ---- Fingerprint identification, identification evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Failure of State to comply with rule requiring that defense counsel be given notice of taking of defendant's fingerprints was harmless where State had served defense counsel with copy of motion to take fingerprints and thereafter serve notice of hearing which was blank in portion where particular motion that was to be heard should have been listed. Vena v. State, App. 3 Dist., 295 So.2d 720 (1974), certiorari denied 307 So.2d 184. Criminal Law  1169.1(5)

Where card bearing defendant's fingerprints as taken by police was admitted and served to identify a print found on stolen articles as that of defendant, failure to present testimony of all persons through whose hands fingerprint card had passed was not basis for reversal in view of fact that officer who took defendant's prints sufficiently identified card. Ruiz v. State, App. 3 Dist., 199 So.2d 478 (1967), certiorari denied 204 So.2d 330, certiorari denied 88 S.Ct. 2068, 392 U.S. 910. Criminal Law  1169.1(1)

Action of State, in order to identify signature of defendant, who was accused of obtaining property by worthless checks, in putting into evidence fingerprint cards, which were blocked out except for defendant's signatures, and conduct of witnesses in referring to cards as fingerprint cards did not amount to reversible error. Davis v. State, App. 2 Dist., 155 So.2d 167 (1963). Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

head.head.info: 159. ---- Hearsay, identification, identification evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Permitting officer's testimony that unnamed witnesses had identified someone with particular name as being involved in robbery and detective's testimony that named individual was in fact defendant, based on information he received from still other police officers was not harmless error in prosecution arising out of robbery, where there was conflicting testimony over identification of perpetrator of robbery. Saintilus v. State, App. 4 Dist., 869 So.2d 1280 (2004). Criminal Law  1169.1(5)

Trial court in prosecution for attempted trafficking in heroin, possession of marijuana, and possession of drug paraphernalia, should not have permitted police officer to testify that he received a tip that defendant was processing and dealing in heroin from his home; only non-hearsay relevance of testimony was to explain why police attention was focused on defendant, and better practice was to allow officer to state that he acted upon a tip or information received without going into the details of the accusatory information. Alvelo v. State, App. 5 Dist., 866 So.2d 1240 (2004), rehearing denied. Criminal Law  419(3)

In view of direct identification of defendant by undercover agent, who purchased LSD from defendant, the admission of hearsay testimony that license tag number had been identified by authorities in Tallahassee as belonging to defendant amounted to merely harmless error. Pickrell v. State, App. 2 Dist., 301 So.2d 473 (1974), certiorari denied 314 So.2d 585. Criminal Law  1169.2(6)

Permitting police officer to testify that an alleged identification of defendant had been made during course of officer's investigation constituted harmless error where the objectionable hearsay was entirely cumulative and repetitious of other testimony in record. Frazier v. State, App. 3 Dist., 216 So.2d 264 (1968). Criminal Law  1169.2(6)

head.head.info: 160. ---- Photographs, identification, identification evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Fact that second witness viewed photographic array containing defendant's photograph prior to defendant's hearing to suppress witness's identification of defendant did not unduly bolster witness's in-court identification of defendant, where witness testified that she had ample opportunity to observe defendant on night victim was murdered. Fitzpatrick v. State, 900 So.2d 495 (2005), revised on rehearing. Criminal Law  339.10(8)

In-court identification of defendant by second witness was admissible independent of prior photographic array identification, based on witness's ability to observe defendant prior to victim's murder. Fitzpatrick v. State, 900 So.2d 495 (2005), revised on rehearing. Criminal Law  339.10(8)

Record supported finding that second witness's out-of-court identification of defendant in photographic array was reliable and not the product of suggestion; record revealed that detective explained to witness that he was going to show her a group of photographs and that witness should see if the person was there that she recalled being at other witness's house on night victim was killed, and detective testified that he asked witness to look at each photograph before deciding and that witness looked at every photo and immediately selected defendant's photograph in less than ten seconds. Fitzpatrick v. State, 900 So.2d 495 (2005), revised on rehearing. Criminal Law  339.7(3)

Police officer's testimony that unnamed witnesses had identified someone with particular name as being involved in robbery and detective's testimony that named individual was in fact defendant, based on information he received from still other police officers, was hearsay that was not admissible to show why officer prepared array of photographs which included defendant's photograph; police officer's state of mind in preparing array was not material issue in prosecution, nor was it necessary for police to show why they prepared array of photographs or even why they included defendant's photo in group. Saintilus v. State, App. 4 Dist., 869 So.2d 1280 (2004). Criminal Law  419(3)

Photographic lineup by which witness to attempted robbery at discount store identified defendant as the perpetrator was not unnecessarily suggestive, even though witness initially identified perpetrator as being an employee of the store chain, and defendant was only employee of chain in the lineup; computer database selected photographs for the lineup based on similarity to defendant, and due process did not require other employees of chain to be included in lineup. State v. Francois, App. 4 Dist., 863 So.2d 1288 (2004). Constitutional Law  4658(4); Criminal Law  339.7(4)

Photographic lineup was not unnecessarily suggestive, even though the victim had told the police that the gunman had a baseball cap pulled down over his eyes, gave a description that did not match the defendant's actual physical attributes, and was only able to glimpse the gunman during the robbery and murders; the claims at most suggested that the victim lacked sufficient opportunity to observe the perpetrator. Rimmer v. State, 825 So.2d 304 (2002), rehearing denied, certiorari denied 123 S.Ct. 567, 537 U.S. 1034, 154 L.Ed.2d 453, denial of post-conviction relief affirmed 59 So.3d 763. Criminal Law  339.7(3)

Photographic array at which witness selected defendant as perpetrator of store robbery and murders six days earlier did not create a substantial likelihood of misidentification; the witness initially saw the defendant in the waiting room of the store, later watched him and another person load boxes of stereo equipment into a car, had not been forced to lie face down on the floor, provided an accurate description, and was able to observe the defendant for the entire episode of approximately twenty minutes, and her selection of another photo did not affect her level of certainty because she claimed that the two photos looked alike. Rimmer v. State, 825 So.2d 304 (2002), rehearing denied, certiorari denied 123 S.Ct. 567, 537 U.S. 1034, 154 L.Ed.2d 453, denial of post-conviction relief affirmed 59 So.3d 763. Criminal Law  339.7(3)

Where victims were exposed to defendants for approximately ten minutes during course of robbery and identified defendants at trial but made no mention of intervening identification of defendants' photographs, admission of officers' testimony that victims selected photographs of defendants from those shown to victims was error but was harmless in view of victim's strong and unequivocal identification testimony. Moore v. State, App. 4 Dist., 267 So.2d 850 (1972). Criminal Law  421(6); Criminal Law  1169.1(5)

Defendant who contended that trial court permitted in-court identification based upon illegal photographic confrontation demonstrated no reversible error. Lawrence v. State, App. 3 Dist., 252 So.2d 299 (1971). Criminal Law  1169.1(5)

In prosecution for robbery, admission of testimony of witness concerning identification of defendant was not reversible error on the ground of alleged illegality of arrest and fact that photographs were taken of him at time he was booked. Hamrick v. State, App. 3 Dist., 235 So.2d 360 (1970), certiorari denied 238 So.2d 421, certiorari denied 91 S.Ct. 466, 400 U.S. 994, 27 L.Ed.2d 443. Criminal Law  1169.1(5)

In view of extensive evidence implicating defendants with commission of robbery, prejudice, if any, resulting from robbery victim's initial identification of defendants from photographs outside presence of defendants' counsel was harmless, there being no very substantial likelihood of irreparable mis-identification. Jenkins v. State, App. 3 Dist., 228 So.2d 114 (1969). Criminal Law  1169.2(2)

Admission of victims' testimony concerning their photographic identification of defendant was not reversible error where identification procedure was in no way suggestive and did not create a very substantial likelihood of irreparable misidentification. Tafero v. State, App. 3 Dist., 223 So.2d 564 (1969), certiorari denied 225 So.2d 912. Criminal Law  1169.1(5)

In prosecution for murder in the first degree, admission of photograph of deceased lying on a mortuary slab was prejudicial error, where location of shotgun head wound was conceded and proved by other evidence, and photograph did not include any part of locus of crime and was too far in time and space therefrom to have any independent probative value. Dyken v. State, 89 So.2d 866 (1956). Criminal Law  438(5.1); Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

head.head.info: 161. ---- In-court identification, identification evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: No reversible error appeared in relation to denial of motion to suppress confession and in-court identification of defendant who was convicted of forgery and of buying, receiving or concealing stolen property. Gould v. State, App. 3 Dist., 318 So.2d 522 (1975). Criminal Law  1169.1(5); Criminal Law  1169.12

Even though witness' in-court identification which was not based upon independent source was tainted because lineup held approximately two hours after commission of offense but prior to filing of information was impermissively suggestive, where witness was not an eyewitness to the robbery but her testimony merely placed defendants near scene of crime and where both defendants, in statements properly introduced into evidence and through their witness, admitted that defendants were near scene of robbery, witness' testimony was cumulative and introduction of her identification testimony was harmless error. Singleton v. State, App. 2 Dist., 303 So.2d 420 (1974). Criminal Law  1169.2(2)

Evidence of guilt was not so conclusive as to warrant finding that admission of in-court identification without a specific indication that it was not tainted by impermissibly suggestive lineup was harmless error. Cribbs v. State, App. 2 Dist., 297 So.2d 335 (1974), certiorari denied 303 So.2d 335. Criminal Law  1169.1(5)

Although preferred procedure is for trial court to make a preliminary determination, out of jury's presence, that in-court identification testimony has not been tainted by a prior improper identification proceeding, failure of trial judge in the instant case to make such a determination adverse to defendant was not reversible error, in view of the fact that the in-court identification testimony was not tainted by any pretrial procedure amounting to a deprivation of due process. Lewis v. State, App. 3 Dist., 256 So.2d 526 (1972). Criminal Law  1168(1)

Trial court's rulings on questions of ten-year-old witness' in-court identification of defendant were not reversible error even though the identification was prefaced by use of words “I think” and “I believe”. Grech v. State, App. 3 Dist., 243 So.2d 216 (1971), certiorari denied 247 So.2d 439. Criminal Law  1169.1(5)

Fact that defendant was only Negro in courtroom when sheriff's deputy took state witnesses to a door of courtroom and asked them to look in and see if they recognized anyone in the courtroom did not require reversal of robbery conviction where state's witness was present when crime was committed and could identify defendant on basis of witness' own observation of defendant. Gilmore v. State, App. 2 Dist., 240 So.2d 179 (1970). Criminal Law  1169.1(5)

Even if identity of defendant was a material issue, where record made clear that prosecutrix' in-court identification of defendant had a source wholly independent of field identification which prosecutrix made shortly after defendant was initially arrested upon suspicion of raping prosecutrix, allowing deputy sheriff to testify over objection as to field identification made by prosecutrix when she was brought to place where defendant was detained immediately following his apprehension did not prejudice defendant's rights. Robinson v. State, App. 4 Dist., 237 So.2d 268 (1970). Criminal Law  1169.1(5)

head.head.info: 162. ---- Police lineups, identification, identification evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Where witness was brought to police station for purpose of identifying woman who had rented automobile and spontaneously recognized defendant at a booking desk as driver of automobile which had brought person who rented automobile to rental firm, there was no “lineup” such as would require the presence of counsel in order to render in-court identification admissible, and in any event, identification of defendant as driver of the automobile was not prejudicial error in view of other evidence implicating defendant in conspiring to transport falsely made and forged securities. U. S. v. Seader, 1971, 440 F.2d 488, certiorari denied 92 S.Ct. 56, 404 U.S. 826, 30 L.Ed.2d 54. Criminal Law  339.8(7); Criminal Law  1169.2(2)

Live lineup at which victim identified defendant was not made unnecessarily suggestive by police statement that the defendant had been arrested and had the victim's wallet. Rimmer v. State, 825 So.2d 304 (2002), rehearing denied, certiorari denied 123 S.Ct. 567, 537 U.S. 1034, 154 L.Ed.2d 453, denial of post-conviction relief affirmed 59 So.3d 763. Criminal Law  339.8(3)

The fact that the defendant was the only person in the physical lineup that had also been in the photographic spread did not make the lineup unnecessarily suggestive; the physical lineup took place two months after the photo spread, and nothing indicated that the victim again viewed the photo spread shortly before viewing the physical lineup. Rimmer v. State, 825 So.2d 304 (2002), rehearing denied, certiorari denied 123 S.Ct. 567, 537 U.S. 1034, 154 L.Ed.2d 453, denial of post-conviction relief affirmed 59 So.3d 763. Criminal Law  339.8(4)

Police officer's improper comment to witness that a victim had picked defendant from photographic array did not make the procedure unnecessarily suggestive; the witness had already selected the defendant from the photo spread, and nothing indicated that the police caused the witness to select the defendant. Rimmer v. State, 825 So.2d 304 (2002), rehearing denied, certiorari denied 123 S.Ct. 567, 537 U.S. 1034, 154 L.Ed.2d 453, denial of post-conviction relief affirmed 59 So.3d 763. Criminal Law  339.7(3)

Trial court, in prosecution for robbery, aggravated assault, and use of firearm in commission of felony, did not err reversibly by refusing to grant defendant's motion requesting court to order State to arrange pretrial corporeal lineup identification of defendants where no contention was made that pretrial photographic lineup from which defendants were positively identified was unconstitutionally suggestive, and where, if defendants were dissatisfied with method of identification, they could have arranged for lineup with court's assistance if necessary. Gibson v. State, App. 1 Dist., 325 So.2d 447 (1976), certiorari denied 341 So.2d 291, certiorari denied 97 S.Ct. 1699, 431 U.S. 906, 52 L.Ed.2d 390. Criminal Law  1169.1(5)

Even if corporeal and photo lineups used by investigating officers were unfair and impermissibly suggestive, defendant, whose sole defense was that he did not willfully participate or acquiesce in the kidnapping and murder, was not deprived of a fair trial. Bryan v. State, App. 2 Dist., 290 So.2d 515 (1974), certiorari denied 297 So.2d 569. Criminal Law  1169.1(5)

Testimony by officer that he observed victim as she identified defendant at lineup was inadmissible because it was submitted by State as original or substantive evidence error in admission of officer's testimony did not permeate trial to such an extent that it constituted reversible error where State proved its case by victim's boyfriend's statement, by admissible confession, and by other competent testimony and where court fully instructed jury to disregard objectionable part of officer's testimony. Stevens v. State, App. 1 Dist., 251 So.2d 565 (1971). Criminal Law  421(6); Criminal Law  1169.1(5)

In view of testimony of witnesses who identified defendant as perpetrator of crime, allegedly improper lineup and prejudicial matters at preliminary hearing were not grounds for reversal of conviction for robbery. Johnson v. State, App. 3 Dist., 248 So.2d 208 (1971). Criminal Law  1169.1(5)

Permitting identification of defendant by state's witness in a police lineup in the absence of defense counsel did not constitute prejudicial error, in view of fact that instant case came to trial and was decided before the non-retroactive Wade decision of the United States Supreme Court, and in view of further fact that it did not appear that in-court identification of defendant was tainted by police lineup identification process. Coleman v. State, App. 4 Dist., 215 So.2d 96 (1968). Criminal Law  1169.1(5)

head.head.info: 163. Incriminating acts and statements, criminal cases--In general

para.paratext: Massiah violation, if it occurred, was not ground for reversal as to defendant whose earlier valid incriminating statements had assured conviction. U. S. v. Venere, 1969, 416 F.2d 144. Criminal Law  1169.2(6)

Use of allegedly tainted statement at trial was not ground for reversal where it added nothing of substance to previous admissions not challenged on review. U. S. v. Venere, 1969, 416 F.2d 144. Criminal Law  1169.12

Admissions or confessions of a defendant may not be admitted in evidence absent independently established corpus delicti. Chaparro v. State, App. 2 Dist., 873 So.2d 631 (2004). Criminal Law  413.74; Criminal Law  413.75

Three separate statements obtained from defendant who was placed in jail on December 24 and who was not carried before a magistrate until after his indictment on January 9, of the following year, and who did not have benefit of and advice of an attorney during time statements were obtained, were not competent evidence, and presentation thereof to jury was prejudicial error. Jacobs v. State, App. 1 Dist., 248 So.2d 515 (1971), certiorari denied 253 So.2d 877. Criminal Law  411.86(5); Criminal Law  1169.12

It is not inexorably reversible error for trial court, in exercise of its broad discretion, to admit evidence of confession or admission against interest prior to time corpus delicti is actually established. Clark v. State, App. 2 Dist., 229 So.2d 877 (1969). Criminal Law  1168(2)

Permitting jurors to use copies of excluded typewritten transcript of recorded conversation between state's witness and one defendant charged with violation of lottery laws as aid in following rendition of admitted recording, which was partially inaudible and unintelligible, was error requiring reversal as to defendant who engaged in such conversation. Brady v. State, App. 2 Dist., 178 So.2d 121 (1965). Criminal Law  438.1; Criminal Law  1169.12

Testimony as to defendant's pretrial statement that he would bet officers $100 that he would not be convicted and that if he was he would be placed on probation was immaterial and irrelevant to issue of defendant's guilt of attempted rape and admission thereof was reversible error. Jenkins v. State, App. 3 Dist., 177 So.2d 756 (1965). Criminal Law  410.8; Criminal Law  1169.12

That a written statement made by defendant to the coroner's jury is introduced in evidence is not reversible error, when the only incriminating fact therein is the act of the shooting, which is not denied. Smothers v. State, 64 Fla. 459, 59 So. 900 (1912). Criminal Law  1169.12

head.head.info: 164. ---- Accomplices and co-defendants, incriminating acts and statements, criminal cases

para.paratext: Error, if any, in admitting detective's testimony regarding incriminating statements which were made by defendants in the absence of each other and which placed defendants together at shopping center where robbery was committed when neither defendant took stand at joint trial was harmless, where such testimony was merely cumulative of other uncontroverted evidence placing defendants at scene of robbery. Singleton v. State, App. 2 Dist., 303 So.2d 420 (1974). Criminal Law  1169.2(6)

Error, if any, in prosecution for conspiracy to commit robbery and grand larceny, in admitting testimony and tape recordings of conversation, which occurred subsequent to filing of information, of defendants with undercover police officer was harmless as to one defendant, where there was clear and convincing evidence elicited from police officers that such defendant was planning a robbery. Scaldeferri v. State, App. 3 Dist., 294 So.2d 407 (1974), certiorari denied 303 So.2d 21, certiorari denied 95 S.Ct. 304, 419 U.S. 993, 42 L.Ed.2d 266, certiorari dismissed, cause remanded 320 So.2d 1, certiorari denied 327 So.2d 229. Criminal Law  1169.2(7)

head.head.info: 165. ---- Admissions by silence, incriminating acts and statements, criminal cases

para.paratext: Claim that allowing FBI agent to testify that defendant had refused to sign a waiver of his rights prejudicially brought before jury defendant's invocation of privilege against self-incrimination was frivolous where defendant answered agent's subsequent questions. U. S. v. Owens, 1970, 431 F.2d 349. Criminal Law  1169.12

Statement to witness, by one person in a group of which defendant was a member, that “we are going to hit the store so you better get out” was not accusatory as regarding the defendant, and where the declarant was not produced by state and did not testify at trial the statement was not admissible as an admission by silence within hearsay exception, but the objectionable hearsay was at best cumulative and harmless where there was more than sufficient evidence, particularly the in-court identification of defendant by the victim, upon which jury could find that defendant participated in robbery of grocery store. Daughtery v. State, App. 1 Dist., 269 So.2d 426 (1972). Criminal Law  410.35; Criminal Law  1169.12

Improper admission of testimony of police officer in grand larceny prosecution that when victim stated that defendant was the one who had taken her purse the defendant remained silent was reversible error, though evidence, aside from testimony of police officer, was sufficient to support conviction. Jones v. State, App. 3 Dist., 200 So.2d 574 (1967). Criminal Law  1169.12

In prosecution for murder, it was reversible error to admit testimony of conversation in which defendant's father accused defendant of murdering deceased who was only missing at that time, where defendant's reply was “No he's around”, since such reply constituted an unequivocal denial of guilt and was not an admission by silence. Douglas v. State, 89 So.2d 659 (1956). Criminal Law  410.33; Criminal Law  1169.12

In prosecution for breaking and entering a dwelling with intent to commit a felony, permitting evidence of defendant's refusal to answer question propounded to him by arresting officers, who had assaulted and abused him, to go to jury as showing admission by silence of crime charged against him was prejudicial error where there was no evidence pointing conclusively to defendant's guilt. Dedge v. State, 128 Fla. 343, 174 So. 725 (1937). Criminal Law  1169.12

head.head.info: 166. ---- Custodial interrogation, incriminating acts and statements, criminal cases

para.paratext: Illegal police interrogations cannot be deterred if court closes its eyes to official indifference in the name of harmlessness. U. S. v. Blair, 1972, 470 F.2d 331, certiorari denied 93 S.Ct. 1536, 411 U.S. 908, 36 L.Ed.2d 197. Criminal Law  1169.12

Although defendant in an in-custody interrogation by government agent was advised of right to remain silent and right to consult with an attorney before making any statement, since he was not advised by agent that he had a right to a court-appointed counsel present during interrogation, admission of statement at trial which took place subsequent to Miranda decision required reversal of conviction. Fendley v. U. S., 1967, 384 F.2d 923. Criminal Law  411.11; Criminal Law  1169.12

Conviction was affirmed against contention that reversible error occurred when the State introduced testimony that the accused, while in custody, remained silent in the face of an accusation of guilt of the crime for which he was arrested and charged. Lester v. State, App. 4 Dist., 325 So.2d 13 (1976), certiorari dismissed 345 So.2d 424. Criminal Law  1169.12

Where boy while in custody signed “consent to interview” but did not give statement at such time, stating that he was confused, and counsel was denied opportunity following morning to see boy but detective interrogated boy on same morning for an hour and a half, boy was deprived of effective representation by counsel at only stage when legal aid and advice would help him, and where his oral statement to detective was only evidence to connect him with crime, he was entitled to reversal of robbery conviction, whether denial of counsel was deliberate or was result of administrative problems. Davis v. State, App. 2 Dist., 287 So.2d 399 (1973). Criminal Law  411.31; Criminal Law  1169.12

Error, if any, in receiving evidence of defendant's postarrest statement that he had burglarized 4,010 motel rooms, objected to on ground that it was so excessive on issue of intent as to prejudice jury against defendant and deprive him of fair trial, was harmless in face of strong proof of guilt by other uncontradicted evidence. Garcia v. State, App. 3 Dist., 278 So.2d 678 (1973), certiorari denied 285 So.2d 21. Criminal Law  1169.12

Permitting police officer to testify as to statements made by defendant at in-custody interrogation was not ground for reversal of conviction for manslaughter, where defendant made no confession and denied knowledge of homicide and statements were made following clear explanation of defendant's rights. Davis v. State, App. 2 Dist., 216 So.2d 87 (1968). Criminal Law  1169.12

Conviction of one defendant for conspiring to commit abortion and of an attempt to commit abortion could not stand where evidence against her was obtained in a custodial interrogation without her being given adequate warning of her constitutional rights as prescribed in Miranda decision. Jimenez v. State, App. 3 Dist., 208 So.2d 124 (1968), certiorari denied 212 So.2d 878. Criminal Law  1169.12

Defendant charged with first-degree murder of his mother was not prejudiced by testimony of a police officer as to statement made by defendant during an interrogation conducted in absence of defendant's counsel. Worthington v. State, App. 3 Dist., 183 So.2d 728 (1966), certiorari denied 188 So.2d 824. Criminal Law  1169.12

Technical error in admitting testimony as to statements or confessions by accused while in custody is not ground for reversal where there is other evidence of confessions and there is evidence to sustain verdict. Gorey v. State, 71 Fla. 195, 71 So. 328 (1916). Criminal Law  1169.12

head.head.info: 167. ---- Guilty pleas, incriminating acts and statements, criminal cases

para.paratext: Admission of evidence that defendant had pleaded guilty to charge at issue (plea having been later withdrawn) was prejudicial error. Toth v. State, App. 2 Dist., 297 So.2d 53 (1974). Criminal Law  410.23; Criminal Law  1169.12

Admission of testimony by magistrate, before whom defendant had pleaded guilty at time when he was not represented by counsel and had not been informed of right to have counsel provided at expense of state that defendant had pleaded guilty was error requiring new trial. Rollins v. State, 194 So.2d 247 (1967). Criminal Law  410.23; Criminal Law  1169.12

head.head.info: 168. ---- Privilege, incriminating acts and statements, criminal cases

para.paratext: Privilege against self-incrimination that no person shall be compelled to give testimony against himself, is mandatory, and its violation will cause a reversal of a conviction. Rowe v. State, 87 Fla. 17, 98 So. 613 (1924). Criminal Law  1169.1(7)

head.head.info: 169. ---- Miranda warnings, incriminating acts and statements, criminal cases

para.paratext: In view of overwhelming evidence against defendant in prosecution for carnally knowing a female child under the age of ten, error occurring by reason of admission of defendant's statement to police, without proper warning of constitutional rights that he was wearing the same clothes which he wore the day before when incident occurred and the admission of testimony as to analysis of the clothing and bed covers, which proved inconclusive, was harmless. Null v. Wainwright, 1975, 508 F.2d 340, certiorari denied 95 S.Ct. 1964, 421 U.S. 970, 44 L.Ed.2d 459. Criminal Law  1169.12

Even if it was error to admit one defendant's statements made before he had been warned of his rights to counsel and to remain silent, admission, in non-jury trial, was beyond a reasonable doubt, harmless error. U. S. v. Hill, 1970, 430 F.2d 129. Criminal Law  1169.12

Although trial court did an excellent job in attempting to weed out testimony which was admissible and that which was not, admission of too much testimony concerning conversations which took place before Miranda warnings were given required reversal. Turner v. State, App. 1 Dist., 314 So.2d 183 (1975), certiorari denied 330 So.2d 21. Criminal Law  1169.12

Admission of police officer's testimony that he advised defendant of his right to counsel and to remain silent and asked him about stolen items in automobile but that defendant had no explanation was harmless error. Wright v. State, App. 1 Dist., 251 So.2d 890 (1971). Criminal Law  410.36; Criminal Law  1169.12

In homicide prosecution, use of defendant's statement “I know. I guess I will have to get a lawyer” made in response to Miranda warning was not reversible error where statement was not offered as admission of guilt but was incorporated in hypothetical questions propounded to expert witnesses for purpose of revealing defendant's state of mind as bearing on issue of insanity; also, contention was defective as ground on appeal for want of objection at trial. Collins v. State, App. 3 Dist., 227 So.2d 538 (1969). Criminal Law  1036.1(5); Criminal Law  1169.12

Even if Miranda rule applied to defendant's statements to officer who, before arrest, inquired of defendant as to contents of back seat and trunk, admission of defendant's answers that cigarettes on seat belonged to a friend and that he had “clothes” and “stuff” in trunk would not be reversible error since their admission was harmless. James v. State, App. 4 Dist., 223 So.2d 52 (1969). Criminal Law  1169.12

Admission of defendant's prearrest comments was not reversible error where Miranda rule did not apply, some statements were inconsequential, and defendant did not object. James v. State, App. 4 Dist., 223 So.2d 52 (1969). Criminal Law  1036.1(5); Criminal Law  1169.12

Police officer's testimony that when during search of defendants' apartment, he asked defendants who owned marijuana he had found, a defendant replied “some man, don't say anything” constituted evidence of pre-trial statements tainted by reason of failure to give Miranda warnings and was erroneously admitted; but convictions would not be reversed where error was harmless in that it could not have injuriously affected the substantial rights of either of the accused. State v. Galasso, 217 So.2d 326 (1968). Criminal Law  413.3; Criminal Law  1169.12

head.head.info: 170. ---- Motion to suppress, incriminating acts and statements, criminal cases

para.paratext: Denial of motion to suppress evidence of statements made in presence of horse's owner and officers by defendant who was charged with larceny of the horse did not constitute reversible error. Thomasson v. State, App. 4 Dist., 309 So.2d 589 (1975). Criminal Law  1169.12

head.head.info: 171. ---- Voluntariness, incriminating acts and statements, criminal cases

para.paratext: Failure of trial judge to affirmatively state on the record that he found that statements made by defendant to witnesses were voluntary was harmless error where it clearly appeared from the record that the statements were voluntary and objections to testimony concerning the statements did not specifically question voluntariness. Newberry v. State, App. 1 Dist., 310 So.2d 416 (1975). Criminal Law  1169.12

Defendant arrested without warrant and charged with crime against nature could not claim that taking of written statement before bringing him before committing magistrate, which statute required to be done without unnecessary delay, made admission of statement on trial reversible error where defendant had been fully apprised of his rights prior to taking of statement and he had then voluntarily given statement to officers. Swain v. State, App. 3 Dist., 172 So.2d 3 (1965). Criminal Law  1169.12

Admission of evidence of defendant's voluntary self-incriminating statement was not prejudicial error, although defendant contended that he had immediately repudiated statement. Boyd v. State, App. 2 Dist., 162 So.2d 271 (1964). Criminal Law  1169.12

Admission of testimony of deputy sheriff concerning purported incriminating admission made by accused did not constitute prejudicial error in absence of positive testimony that threats or improper inducements were made to accused or used in obtaining admission from him. Ebert v. State, App. 2 Dist., 140 So.2d 63 (1962). Criminal Law  1169.12

Whether statements made by accused while in custody and admitted in evidence though not voluntarily made were confessions or merely admissions against interest was immaterial, where conviction was amply sustained by other evidence. Daugherty v. State, 154 Fla. 308, 17 So.2d 290 (1944). Criminal Law  1169.12

That witnesses were examined as to whether defendant's admissions and confessions were free and voluntary in presence of the jury was harmless, where the evidence showed they were free and voluntary. Stiner v. State, 78 Fla. 647, 83 So. 565 (1919). Criminal Law  1169.12

head.head.info: 172. Confessions, criminal cases--In general

para.paratext: Defendant's confession to committing various violent theft offenses was admissible as voluntarily given; while testimony at suppression hearing demonstrated that defendant got drunk before he was taken in for questioning by the police, detectives who questioned defendant testified that he did not appear intoxicated, that they advised him of his rights, that he intelligently waived those rights, and that he voluntarily gave the statements. Lawson v. State, App. 4 Dist., 884 So.2d 540 (2004), rehearing denied, review denied 902 So.2d 790. Criminal Law  410.89; Criminal Law  411.3; Criminal Law  411.96

Harmless error rule may be applied to constitutional errors, including erroneous admission of confessions. McDonnell v. State, App. 4 Dist., 292 So.2d 420 (1974), remanded 336 So.2d 553. Criminal Law  1169.12

Even if it was error to admit, without objection, confession on ground that it had not been signed by nor read to or by defendant, error was harmless where there was sufficient evidence disregarding confession to sustain finding of guilt. Simpson v. State, App. 3 Dist., 211 So.2d 862 (1968), appeal dismissed 225 So.2d 908, certiorari denied 225 So.2d 912. Criminal Law  1169.12

Defendant failed to demonstrate prejudice resulting from court's admission into evidence of his confession regarding killing of wife and paramour where confession amounted to nothing more than defendant's acknowledgment that he shot the two parties at a particular place and in particular circumstances, and he reiterated this and more at trial when he testified on his own behalf upon advice of his counsel. Kimmons v. State, App. 1 Dist., 178 So.2d 608 (1965), certiorari discharged 190 So.2d 308, certiorari denied 87 S.Ct. 2057, 387 U.S. 934, 18 L.Ed.2d 996. Criminal Law  1169.12

Permitting detective to testify as rebuttal witness that defendant made oral confession to him, following defendant's testimony that he had not made oral confession, where detective had not been subpoenaed but volunteered to testify after hearing defendant's testimony, in violation of rule requiring sequestration of witnesses, was abuse of discretion and harmful error. Jackson v. State, App. 3 Dist., 177 So.2d 353 (1965). Criminal Law  665(3); Criminal Law  1168(2)
Any error in allowing statements of accused's political beliefs to remain in accused's confession was harmless. Johnson v. State, 61 So.2d 179 (1952). Criminal Law  1169.12
Admission of confession of rape, if error, was harmless in view of overwhelming evidence of guilt. Melton v. State, 159 Fla. 106, 30 So.2d 916 (1947). Criminal Law  1169.12

Error, if any, in admitting defendant's confession in evidence on murder trial was rendered harmless by defendant's testimony that he and another went to deceased's home to commit robbery or larceny and that both were armed and deliberately shot deceased. Smith v. State, 129 Fla. 388, 176 So. 506 (1937). Criminal Law  1169.12

Even if proper predicate is not laid for confession, admitting statements of accused which could not have been harmful to him in view of other evidence, is not reversible error. Meyer v. State, 89 Fla. 261, 103 So. 630 (1925). Criminal Law  1169.12

head.head.info: 173. ---- Accomplices and co-defendants, confessions, criminal cases

para.paratext: Mere finding of a violation of the Bruton rule against admission of codefendant's confession in course of a trial does not automatically require reversal of ensuing criminal conviction, even though Bruton is retroactive, and reversal will not be required where properly admitted evidence of guilt is so overwhelming and prejudicial effects of codefendant's admission is so insignificant by comparison that it is clear beyond a reasonable doubt that improper use of the codefendant's admission was harmless error. Schneble v. Florida, U.S.Fla.1972, 92 S.Ct. 1056, 405 U.S. 427, 31 L.Ed.2d 340. Criminal Law  1169.12

In determining whether improper admission of a codefendant's confession was prejudical error a determination must be made of probable impact of the confession on minds of an average jury. Schneble v. Florida, U.S.Fla.1972, 92 S.Ct. 1056, 405 U.S. 427, 31 L.Ed.2d 340. Criminal Law  1169.12

Any violation of Bruton that might have occurred as a result of admission into evidence of codefendant's statement implicating defendant was harmless error where in view of overwhelming properly admitted evidence of guilt minds of an average jury would not have found State's case significantly less persuasive. Schneble v. Florida, U.S.Fla.1972, 92 S.Ct. 1056, 405 U.S. 427, 31 L.Ed.2d 340. Criminal Law  1169.12

In prosecution for breaking and entering dwelling, court did not err in admitting confession of codefendant in nonjury case, but in any event evidence of such confession was cumulative where four eyewitnesses testified they saw defendant leaving home of victim wearing jacket belonging to victim's son and defendant voluntarily confessed to having committed crime and his confession was introduced into evidence at trial; and admission of such cumulative evidence was harmless. Fowler v. Wainwright, 1971, 436 F.2d 387. Criminal Law  410.78; Criminal Law  1169.2(6)

Where defendant did not take the stand and was thus not subject to cross-examination, the introduction of his confession which implicated codefendant constituted prejudicial error as to codefendant. Atwell v. U. S., 1968, 398 F.2d 507. Criminal Law  425.5; Criminal Law  1169.12

Trial court committed reversible error against other defendants in admitting purported confession of one of the defendants where its introduction was not limited by appropriate instructions, given at time it was offered and in charge, to receive it only against defendant who had made it. Everitt v. U.S., 1960, 281 F.2d 429. Criminal Law  673(4); Criminal Law  1168(2)

Where evidence of guilt is overwhelming, a violation of United States Supreme Court decision that in a joint trial a confession of a codefendant who fails to take the stand cannot be introduced into evidence is harmless error. Gadson v. State, App. 3 Dist., 277 So.2d 571 (1973). Criminal Law  1169.12

Where record clearly demonstrated that confessions of each of three non-testifying defendants coupled with other independent, competent and clearly admissible evidence was ample to sustain convictions and any spillover incrimination resulting from inculpation of defendant in confession of codefendants was merely cumulative, admission of such confessions in joint trial did not constitute reversible error. State v. Garcia, 240 So.2d 633 (1970), conformed to 244 So.2d 442, conformed to 244 So.2d 443. Criminal Law  1169.12

Admission of detailed confession which implicated defendant in crime of rape and which was signed by defendant rendered admission of statements made by codefendants in joint trial harmless error. Jones v. State, App. 4 Dist., 227 So.2d 326 (1969), certiorari dismissed 237 So.2d 533. Criminal Law  1169.12

Admission into evidence of first defendant's confession which implicated second defendant was reversible error even though jury was instructed on three occasions during trial that jury must disregard any reference made by first defendant in his confession to second defendant. Branch v. State, App. 2 Dist., 212 So.2d 29 (1968). Criminal Law  1169.12

head.head.info: 174. ---- Custodial interrogation, confessions, criminal cases

para.paratext: Error, of any, in admission of postindictment, pretrial confession obtained by a police officer who posed as fellow prisoner confined in cell with petitioner was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt, where jury, in addition to hearing challenged testimony, was presented with overwhelming evidence of petitioner's guilt, including no less than three full confessions made by petitioner prior to his indictment. Milton v. Wainwright, U.S.Fla.1972, 92 S.Ct. 2174, 407 U.S. 371, 33 L.Ed.2d 1. Criminal Law  1169.12

Admission of defendant's confession made at time he was apprehended and shortly thereafter to police officers was harmless error where overwhelming, independent testimony established that defendant did kill the victim. Blatch v. State, App. 3 Dist., 216 So.2d 261 (1968), certiorari dismissed 225 So.2d 532. Criminal Law  1169.12

Where oral and written confessions were both made at jail soon after arrest of accused, and proper investigation was made in absence of jury before written confession was introduced, that oral confession, which was substantially identical to the written one, was admitted without investigation in absence of jury to determine its admissibility, could amount to nothing more than harmless error. Finley v. State, 153 Fla. 394, 14 So.2d 844 (1943). Criminal Law  1169.12

head.head.info: 175. ---- Former trial, confessions, criminal cases

para.paratext: Since only death or life imprisonment were available upon defendant's plea of guilty to first-degree murder, defendant was not prejudiced by admission in evidence, at hearing to determine punishment, of his confession at former trial, where the court imposed the lesser punishment. Zuniga v. State, App. 1 Dist., 184 So.2d 659 (1966), certiorari dismissed 189 So.2d 635, certiorari denied 87 S.Ct. 404, 385 U.S. 962, 17 L.Ed.2d 307. Criminal Law  1169.12

head.head.info: 176. ---- Foundation for admission, confessions, criminal cases

para.paratext: Generally, before evidence of a defendant's confession or admission can be admitted, the state must independently establish prima facie evidence that each element of the offense occurred through the criminal agency of a person. Williams v. State, App. 2 Dist., 901 So.2d 357 (2005). Criminal Law  413.73; Criminal Law  413.79; Criminal Law  413.80

A trial court should not permit the introduction of a defendant's confession until sufficient proof of the corpus delicti is first given; but if the confession be admitted without such proof, and additional evidence upon that subject is afterwards introduced, independent of the confession, which would have justified the admission thereof, the error is cured. Anthony v. State, 44 Fla. 1, 32 So. 818 (1902). Criminal Law  1169.12

head.head.info: 177. ---- Miranda warnings, confessions, criminal cases

para.paratext: Suppression of inmate's second confession to murdering another inmate was not required, though inmate had not been brought before judicial officer within 24 hours of his alleged de facto “arrest” relating to being removed from open population at prison and being taken to higher-security prison; inmate was repeatedly advised of his Miranda rights, he would not have been subject to release because of his prior convictions, he did not invoke his right to counsel, and he had made his first confession within 24 hours of alleged de facto arrest. Globe v. State, 877 So.2d 663 (2004), rehearing denied. Criminal Law  413.16

Where record showed that defendant was read his rights and that he signed document stating that he was advised of his rights and that he understood them, and where there was no evidence adduced which amounted to a charge of coercion, the trial court committed, at most, harmless error in failing to make an express finding as to voluntariness of defendant's confession. Walker v. State, App. 3 Dist., 319 So.2d 642 (1975). Criminal Law  1169.12

Admission of confession not procured in compliance with Miranda was fundamental error requiring reversal, even though confession was made prior to Miranda and there was substantial evidence of guilt even without the inadmissible confession, where trial was held subsequent to Miranda. Ard v. State, App. 4 Dist., 233 So.2d 439 (1970), certiorari denied 238 So.2d 108. Courts  100(1); Criminal Law  1169.12

Where defendant's confession was obtained before date of Miranda decision, but his trial was subsequent to that date, and where it clearly appeared that exactions of Miranda were not met and that defendant's rights were thereby prejudiced, defendant's conviction would be reversed. Glover v. State, App. 4 Dist., 203 So.2d 676 (1967). Criminal Law  1169.12

Where accuseds were advised of right to counsel and right to remain silent when interrogated, did not request counsel and were not denied counsel, admission of written confession found to be voluntary and of oral admissions was not reversible error. Watson v. State, 190 So.2d 161 (1966), certiorari denied 88 S.Ct. 339, 389 U.S. 960, 19 L.Ed.2d 369. Criminal Law  1169.12

Where state attorney gave defendant information as to his rights as required by statute when defendant was brought before committing magistrate, though statute required magistrate to give such information, but defendant was fully advised of his rights, error in admission of confession made when brought before magistrate was technical and harmless. Ezzell v. State, 88 So.2d 280 (1956). Criminal Law  1169.12

head.head.info: 178. ---- Motion to suppress, confessions, criminal cases

para.paratext: No reversible error appeared in relation to denial of motion to suppress confession and in-court identification of defendant who was convicted of forgery and of buying, receiving or concealing stolen property. Gould v. State, App. 3 Dist., 318 So.2d 522 (1975). Criminal Law  1169.1(5); Criminal Law  1169.12

head.head.info: 179. ---- Voluntariness, confessions, criminal cases

para.paratext: When trial judge admits into evidence a statement or confession to which there has been an objection, on review the record must reflect with unmistakable clarity that the judge found that the statement or confession was, by the preponderance of the evidence, voluntary. Dillow v. State, App. 2 Dist., 884 So.2d 508 (2004). Criminal Law  1086.11

Defendant's denial of knowledge of murder weapon found near him at time of arrest was not a confession required to be tested by its voluntariness, but, even if it had been, in view of evidence against defendant, fingerprints on weapon and eyewitness' identification, failure to make specific findings of voluntariness was, at most, harmless error. Ballard v. State, App. 3 Dist., 323 So.2d 297 (1975). Criminal Law  1169.12

Conduct on the part of any government agent in obtaining postindictment confessions by tricks, coercion, force, overreaching, guile, subterfuge, or entrapment is violative of constitutional rights and will result in reversal of conviction. Sikes v. State, App. 2 Dist., 313 So.2d 436 (1975), dismissed 322 So.2d 919. Criminal Law  411.49; Criminal Law  411.51; Criminal Law  411.60; Criminal Law  1169.12

In absence of any evidence or contention of coercion and in view of total record indicating that trial court had in fact determined that confession was voluntary, failure of trial court to spell out with unmistakable clarity in its ruling admitting confession that it was voluntary was, at most, harmless error. Bunch v. State, App. 1 Dist., 303 So.2d 705 (1974), certiorari denied 314 So.2d 778. Criminal Law  1169.12

If totality of circumstances indicated that confession resulted from coercive effect on defendant's will, denial of suppression of confession would require reversal of conviction. Davis v. State, App. 1 Dist., 275 So.2d 575 (1973), certiorari denied 280 So.2d 684. Criminal Law  1169.12

Admission of confession apparently obtained by police after first duly warning defendant of constitutional rights to remain silent and to have assistance of counsel and which trial judge out of presence of jury found to have been freely and voluntarily given was not harmful or prejudicial error. McClendon v. State, 196 So.2d 905 (1967). Criminal Law  1169.12

Absent showing that delay in presentment before a committing magistrate induced defendant's confession, failure to take the prisoner before a committing magistrate prior to obtaining a confession is not reversible error. Nixon v. State, App. 3 Dist., 178 So.2d 620 (1965), certiorari denied 87 S.Ct. 97, 385 U.S. 853, 17 L.Ed.2d 81. Criminal Law  1169.12

Despite the fact that corroborating evidence points clearly to guilt of accused, impermissibly extracted confession will require reversal if it is allowed as link in chain of evidence. Reddish v. State, 167 So.2d 858 (1964). Criminal Law  1169.12

In prosecution for first-degree murder, admission into evidence of purported confession that was unsigned, unsworn and unapproved by defendant was harmless in view of fact that on record as a whole jury could have concluded guilt of defendant without considering confession and it was not contended that confession was involuntary or that it did not speak the truth. Coggins v. State, App. 3 Dist., 101 So.2d 400 (1958). Criminal Law  1169.12

Where confession of murder was obtained from defendant after more than 10 hours of continuous and incessant examination by officers, defendant during course of examination was taken to view body of victim, and defendant's mother was brought to the police station and defendant questioned in her presence, confession was not free and voluntary, and its admission constituted prejudicial error as compelling defendant to testify against himself. Williams v. State, 156 Fla. 300, 22 So.2d 821 (1945). Criminal Law  411.47; Criminal Law  1169.12

head.head.info: 180. Other offenses, criminal cases--In general

para.paratext: Hearsay evidence indicating the accused is guilty of the crime is far more egregious and harmful than the admission of material directed to an unrelated collateral wrong. Neeley v. State, App. 1 Dist., 883 So.2d 861 (2004). Criminal Law  1169.1(9); Criminal Law  1169.11

If separate offense is relevant and has probative value in proof of any issue in case on trial, evidence of commission of separate criminal offense is admissible, but if the evidence of the commission of another crime has as its sole relevancy the bad character or propensity of accused to commit a crime, it is reversible error for such evidence to be admitted and considered by the jury. Randall v. State, App. 2 Dist., 239 So.2d 81 (1970). Criminal Law  368.5; Criminal Law  368.9; Criminal Law  1169.11

Generally, it is harmful to admit evidence of other or collateral crimes independent of and unconnected with the crime for which defendant is on trial. Kennedy v. State, 140 Fla. 124, 191 So. 193 (1939). Criminal Law  1169.11

Generally, admitting evidence of crimes collateral to, or other than, and independent of, and unconnected with, offense for which accused is on trial, is harmful error. Nickels v. State, 90 Fla. 659, 106 So. 479 (1925). Criminal Law  1169.11

head.head.info: 181. ---- Accomplices and co-defendants, other offenses, criminal cases

para.paratext: Weighing together all of the circumstances, including the evidence and instructions given, any error in admission of testimony of undercover agent that after he bought the heroin from defendant he made another drug purchase of cocaine from codefendant who had been introduced to agent by defendant was harmless beyond reasonable doubt in prosecution of defendant for possession with intent to distribute and for distribution of heroin. U. S. v. Bell, 1975, 510 F.2d 1095. Criminal Law  1169.11

Where defendant's objection to questioning of one defendant in joint trial concerning prior conviction was sustained by trial court and defendants refused offer of judge to instruct jury to disregard that testimony, there was no prejudicial error. Slaughter v. State, 301 So.2d 762 (1974), certiorari denied 95 S.Ct. 1448, 420 U.S. 1005, 43 L.Ed.2d 763. Criminal Law  1169.5(3)

Witness was properly allowed to testify that two men beat her on March 22, and that she recognized the voice of one of them as that of one of two men who committed various crimes in her apartment on March 4 where the testimony was relevant to establish guilt of defendant's codefendant as to the March 4 offenses and defendant was not in any way prejudiced because he was in jail when the beating occurred. Tafero v. State, App. 3 Dist., 223 So.2d 564 (1969), certiorari denied 225 So.2d 912. Criminal Law  1169.11

head.head.info: 182. ---- Arrests, other offenses, criminal cases

para.paratext: Admission of collection of police photographs from which defendant's picture had been selected by witnesses constituted harmless error in view of identification of defendant by three witnesses in lineup and in court and defendant's own incriminating statement. U. S. v. Sawyer, 1974, 504 F.2d 878, certiorari denied 95 S.Ct. 1578, 421 U.S. 916, 43 L.Ed.2d 783. Criminal Law  1169.11

Fact that police officer, testifying as state witness, in answer to question on cross-examination as to basis for arresting defendant on check charge, stated that “I showed mug shots to the complainant on this case, and he identified that (defendant) as being the one that cashed that check,” did not warrant reversal on theory that statement implied that defendant was a criminal and that its sole thrust was at character and propensity of defendant. Anderson v. State, App. 2 Dist., 230 So.2d 704 (1970). Criminal Law  1169.11
Under circumstances, officer's reference to defendant's “arrest slips” did not prejudice defendant. Rhome v. State, App. 3 Dist., 222 So.2d 431 (1969). Criminal Law  1169.11

head.head.info: 183. ---- Confessions, other offenses, criminal cases

para.paratext: Reading of entire purported confession without deletion of portions referring to prior criminal entanglements was reversible error. Minturn v. State, App. 3 Dist., 136 So.2d 359 (1962). Criminal Law  368.16; Criminal Law  1169.11

head.head.info: 184. ---- Connection and relationship of crimes, other offenses, criminal cases

para.paratext: Where criminal acts which were not alleged in indictment charging conspiracy to manufacture and use destructive devices were closely connected in time and nature to the overt acts alleged in the indictment, their admission into evidence was not reversible error. U. S. v. Evans, 1976, 526 F.2d 701, rehearing denied 529 F.2d 523, certiorari denied 97 S.Ct. 62, 429 U.S. 818, 50 L.Ed.2d 78, rehearing denied 97 S.Ct. 509, 429 U.S. 987, 50 L.Ed.2d 599. Criminal Law  1169.11

Where connection between charged crime, of conspiring to conceal material facts in effort to defraud Immigration and Naturalization Service, and alleged extortion effort by defendants in connection with threat of releasing embarrassing photographs of unrelated person was tenuous at best, and where prejudicial effect of testimony, which related the alleged extortion attempt and which was admitted under similar acts doctrine to establish requisite intent to defraud United States, outweighted any proper benefit to prosecution, admission of such testimony was abuse of discretion and required reversal of subject convictions. U. S. v. Kasouris, 1973, 474 F.2d 689. Criminal Law  371.37; Criminal Law  371.38; Criminal Law  1169.11

Allowance, in murder prosecution, of testimony and photographs depicting criminal acts of buggery upon two-year-old victim, who died as result of head or brain injury, was reversible error, where defendant had not been connected with such acts. Saxon v. State, App. 4 Dist., 225 So.2d 925 (1969). Criminal Law  368.55; Criminal Law  1169.11

head.head.info: 185. ---- Cumulative evidence, other offenses, criminal cases

para.paratext: Reference in police officer's testimony to mug shots did not constitute reversible error where guilt of accused was conclusively established by positive in-court identification of defendant by victim and by police officer who apprehended him at the scene, and where, in addition, testimony of officer relating to identification of defendant by photograph represented cumulative evidence. Williams v. State, App. 3 Dist., 233 So.2d 428 (1970). Criminal Law  1169.2(3)

head.head.info: 186. ---- Evidence introduced by accused, other offenses, criminal cases

para.paratext: In light of fact that defendant himself introduced tape recording that included a clear inference that defendant had been imprisoned, defendant's substantial right were not affected by voluntary statement of witness indicating that defendant had been on probation; nor were substantial rights of codefendant violated by such statement. U. S. v. Nakaladski, 1973, 481 F.2d 289, certiorari denied 94 S.Ct. 570, 414 U.S. 1064, 38 L.Ed.2d 469. Criminal Law  1169.2(3)

Error, if any, in allowing prosecution to question witness as to whether defendant had in effect stated after the events involved that if he had to return to Raiford there would be some funerals or a funeral before he went was rendered harmless by defendant's testimony that he had never been to Raiford or sentenced to serve a term there. Luke v. State, App. 4 Dist., 204 So.2d 359 (1967), certiorari denied 210 So.2d 223, certiorari denied 89 S.Ct. 290, 393 U.S. 932, 21 L.Ed.2d 269. Criminal Law  1169.11

In a prosecution for breaking and entering with intent to commit grand larceny, of defendant in whose attic the stolen goods were found concealed, along with goods stolen elsewhere, admission of evidence about the other stolen property, which was linked by defendant with property stolen from building broken and entered when he undertook to explain his possession of the whole, was not reversible error. Tavalaccio v. State, 59 So.2d 247 (1952). Criminal Law  1169.11

head.head.info: 187. ---- Foundation or predicate, other offenses, criminal cases

para.paratext: Introduction on rebuttal of evidence of other unrelated crimes when no predicate for the introduction of the evidence was laid during defendant's case, thereby focusing the trial on defendant's character, general reputation and propensity to engage in criminal activities, constituted reversible error. Reyes v. State, App. 1 Dist., 253 So.2d 907 (1971). Criminal Law  683(1); Criminal Law  1168(2)

head.head.info: 188. ---- Identity, intent, motive or course of conduct, other offenses, criminal cases

para.paratext: Testimony of sales of counterfeit obligations other than those counterfeit obligations which were the subject matter of the counts of the indictment was not prejudicial; such testimony was admissible to show intent, preparation, or plans relating to a charge of conspiracy and to show a common scheme, plan, design, or intent.
