U. S. v. Banks, 1972, 465 F.2d 1235, certiorari denied 93 S.Ct. 568, 409 U.S. 1062, 34 L.Ed.2d 514. Criminal Law  368.20; Criminal Law  373.12; Criminal Law  1169.11

In prosecution for failure to pay federal cabaret excise tax, errors or near errors in admitting contracts of musicians who had played at defendant's establishment to prove existence of “cabaret,” charts drawn by government agent based on defendant's sales figures to demonstrate that certain sales were subject to tax, and cabaret tax returns and Florida sales tax returns for periods immediately preceding and following period covered by indictment to demonstrate pattern of fraudulent conduct, required that very close case be reversed and remanded for new trial. Baines v. U. S., 1970, 426 F.2d 833. Criminal Law  1169.1(10); Criminal Law  1169.11

Previous homosexual encounter between defendant and intoxicated adult merely showed had character of defendant and his propensity to commit homosexual act and was so dissimilar to charge that defendant approached 12-year-old child, lured him to secluded area, suggested homosexual acts, and twice grabbed child's leg before he got away, that evidence of prior offense did not tend to prove motive, intent, absence of mistake, identity or common scheme or design, and thus admission of testimony concerning prior offense in prosecution for commission of lewd and lascivious act constituted reversible error. Clingan v. State, App. 2 Dist., 317 So.2d 863 (1975). Criminal Law  368.63; Criminal Law  373.10; Criminal Law  1169.11

Even though, in prosecution for murder of informer in case involving stolen securities, some reference to defendant's alleged involvement in the securities case was essential to establish defendant's motive for killing the informer and to enable State to intelligently present case, detailed testimony concerning actual modus operandi of earlier offense, of which defendant was acquitted, and of defendant's role in its commission was irrelevant and was prejudicial to defendant. Lawson v. State, App. 3 Dist., 304 So.2d 522 (1974), certiorari denied 315 So.2d 181. Criminal Law  371.13; Criminal Law  373.29; Criminal Law  1169.11; Homicide  1002

Admission, in aggravated assault prosecution of defendant for forcing female victim to submit to copulation per anus, of testimony of 17-year-old boy who three years prior had been forced by defendant to submit to copulation per anus, sought to be sustained on theory that it was relevant to issue of identification in that it tended to show a modus operandi, was reversible error where the sole similarity in the two offenses was the copulation per anus itself. Braen v. State, App. 2 Dist., 302 So.2d 485 (1974). Criminal Law  373.15; Criminal Law  1169.11

Although evidence of other similar offenses by defendant charged with committing a sexual assault upon his 13-year-old adopted daughter by fondling her in a certain lewd and lascivious manner was not admissible to show a continuing course of conduct, a plan or scheme or a modus operandi, error in admitting the evidence was harmless since such evidence would have been admissible in rebuttal of defendant's defense of impotency. Duncan v. State, App. 2 Dist., 291 So.2d 241 (1974), certiorari denied 297 So.2d 833. Criminal Law  1169.11

Admission of evidence relating to other criminal activity was reversible error where only common denominator between crime for which defendant was being charged and prior offense was that both incidents were robberies allegedly committed by defendant and an accomplice with a gun during the evening; reversal was required since State had failed to demonstrate that the prior act fell into any of the familiar categories such as proof of identity, motive, pattern or intent, or common scheme or design and was not introduced solely for purpose of showing propensity or bad character. Marion v. State, App. 4 Dist., 283 So.2d 53 (1973), certiorari denied 287 So.2d 690. Criminal Law  368.62; Criminal Law  373.12; Criminal Law  1169.11

Where after State had adduced sufficient proof that defendant robbed employee of cleaning establishment, in prosecution for such robbery, State went further and proved that food store had also been robbed and furnished testimony from which jury might have believed that defendant robbed food store, and where there was no general pattern but two separate and distinct crimes without common element, admission of testimony as to food store robbery was reversible error. Davis v. State, App. 2 Dist., 276 So.2d 846 (1973), affirmed 290 So.2d 30. Criminal Law  368.62; Criminal Law  1169.11

Prior crimes allegedly committed by defendant by breaking into offices of professional men, stealing files and other property and telephoning victims who then ransomed the stolen property for a sum of money involved a completely different modus operandi from telephoning a retail store and threatening to bomb them during business hours unless paid a sum of money, so that admission of evidence of prior crimes in prosecution for unlawfully threatening to throw, place or discharge deadly explosives and extortion arising out of threat to bomb retail store was reversible error. Steppe v. State, App. 3 Dist., 193 So.2d 617 (1967). Criminal Law  373.15; Criminal Law  1169.11

Admitting evidence that during the period of a few days immediately preceding and following commission of alleged rape for which defendant was on trial he attacked four other women in the same area, using similar method of approach, was not reversible error, where consideration of such evidence was limited to question of defendant's identity and plan or design. Talley v. State, 160 Fla. 593, 36 So.2d 201 (1948). Criminal Law  1169.11

head.head.info: 189. ---- Impeachment, other offenses, criminal cases

para.paratext: Admission of corporate income tax returns and personal returns of defendant on theory that they tended to impeach credibility of defendant, charged with attempting to bribe internal revenue agent was reversible error where returns, together with evidence relating to them, had tendency to prove that defendant had filed false returns, another and different crime than one laid in indictment. Marko v. U. S., 1963, 314 F.2d 595. Criminal Law  368.35; Criminal Law  1169.11

head.head.info: 190. ---- Instructions, other offenses, criminal cases

para.paratext: Defendant who was charged with conspiring to bring into the United States by means of a vessel a number of illegal aliens was not prejudiced by testimony of witness that defendant had brought aliens to ship in Nassau at times prior to dates alleged in indictment where court gave cautionary instruction on such testimony to jury and evidence of defendant's guilt was overwhelming. U. S. v. Boerner, 1975, 508 F.2d 1064, certiorari denied 95 S.Ct. 2418, 421 U.S. 1013, 44 L.Ed.2d 681, certiorari denied 95 S.Ct. 2419, 421 U.S. 1013, 44 L.Ed.2d 681. Criminal Law  1169.5(3)

Fact that, on cross-examination, defendant was required to give information concerning a prior felony conviction for illegal transportation of aliens did not require reversal, where jury was instructed that evidence of defendant's prior conviction was to be considered only insofar as it might affect credibility of defendant as a witness and could not be considered as evidence of guilt of crime for which defendant was on trial. U. S. v. Rodriguez-Hernandez, 1974, 493 F.2d 168, certiorari denied 95 S.Ct. 2678, 422 U.S. 1056, 45 L.Ed.2d 708. Criminal Law  1169.5(3)

Admission, in Dyer Act prosecution, of evidence regarding stolen drill and unreturned rented tow bar found in vehicle in question was error, but was harmless and in no event did it rise to level of plain error, where such evidence came into case in nature of an inadvertent statement and witness was foreclosed by prosecutor from giving further testimony of such nature, and where there was no objection to the testimony but the court, on its own motion, directed the jury in charge to give no consideration to the evidence. U. S. v. Hurst, 1974, 491 F.2d 1388, certiorari denied 95 S.Ct. 107, 419 U.S. 859, 42 L.Ed.2d 93. Criminal Law  368.57; Criminal Law  1036.1(8); Criminal Law  1169.5(3)

Where trial court asked each juror if he or she remembered examining exhibit containing inadmissible statement by defendant admitting that he had been previously arrested for carrying a concealed weapon and no one answered affirmatively and court then instructed jury to disregard anything that they might have seen on the exhibit in question, there was no error in either the procedure or court's conclusion that the trial process had not been irretrievably tainted, and defendant having made a conscious choice not to move for a mistrial might not on appeal complain of trial court's failure to declare one and, even if the set of circumstances constituted error, it was harmless beyond reasonable doubt. U. S. v. Calles, 1973, 482 F.2d 1155. Criminal Law  1044.1(5.1); Criminal Law  1169.1(10); Criminal Law  1169.5(3)

Where, after government witness testified District Court instructed jury to disregard any suggestion, implication or reference to possible previous criminal activities of defendant, admonition was sufficient to expunge any possible prejudice to defendant and error, if any, was harmless. Driver v. U. S., 1971, 441 F.2d 276. Criminal Law  1169.5(3)

In prosecution for willful failure to file income tax return in 1959 and for attempted evasion by filing a false income tax return in 1960, admission of evidence reflecting accused's failure to file in 1944-1959 did not require reversal of conviction for evasion on theory that such evidence prejudiced jury's consideration of his intent in 1960, where trial judge clearly instructed jury that this evidence related only to failure to file returns. U.S. v. Brook, 1969, 414 F.2d 804, certiorari denied 90 S.Ct. 756, 396 U.S. 1060, 24 L.Ed.2d 754. Criminal Law  1169.5(3)

Where trial court carefully instructed jury not to consider statement of witness that he arrested defendant out of state for shooting rural mail carrier, no reversible error resulted from such statement in defendant's prosecution for first-degree murder. Rivers v. State, 226 So.2d 337 (1969). Criminal Law  1169.5(3)

Officer's reference to “other circumstances” involving defendant did not require reversal where jury was instructed to disregard testimony. Rhome v. State, App. 3 Dist., 222 So.2d 431 (1969). Criminal Law  1169.5(3)

head.head.info: 191. ---- Objections and motions, other offenses, criminal cases

para.paratext: Defendant's failure to obtain ruling from trial court regarding his motion in limine to prohibit introduction of testimony of his drug sales to be presented to jury in prosecution for robbery, kidnapping, and aggravated battery, along with his failure to timely object at time testimony concerning his drug sales was introduced, effectively waived his objection on appeal. Tolbert v. State, App. 5 Dist., 922 So.2d 1013 (2006), rehearing denied, review denied 934 So.2d 451. Criminal Law  1036.1(8); Criminal Law  1045

Allegedly improper testimony relating to a previous offense did not require reversal of rape conviction where testimony concerning earlier offense was at most an unpretentious remark during trial, was objected to by counsel and sustained by the court. Fields v. State, 257 So.2d 241 (1971). Criminal Law  1169.5(3)

head.head.info: 192. ---- Particular cases, other offenses, criminal cases

para.paratext: The admission of testimony of friend of defendant accused of Dyer Act violation that defendant had stolen friend's gasoline credit card before leaving his home on what, within a reasonably short period thereafter, turned out to be the trip that took the automobile across state lines was not prejudicial error. Cade v. U. S., 1965, 351 F.2d 468. Criminal Law  1169.11

Police officer's improper testimony referring to defendant as robbery suspect in violation of pretrial order in limine was reversible error in prosecution for aggravated fleeing and eluding police officers, where it was unclear that the impact of testimony could not have affected jury's verdict of guilt. Woods v. State, App. 4 Dist., 905 So.2d 246 (2005). Criminal Law  1166(1)

Defendant preserved for appeal the error in police officer's testimony referring to defendant as robbery suspect in violation of pretrial order in limine, even though defense counsel inexplicably failed to hear testimony and did not object at time of testimony, where counsel moved for mistrial as soon as he learned of testimony from defendant and before jury returned its verdict, in prosecution for aggravated fleeing and eluding police officers. Woods v. State, App. 4 Dist., 905 So.2d 246 (2005). Criminal Law  1044.2(1)

Admission of detective's testimony referencing discussion with defendant of “other cases pending” was not prejudicial error; defendant's statement was isolated, inadvertent, and not focused upon, State did not intentionally elicit information from detective, and error would have required no more than curative instruction, which was not requested. Levi v. State, App. 5 Dist., 867 So.2d 647 (2004). Criminal Law  1169.11

Where most that could be said was that all three robberies involved the robbery of retail establishments by a varying number of black persons, conviction of defendant for robbing of one of those establishments must be reversed because of introduction of evidence of defendant's participation in the other two robberies, but the other two cases were not tainted by the same error since there was no evidence of defendant's participation in other robberies introduced in those trials so that judgments of conviction as to those two robberies and for using firearm in commission of felony must be affirmed. Golphin v. State, App. 2 Dist., 293 So.2d 755 (1974). Criminal Law  1169.11

Error, if any, in receiving evidence to the effect that defendant, who was convicted of aggravated assault on a named victim had shot another person three hours prior to assault leading to his conviction did not injuriously affect substantial rights of defendant, and harmless error rule applied. Gordan v. State, App. 4 Dist., 288 So.2d 295 (1974), certiorari denied 293 So.2d 362. Criminal Law  1169.11

In prosecution on charge of carrying concealed weapon, introduction of evidence of similar prior occurrence required reversal. Rodriquez v. State, App. 2 Dist., 281 So.2d 921 (1973). Criminal Law  1169.11

Admission of testimony concerning two alleged acts of intercourse by father with daughter occurring some years prior to act of incest with which father was charged was not reversible error. Clark v. State, App. 1 Dist., 266 So.2d 687 (1972), certiorari denied 270 So.2d 21. Criminal Law  1169.11

Evidence of two subsequent sales of heroin made by defendant transformed trial from a “feature” to a sideshow and warranted a reversal. Denson v. State, App. 1 Dist., 264 So.2d 442 (1972). Criminal Law  368.47; Criminal Law  373.22; Criminal Law  1169.11

Even if admission, in prosecution for robbery of store, of testimony pertaining to robberies allegedly committed by defendant on day after store robbery was error, such was harmless, in view of eyewitness testimony of store's employee. Keel v. State, App. 4 Dist., 243 So.2d 630 (1971). Criminal Law  1169.11

Under information charging larceny of Ford coupé and receiving stolen property, admitting evidence of stealing other automobiles was reversible error. Suarez v. State, 95 Fla. 42, 115 So. 519 (1928). Criminal Law  1169.11

head.head.info: 193. ---- Prejudicial effect, other offenses, criminal cases

para.paratext: In prosecution for possession of television stolen from interstate or foreign shipment, trial court committed prejudicial error in permitting cross-examination of defense witnesses concerning alleged improper conduct on their part and on part of defendant involving 85 air conditioners, $4,000 in an envelope, pilot trucks, goods moved from one warehouse to another and activities of other individuals whose conduct was not validly related to defendant's guilt, in view of fact that such matters had not been raised on direct examination and notwithstanding contention that evidence was admissible to show similar identical crimes. U. S. v. Park, 1976, 525 F.2d 1279. Criminal Law  368.57; Criminal Law  1169.11

Where there was little, save defendant's presence approximately a block and a half from robbery scene and fact that the actual perpetrator of the robbery was the same in both crimes, to show that defendant had any responsibility for or participation in robbery of savings and loan association on the day preceding bank robbery, the evidence of defendant's presence near the robbery scene did not have sufficient probative value to outweigh the dangers of prejudice and the admission of the evidence of other crimes in prosecution for bank robbery and conspiracy to commit bank robbery was reversible error. U. S. v. Vosper, 1974, 493 F.2d 433. Criminal Law  373.17; Criminal Law  1169.11

Evidence of defendant's apparent possession or importation of marijuana offshore, nine months after defendant's alleged participation in conspiracy to import and importation of marijuana, was not shown to serve any proper judicial or prosecutorial function outweighing its prejudicial effect, and admission thereof constituted prejudicial error. U. S. v. Goodwin, 1974, 492 F.2d 1141. Criminal Law  368.47; Criminal Law  373.22; Criminal Law  1169.11

In prosecution for uttering of and dealing in counterfeit $20 federal reserve notes, admission of surprise testimony as to alleged transaction involving passing of counterfeit bills other than those referred to in indictment, and trial judge's damaging emphasis thereof by active and vigorous participation in examining one of the surprise witnesses, was reversible error. Riggs v. U.S., 1960, 280 F.2d 750. Criminal Law  368.48; Criminal Law  1169.11

In prosecution for uttering of and dealing in counterfeit $20 federal reserve notes, admission of evidence of finding of defendant guilty, in another case in which appeal was pending, without a showing of the nature of the offense of which he was found guilty, was reversible error. Riggs v. U.S., 1960, 280 F.2d 750. Criminal Law  368.48; Criminal Law  1169.11

In prosecution for aggravated assault arising out of domestic violence incident, defendant's former wife's nonresponsive answer to prosecutor's question, stating that defendant had been “sent back to prison,” erroneously implying that defendant had been sent to prison in connection with earlier domestic violence incident, was prejudicial error; cautionary instruction that nonresponsive statement was “beyond this witness's knowledge” could not ameliorate statement's prejudicial effect, evidence of prior criminal behavior cast doubt on defendant's claim of self-defense, and denial of motion for mistrial necessitated substantial shift in defense strategy, including exposing defendant to impeachment concerning his two prior felony convictions. Brooks v. State, App. 2 Dist., 868 So.2d 643 (2004). Criminal Law  368.44; Criminal Law  372.56; Criminal Law  1170.5(1)

In prosecution for fondling male under age of 14 years in lewd, lascivious and indecent manner, eliciting of testimony, which was to effect that accused had enticed 14-year-old boy into permitting accused to commit homosexual acts and which was used for singular purpose of proving bad character of accused and his propensity to commit homosexual act, was reversible error. Banks v. State, App. 1 Dist., 298 So.2d 543 (1974), certiorari denied 308 So.2d 538. Criminal Law  368.63; Criminal Law  1169.11
Where testimony as to another crime committed by defendant became feature of trial, conviction was properly reversed. State v. Davis, 290 So.2d 30 (1974). Criminal Law  1169.11

Admitting of testimony of two victims of other robberies which defendant had allegedly committed, where testimony presented jury with no additional information relevant to issue of defendant's participation in robbery in question, other than to show a propensity on part of defendant to commit robbery, was prejudicial error. Franklin v. State, App. 3 Dist., 229 So.2d 892 (1969), certiorari denied 237 So.2d 754. Criminal Law  368.62; Criminal Law  1169.11

Permitting second check, which was basis for second information filed against defendant and his codefendant, to be introduced in prosecution for embezzlement was prejudicial error inasmuch as latter check was not evidence of a crime. Mann v. State, App. 1 Dist., 209 So.2d 472 (1968), appeal dismissed 222 So.2d 744, certiorari denied 225 So.2d 524. Criminal Law  368.31; Criminal Law  1169.11

In prosecutions for subornation of perjury, trial court committed prejudicial error in allowing into evidence a copy of an indictment filed by the grand jury indicting defendants for violations of the election law, in view of fact such evidence could serve no genuine purpose other than to convey to the jury fact that grand jury had deliberated and concluded that defendant was guilty of violations of the election law, an offense unrelated to the charge of subornation of perjury for which defendants were being tried. Gordon v. State, 104 So.2d 524 (1958). Criminal Law  368.35; Criminal Law  1169.11

In prosecution for conducting lottery, admission, over defendant's objection, of affidavit and warrant for defendant's arrest on charge of another offense, committed prior to date of offense on which instant prosecution was based, was error with prejudice. Adams v. State, 153 Fla. 68, 13 So.2d 610 (1943). Criminal Law  368.53; Criminal Law  1169.11
Permitting state to introduce evidence, over objection, to prove crime other than charged in indictment, was reversible error. Hood v. State, 95 Fla. 767, 116 So. 647 (1928). Criminal Law  1169.11

head.head.info: 194. ---- Prisoner status of accused, other offenses, criminal cases

para.paratext: Use of such words as “jail,” “prison,” “arrest,” where irrelevant, are generally to be avoided by a witness in testifying as to whereabouts of defendant during a certain period, but mere utterance of the word does not, without regard to context or circumstance, constitute reversible error per se. U. S. v. Barcenas, 1974, 498 F.2d 1110, certiorari denied 95 S.Ct. 521, 419 U.S. 1036, 42 L.Ed.2d 312. Criminal Law  1169.11

Where defendant did not take witness stand in prosecution under Dyer Act and his character was not put in issue on trial, admission by trial court over strenuous objection each time it was offered of testimony that defendant had escaped from a penal institution the day before leaving on interstate drive in stolen automobile was prejudicial error. U. S. v. Stallings, 1971, 437 F.2d 1057. Criminal Law  368.57; Criminal Law  1169.11

Reference in testimony of witness at trial that present status of incarceration of defendant was for a previously committed robbery was not reversible error, where, when crime for which trial was being conducted was committed, defendant was serving sentence in work camp from which he was furloughed on weekends, defendant had brought out fact of his incarceration status and evidence as to nature of crime for which defendant was so imprisoned was elicited by State from defendant's witness on cross-examination and was not made basis for objection or motion to strike. Breedlove v. State, App. 3 Dist., 295 So.2d 654 (1974), certiorari denied 302 So.2d 761. Criminal Law  1169.11

Even if disclosure in evidence of defendant's status as inmate of prison camp was improper in prosecution for possession of marijuana and heroin, such disclosure was harmless error in view of direct and uncontradicted evidence of guilt. Taylor v. State, App. 3 Dist., 289 So.2d 421 (1974). Criminal Law  1169.11

head.head.info: 195. ---- Quantum of evidence received, other offenses, criminal cases

para.paratext: Erroneous admission of nondebtor's testimony as to a threat made by defendant to her in dispute over legal automobile sale was harmless error and did not require reversal of defendant's convictions for violations of the Extortionate Credit Transactions Act, where Government had proved its case completely without such witness' testimony on this incident. U. S. v. Bowdach, 1974, 501 F.2d 220, certiorari denied 95 S.Ct. 1331, 420 U.S. 948, 43 L.Ed.2d 426. Criminal Law  1169.11

Even though curative instructions, promised after a government witness gave testimony suggesting that defendant dealt in stolen guns and participated in unlawful alteration of semiautomatic weapons to fully automatic ones, were not given, error, if any, was harmless, where no prejudice resulted in anywise affecting jury verdict finding defendant guilty of selling firearms to nonresidents and of failing to keep appropriate firearms transaction records, and evidence of defendant's guilt was strong, clear and convincing beyond question. U. S. v. Resnick, 1974, 488 F.2d 1165, certiorari denied 94 S.Ct. 2400, 416 U.S. 991, 40 L.Ed.2d 769. Criminal Law  1169.11

In prosecution for willful failure to file income tax return in 1959, admission of testimony concerning accused's failure to file income tax returns in the years 1944-1950 and his living expenses during that period was erroneous, but, in view of other evidence, this error did not so affect jury's verdict as to require reversal. U.S. v. Brook, 1969, 414 F.2d 804, certiorari denied 90 S.Ct. 756, 396 U.S. 1060, 24 L.Ed.2d 754. Criminal Law  368.38; Criminal Law  1169.11

In prosecution for assault with intent to murder in the first degree, evidence of shooting incident which involved same victim and which occurred nearly three months prior to crime charged was incident rather than feature of trial where so far as quantum of evidence received on incident was concerned, such quantum was grossly aggravated by defendant's liberal and extensive exercise of right to cross-examine State's witnesses concerning such incident. Blackburn v. State, App. 4 Dist., 314 So.2d 634 (1975), certiorari denied 334 So.2d 603, certiorari denied 97 S.Ct. 170, 429 U.S. 864, 50 L.Ed.2d 142, rehearing denied 97 S.Ct. 342, 429 U.S. 933, 50 L.Ed.2d 303. Criminal Law  1169.11

Where, in face of other evidence, improperly admitted parking tickets faded almost into total obscurity, their improper admission was not reversible error. Dornau v. State, App. 2 Dist., 306 So.2d 167 (1974), certiorari denied 95 S.Ct. 2636, 422 U.S. 1011, 45 L.Ed.2d 675. Criminal Law  1169.11

Regardless of whether defendant, charged with uttering one forged check, was prejudiced by proof that he uttered three, and regardless of the fact that the prosecutor's continued reference to defendant's failure to discuss the case with a police officer was erroneous, the guilt of defendant appeared beyond any reasonable doubt, even after excluding all the evidence alleged to be improper, thus rendering any error harmless. Williams v. State, App. 2 Dist., 291 So.2d 240 (1973), certiorari denied 297 So.2d 838. Criminal Law  1169.11; Criminal Law  1171.6

Where testimony of deaf-mute through interpreter, that defendant had abducted and raped her on night previous to rapes for which defendant was being tried did not become feature of trial but was incidental to trial and testimony was not in and of itself inflammatory, admission of the testimony was not prejudicial. Hines v. State, App. 2 Dist., 243 So.2d 434 (1971). Criminal Law  1169.11

Testimony by female witness to effect that witness and defendant were lovers and that defendant allegedly made incriminating statements in her presence concerning death of his wife was irrelevant but its admission was not reversible error since jury, who returned verdict of second-degree murder, could reasonably have found defendant guilty of first-degree murder, testimony was not unduly emphasized, and jury was not likely to conclude from defendant's commission of fornication that he was likely to commit murder. Coppolino v. State, App. 2 Dist., 223 So.2d 68 (1968), appeal dismissed 234 So.2d 120, certiorari denied 90 S.Ct. 2242, 399 U.S. 927, 26 L.Ed.2d 794. Criminal Law  1169.11

head.head.info: 196. ---- Striking out, other offenses, criminal cases

para.paratext: Remedial action of trial judge in striking the inadmissible, gratuitous remarks of reputation witness and admonishing jury to disregard remarks was adequate, and no prejudice accrued to defendant with respect to whom there was evidence of two prior felony convictions as well as his admissions of other criminal activity. Baxter v. State, App. 4 Dist., 294 So.2d 392 (1974), certiorari denied 303 So.2d 26, certiorari denied 95 S.Ct. 1412, 420 U.S. 981, 43 L.Ed.2d 664. Criminal Law  1169.5(3)

Where officer testified that defendant had been involved in a same type incident previously and trial judge immediately granted motion to strike testimony and advised jury to disregard it, substantial rights of defendant, charged with throwing deadly weapon at an occupied vehicle, had not been injuriously affected. Monroe v. State, App. 2 Dist., 218 So.2d 209 (1969). Criminal Law  1169.5(3)

State witness' referring to pictures used for identification of defendant as “mug shots” during cross-examination when he was being pressed by defendant's attorney to restate an answer did not warrant reversal, especially where judge immediately ordered answer stricken and instructed jury to disregard it. Gagnon v. State, App. 3 Dist., 212 So.2d 337 (1968). Criminal Law  1169.5(3)

head.head.info: 197. ---- Waiver, other offenses, criminal cases

para.paratext: In prosecution of defendants for using mails and interstate telephones to defraud insurance companies by obtaining collision or liability insurance on automobiles and collecting on staged or faked automobile collisions, where trial court on direct examination had ruled that accidents not covered by indictment were inadmissible but allowed government to cross-examine defendants as to accidents which were not covered by indictment, prejudicial error occurred since each defendant had a constitutional right not to be a witness against himself and knew that when he took the stand his voluntary offer of testimony was a waiver thereof, but waiver was restricted to relevant facts and each had a right to believe that evidence as to other accidents was not relevant. Belvin v. U.S., 1960, 273 F.2d 583. Criminal Law  1169.11; Witnesses  301; Witnesses  305(2)

head.head.info: 198. Objections and motions, generally, criminal cases

para.paratext: State waived any supposed defect in habeas petitioner's proffer of witness's testimony, where state lodged no objection to proffer at trial, prosecution's appellate brief in state's district court of appeal included no objection to proffer, and no earlier paper in federal habeas corpus case preserved any objection to sufficiency of proffer. Johnson v. Moore, M.D.Fla.2007, 493 F.Supp.2d 1236. Habeas Corpus  816; Habeas Corpus  824

Defendant was not required to renew objection at trial to preserve for appeal claim that trial court erred in granting state's motion in limine to admit certain evidence, where trial court made a definitive ruling on the record admitting the evidence, and damage of exposing the jury to the evidence began with the opening statement, where no curative instruction was allowed. Tillman v. State, App. 4 Dist., 964 So.2d 785 (2007). Criminal Law  1043(1)

Defendant failed to preserve challenge to alleged refusal to permit cross-examination of victim concerning probationary status at time of the charged aggravated assault; record was unclear that defendant was attempting to establish victim's probation at time of the charged incident and motive to lie in order to curry favor with State, and defendant failed to make clear offer of proof of intent to establish the probation and the motive to lie. Strapp v. State, App. 3 Dist., 588 So.2d 27 (1991). Criminal Law  1036.2

Defendant's general objection to testimony by mother and stepfather of child victim in prosecution of defendant for sexual battery and simply battery sufficiently preserved issue of admissibility for review. Reyes v. State, App. 3 Dist., 580 So.2d 309 (1991). Criminal Law  1043(2)

In prosecution for first-degree murder, testimony that witness knocked on defendant's door and was greeted by shotgun, in response to defense counsel's question concerning witness' knowledge of secret knock to gain access to defendant's apartment, which statement defense counsel made no motion to have stricken, though it was somewhat unresponsive, could not be challenged for first time on appeal. Herzog v. State, 439 So.2d 1372 (1983). Criminal Law  1044.1(5.1)

Where defendant's living quarters in rear of shoe store were not disconnected or separated from store by a door or other closure and arresting officers observed defendant from the front of the store, arrest of defendant in his living quarters was lawful and trial court did not commit reversible error in prosecution for possession of marijuana by denying defendant's motion to suppress marijuana seized as result of search of the area. Hutchinson v. State, App. 3 Dist., 201 So.2d 485 (1967). Arrest  68.2(1); Arrest  71.1(7); Criminal Law  1168(4)

Trial court's failure to hear defendants' motion to suppress evidence prior to trial on merits was not reversible error, in absence of prejudice being demonstrated. Wells v. State, App. 3 Dist., 168 So.2d 787 (1964), certiorari denied 177 So.2d 12. Criminal Law  1169.1(8)

Error, if any, in denying appellant's shot gun motion for directed verdict at close of state's case, with respect to some counts, was harmless for failure to injuriously affect substantial rights of appellant whose identity was sufficiently established under the whole evidence. Bullard v. State, App. 1 Dist., 151 So.2d 343 (1963), certiorari denied 84 S.Ct. 1915, 377 U.S. 992, 12 L.Ed.2d 1044, rehearing denied 85 S.Ct. 19, 379 U.S. 872, 13 L.Ed.2d 78. Criminal Law  1168(1)

Even if trial court erred, at conclusion of state's case, in refusing to direct verdict where motion therefor was made on grounds that state had failed to prove venue, such error was harmless were defendant was thereafter put on stand and he admitted that the acts complained of occurred in the county of prosecution. Kozakoff v. State, App. 2 Dist., 104 So.2d 59 (1958). Criminal Law  1168(1)
Use of an inapt word by the court in sustaining objection to a question was harmless. Blackwell v. State, 69 Fla. 453, 68 So. 479 (1915). Criminal Law  1168(2)

head.head.info: 199. Motion for mistrial, criminal cases

para.paratext: Where District Court overruled motion to strike testimony concerning illicit liquor transactions between witness and accused which occurred several years before date of alleged conspiracy to violate revenue laws relating to intoxicating liquors, and no motion for mistrial was made, instruction that, in determining accused's guilt, jury should disregard any evidence concerning transactions of accused prior to period covered in indictment, granted to accused only relief to which he would have been entitled if motion had been sustained, and overruling of motion was not prejudicial. Heflin v. U.S., 1943, 132 F.2d 907. Criminal Law  1168(4)

Trial court did not abuse its discretion in denying defendant's motions for mistrial after the State, through two separate witnesses, introduced improper evidence of defendant's bad character, where the court recognized the errors, sustained the objections, and gave sufficient curative instructions. Villanueva v. State, App. 3 Dist., 917 So.2d 968 (2005). Criminal Law  2194

head.head.info: 200. Motions to strike out evidence, criminal cases--In general

para.paratext: Error, if any, in striking all testimony of defendant charged with murder was harmless in view of uncontradicted evidence of number of eyewitnesses and confession of defendant which reflected that he knowingly and cold-bloodedly murdered the decedent. Harris v. State, App. 1 Dist., 236 So.2d 135 (1970). Criminal Law  1168(4)

In prosecution of mother and son for murder of son's wife, wherein evidence of statements made by mother was admitted to show that mother was present in the house when the homicide occurred, and trial judge subsequently instructed jury to find mother not guilty, but there was no motion to exclude such testimony from the jury's consideration, and such testimony was not important, introduction of such evidence was not ground for reversing conviction of son. Dewey v. State, 135 Fla. 443, 186 So. 224 (1938). Criminal Law  1169.1(3)

In criminal prosecution, an order overruling a motion to strike evidence of flight of an accomplice is not reversible error when there is also in the record undisputed proof of flight of the defendants on trial. Tucker v. State, 86 Fla. 36, 96 So. 10 (1923). Criminal Law  1168(4)

It is not reversible error for the trial court, upon motion of the state, to strike testimony that is in effect a self-serving declaration of defendant, not part of the res gestae, and harmful to defendant in one aspect. Stinson v. State, 76 Fla. 421, 80 So. 506 (1918). Criminal Law  410.70; Criminal Law  1170(1)

head.head.info: 201. ---- Grounds motions to strike out evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: In prosecution for murder of police officer, wherein discrepancy in arresting officer's description of automobile, in which defendant was arrested, as “two door”, and description of custodian of automobile stolen near hotel, in which officer was shot, as “four door”, was not called to attention of trial judge at time of oral motions to strike testimony of theft of the automobile, on ground that state had failed to prove that stolen automobile was automobile in which defendant was arrested, and for mistrial because of admission of the evidence, trial judge did not commit reversible error in admitting and refusing to strike the evidence. Mackiewicz v. State, 114 So.2d 684 (1959), certiorari denied 80 S.Ct. 883, 362 U.S. 965, 4 L.Ed.2d 879, rehearing denied 80 S.Ct. 1083, 362 U.S. 992, 4 L.Ed.2d 1024. Criminal Law  1168(4)

head.head.info: 202. ---- Preservation of objections, motions to strike out evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Although trial court erred in sustaining state's objection to deputy's testimony regarding statement of second deputy during chase of defendant as hearsay, issue was not adequately preserved for appeal because defense counsel never proffered the answer; counsel stated he was not certain what deputy would say, and although statement later came in when defense called second deputy, record did not show whether first deputy heard statement during chase. Miller v. State, App. 2 Dist., 870 So.2d 15 (2003), rehearing denied, habeas corpus denied 2009 WL 2436075. Criminal Law  1036.5

Defendant's non-specific objection that “There's no foundation” was insufficient to preserve challenge to police investigator's testimony that the license tag of a white van observed by police investigators at scene of burglary was a Florida tag registered to defendant. Couzo v. State, App. 4 Dist., 830 So.2d 177 (2002), rehearing denied, review denied 842 So.2d 843. Criminal Law  1043(2)

The objection “lack of foundation,” like its first cousin “improper predicate,” is not a specific ground of objection so as to preserve a ruling admitting evidence for appellate review. Couzo v. State, App. 4 Dist., 830 So.2d 177 (2002), rehearing denied, review denied 842 So.2d 843. Criminal Law  1043(2)

Defendant, who was charged with felony driving under the influence (DUI), failed to preserve for appeal evidentiary objection that hospital medical records, which contained results of blood alcohol test, were inadmissable due to lack of foundation in compliance with business records hearsay exception, notwithstanding trial objection that state failed to lay proper foundation “as to who drew defendant's blood,” since defendant's objection was neither specific nor sufficiently precise to fairly apprise trial court of grounds for relief sought. Filan v. State, App. 4 Dist., 768 So.2d 1100 (2000). Criminal Law  1043(1); Criminal Law  1043(2)

head.head.info: 203. ---- Timeliness, motions to strike out evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: In prosecution for conspiracy to steal or to receive, possess and dispose of whiskey from an interstate shipment, where evidence as to other crimes and conspiracies was not solicited by prosecution, but was injected by a witness in response to cross-examination questions of counsel for defendants, and there was no immediate objection to such evidence, subsequent refusal to strike such evidence was not reversible error. Clark v. U.S., 1954, 213 F.2d 63. Criminal Law  1168(4)

Court did not err in refusing to strike any references to defendant in testimony about incriminating oral statements made by his co-defendant to a constable, where court had properly instructed jury that nothing in co-defendant's statements could be considered against defendant and the incriminating statements of the co-defendant objected to by defendant had been admitted, without objection, by the introduction of co-defendant's confession. Coney v. State, App. 3 Dist., 193 So.2d 57 (1966). Criminal Law  1168(4)

head.head.info: 204. ---- Prejudicial effect of ruling, motions to strike out evidence, criminal cases

para.paratext: Inasmuch as it did not appear with any degree of certainty that error in striking testimony of reputation witnesses for defendant had been harmless, reversal was required. Eubanks v. State, App. 1 Dist., 179 So.2d 256 (1965). Criminal Law  1168(4)

In abortion prosecution, striking of certain testimony, which had been elicited by defense counsel from chief prosecuting witness with aid of transcript of previous interview by counsel with such witness, and which had direct bearing on credibility of witness and upon defendant's defense in general, constituted reversible error. Urga v. State, 85 So.2d 629 (1956). Criminal Law  696(1); Criminal Law  1168(4)

head.head.info: 205. Curing defects or objections, criminal cases--In general

para.paratext: In prosecution for embezzlement of United States postal matter, admission of testimonial evidence to prove terms of alleged postal regulation prohibiting postal workers from placing mail matter in their pockets, without explaining why the writing itself could not be produced, was error, but such error was harmless since any such rule would relate only indirectly to defendant's guilt and since such testimony, introduced to show criminal intent and attack defendant's principal defense, was merely cumulative with respect to both purposes. U. S. v. Holley, 1972, 463 F.2d 634. Criminal Law  400(3); Criminal Law  1169.10

Wife's testimony that her husband gave her a sweater which state asserted had been stolen from automobile which husband had broken into was merely cumulative of other testimony connecting husband with theft of other articles stolen from the automobile, and to that extent the admission of this testimony was harmless. Ross v. State, App. 1 Dist., 202 So.2d 582 (1967). Criminal Law  1169.2(2)

Any error in admission of evidence allegedly illegally seized was not basis for reversal of conviction, where evidence was merely cumulative and there was ample evidence to make out case for jury aliunde the fruits of the arrest and search. Casso v. State, App. 2 Dist., 182 So.2d 252 (1966), certiorari denied 192 So.2d 487. Criminal Law  1169.2(5)

Evidence, relating to intoxication based on observations made some hours after accident and on drunkometer reading taken later, was cumulative, and, even if such evidence was incompetent, reception of same would not require reversal of conviction for causing death of another by driving motor vehicle while intoxicated. Cesario v. State, App. 3 Dist., 167 So.2d 896 (1964). Criminal Law  1169.2(2)

Any error in admission of testimony by examining doctor as to statements made to him by prosecuting witness out of the presence of the defendant was harmless when prosecuting witness gave competent testimony as to the very same facts. Urga v. State, App. 2 Dist., 155 So.2d 719 (1963). Criminal Law  1169.2(6)

In murder prosecution, admitting a shotgun allegedly used to commit the killing to which was attached a tag stating that it was the gun that the victim was shot with and signed by the defendant was not prejudicial where the tag added no new incriminating evidence above what was contained in a voluntary confession. Conner v. State, 106 So.2d 416 (1958). Criminal Law  1169.2(6)

In prosecution for assault with intent to commit murder, where police officer who was victim of assault testified without objection that he did not discover bullet hole in patrol car but that it was pointed out to him day after incident, if admission of photograph of patrol car as true representation of patrol car on day after assault was an error, it was harmless error. Kirkland v. State, 91 So.2d 656 (1956). Criminal Law  1169.2(7)

In prosecution for murder in first degree by shooting victim with a pistol, error, if any, in admitting two photographs taken in home where victim was shot was harmless when jury viewed premises at close of testimony. Porter v. State, 81 So.2d 519 (1955). Criminal Law  1169.2(7)

In embezzlement prosecution, wherein prosecuting witness testified that he told defendant to use a portion of witness' money in defendant's possession to cover defendant's shortage in his accounts at hotel where he worked, admission of testimony of manager of hotel that defendant at time of alleged embezzlement was short in his cash account with the hotel, if error, was harmless. Roberts v. State, 158 Fla. 632, 29 So.2d 446 (1947). Criminal Law  1169.2(2)

Error, if any, in admitting officers' testimony as to finding gambling paraphernalia in place entered by them without search warrant was immaterial and harmless to defendants in trial for keeping and maintaining gaming implements and apparatus and place for gaming purposes, where other testimony supported conviction and no timely effort was made to suppress such evidence. Davis v. State, 137 Fla. 151, 187 So. 761 (1939). Criminal Law  1044.1(6); Criminal Law  1169.2(5)

head.head.info: 206. ---- Accomplices and co-defendants, curing defects or objections, criminal cases

para.paratext: Where statements which defendant claimed had been improperly received into evidence either had no relevance to charge of which defendant was convicted or asserted facts otherwise established by independent evidence, any error in admitting such out-of-court statements of confederates was not prejudicial. U. S. v. Gattie, 1975, 511 F.2d 608. Criminal Law  1169.7

Policeman's testimony that codefendant had told him that “Georgia boys had a contract out” for government witness and FBI informant had no spillover effect on codefendant or another codefendant who presented alibi defenses and whose tactful approaches throughout trial were separate and distinct from that of defendant, who policeman inferred was one of the “Georgia boys.” U. S. v. Cochran, 1974, 499 F.2d 380, rehearing denied 502 F.2d 1168, certiorari denied 95 S.Ct. 810, 419 U.S. 1124, 42 L.Ed.2d 825. Criminal Law  1169.7

Testimony of government agent relating to an interview with one defendant was irrelevant and thus inadmissible; the error in admitting such evidence was not prejudicial. U. S. v. Burke, 1974, 495 F.2d 1226, certiorari denied 95 S.Ct. 667, 419 U.S. 1079, 42 L.Ed.2d 673. Criminal Law  422(1); Criminal Law  1169.7

Where guilt of petitioner was overwhelmingly established by testimony other than extrajudicial statements of codefendants implicating petitioner in first-degree murder, there was no necessity for jury to have looked to extrajudicial statements of nontestifying codefendants; thus, conviction was not unconstitutionally infirm as having been obtained in violation of constitutional right of confrontation. Simpson v. Wainwright, 1971, 439 F.2d 948, certiorari denied 91 S.Ct. 2199, 402 U.S. 1011, 29 L.Ed.2d 434. Criminal Law  1169.7

Initial admission of testimony as to declarations of codefendant, even if error, was not prejudicial to defendant where, by end of trial copartnership in crime had been established. Orser v. U. S., 1966, 362 F.2d 580. Criminal Law  1169.7

Any residual recollections which jury might have held of one defendant's reference to other defendants in extrajudicial admission were without prejudice to other defendants where only cumulative to other evidence which was sufficient to tie them with conspiracy and to warrant finding of guilt in each case. Carter v. U. S., 1962, 304 F.2d 881. Criminal Law  1169.7

Introduction into evidence of codefendants' statements containing incriminating statements against petitioner was harmless error, where limiting instruction was given that such statements not be considered by jury against petitioner, the confessions of codefendants were merely cumulative, containing essentially the same facts as petitioner's confession and testimony of prosecutrix, and testimony of prosecutrix and her boyfriend and confession of petitioner considered together presented an overwhelming case against petitioner. Stubbs v. Wainwright, S.D.Fla.1972, 340 F.Supp. 1, affirmed 468 F.2d 248. Criminal Law  1169.7

Admission of officer's testimony concerning inculpatory statement which allegedly had been made by one defendant and which implicated codefendant did not constitute reversible error where both defendants took stand and testified and defendant who allegedly made the statement testified in favor of the other defendant by denying that he had made the statement and by claiming alibi. Frazier v. State, App. 1 Dist., 287 So.2d 386 (1973). Criminal Law  1169.7

With respect to codefendant who was implicated in charged offense by defendant's alleged statement, error, if any, in admitting officer's testimony concerning the statement was harmless in view of clear proof of defendants' guilt. Frazier v. State, App. 1 Dist., 287 So.2d 386 (1973). Criminal Law  1169.7

In view of overwhelming evidence of defendant's guilt of rape, the admission into evidence of codefendant's statement, which incriminated defendant, as against defendant at joint trial at which neither defendant testified was harmless error. Horton v. State, App. 2 Dist., 285 So.2d 418 (1973). Criminal Law  1169.7

Where evidence of defendant's guilt of robbery was ample and compelling, testimony of police officers with regard to the identification of statement taken from defendant's accomplice but not introduced in evidence, if error, was harmless error, Gadson v. State, App. 3 Dist., 277 So.2d 571 (1973). Criminal Law  1169.7

Notwithstanding court's instruction that statements of two codefendants, which inculpated appealing defendant in joint trial, should be disregarded in evaluating case against appealing defendant, appellate review of record was required to determine if error was rendered harmless beyond reasonable doubt. Sturgis v. State, App. 4 Dist., 233 So.2d 166 (1970), certiorari denied 238 So.2d 109. Criminal Law  1169.5(5)

Where confession of codefendant was complete in detail and fully incriminated such codefendant and the others in joint trial including appealing defendant in rape, admission of confession which was hardly cumulative and could have caused a substantial impact on jury was not harmless error. Sturgis v. State, App. 4 Dist., 233 So.2d 166 (1970), certiorari denied 238 So.2d 109. Criminal Law  1169.7

Where defendant's trial occurred before entry of United States Supreme Court decision pertaining to exclusion of codefendants' statement which implicates an accused and evidence of defendant's guilt of rape was overwhelming, admission into evidence of codefendant's oral statement which implicated defendant was harmless error. Coney v. State, App. 3 Dist., 231 So.2d 538 (1970). Criminal Law  1169.7

Incriminating statements made by or attributed to nontestifying codefendant, the admission of which statements violated defendant's Sixth Amendment rights, were so cumulative in nature, and the evidence against petitioner otherwise so overwhelming, that beyond a reasonable doubt it could be said such admission of evidence constituted harmless error. Collins v. State, App. 4 Dist., 230 So.2d 711 (1970). Criminal Law  1169.7

Admission of hearsay testimony relating to confession of accomplice was harmless error even if relied on when there was testimony of accomplice himself covering same matters. Montalvo v. State, App. 3 Dist., 154 So.2d 713 (1963). Criminal Law  1169.2(2)

head.head.info: 207. ---- Co-conspirators, curing defects or objections, criminal cases

para.paratext: Even though statements of coconspirator, made to federal agents after other coconspirators' arrest, were inadmissible as to other coconspirators in joint trial, other coconspirators were not prejudiced and admission of such statements was harmless beyond reasonable doubt where conspiracy had already been overwhelmingly proved against other coconspirators. U. S. v. Killian, 1975, 524 F.2d 1268, certiorari denied 96 S.Ct. 1667, 425 U.S. 935, 48 L.Ed.2d 177. Criminal Law  1169.7

Where declarant's role as a coconspirator had ended by reason of his arrest, his later declaration to effect that other defendants had threatened to kill informer should not have been admitted against those other defendants, but the error in admission of such testimony was harmless in light of the overwhelming evidence against those other defendants. U. S. v. Arias-Diaz, 1974, 497 F.2d 165, rehearing denied 504 F.2d 760, certiorari denied 95 S.Ct. 1445, 420 U.S. 1003, 43 L.Ed.2d 761, certiorari denied 95 S.Ct. 1446, 420 U.S. 1003, 43 L.Ed.2d 761. Criminal Law  422(1); Criminal Law  1169.7

Evidence that defendant was aware of unindicted coconspirator's interest in securing cocaine, that several telephone calls were placed between defendant's and coconspirator's residences immediately prior to attempted sale of cocaine, and that defendant was present in parking lot at time of attempted sale was insufficient to establish conspiracy and introduction of hearsay statements of coconspirator was reversible error. U. S. v. Oliva, 1974, 497 F.2d 130. Criminal Law  427(5); Criminal Law  1169.7

Where defendant contended that Government's evidence showed that witness was a coconspirator and his testimony was introduced by Government for sole purpose of showing intent and knowledge on part of codefendant and prosecutor informed counsel of his intention to call witness as soon as practicable after learning of his existence and his relationship to codefendant and materials for cross-examination of witness were given counsel and witness' entire testimony was proffered during extended in camera hearing, defendant's substantial rights were not prejudiced by court's allowing witness' testimony over claim that since he was not named as coconspirator in bill of particulars proof exceeded confines of the bill. U. S. v. Martinez, 1972, 466 F.2d 679, rehearing denied 481 F.2d 896, certiorari denied 94 S.Ct. 571, 414 U.S. 1065, 38 L.Ed.2d 469. Criminal Law  1169.7

Although testimony of witness that codefendant had told him to take the Fifth Amendment if he was called as a witness before grand jury was inadmissible as to defendant, in that it was clear that conspiracy had ended by the time statement was made, error in admitting testimony was harmless, where record established that judgment of jury was not swayed or influenced by admission of testimony. U. S. v. Fischetti, 1971, 450 F.2d 34, certiorari denied 92 S.Ct. 1290, 405 U.S. 1016, 31 L.Ed.2d 478. Criminal Law  1169.7

In prosecution for conspiracy to violate Internal Revenue liquor and illicit still laws, admission of testimony of arresting officer as to statements made by alleged coconspirators after their arrest was reversible error, in absence of evidence of any conspiracy which continued after such arrest and after destruction of still. Mosley v. U.S., 1960, 285 F.2d 226. Criminal Law  427(2); Criminal Law  1169.7

Admission of statements of coconspirator under “co-conspirator rule” was not reversible error, where the evidence was sufficient to find that each of the defendants was a coconspirator. Scaldeferri v. State, App. 3 Dist., 294 So.2d 407 (1974), certiorari denied 303 So.2d 21, certiorari denied 95 S.Ct. 304, 419 U.S. 993, 42 L.Ed.2d 266, certiorari dismissed, cause remanded 320 So.2d 1, certiorari denied 327 So.2d 229. Criminal Law  1169.7

head.head.info: 208. ---- Admissions by accused, curing defects or objections, criminal cases

para.paratext: Error, if any, established by fact that, during course of trial, testimony was given concerning a statement previously made by a codefendant implicating defendant was rendered completely harmless where defendant himself testified that he inflicted mortal wound upon decedent and, in essence, admitted everything that was encompassed within codefendant's statement. Thompson v. State, App. 2 Dist., 300 So.2d 301 (1974), certiorari denied 303 So.2d 29. Criminal Law  1169.3

If was error for trial court to refuse to permit defendant to testify as to whether he committed crime with which he was charged, but such error was harmless in light of his other testimony. Moore v. State, App. 4 Dist., 276 So.2d 504 (1973). Criminal Law  337; Criminal Law  1169.3

Possible error committed by private security officer in his testimony that upon arresting defendant and warning him not to say anything, defendant responded by saying that he already knew what to do from prior experience, was subsequently cured where defendant admitted, while testifying in his own behalf, the prior facts on which officer's comment was based. Cooper v. State, App. 3 Dist., 261 So.2d 859 (1972). Criminal Law  1169.3

Assuming arguendo that it was error, in manslaughter prosecution, to display to the jury certain firearms not connected with the defendant, the error was harmless in view of the fact that defendant admitted shooting the victim but claimed that the shooting was an accident. Wells v. State, App. 3 Dist., 256 So.2d 580 (1972). Criminal Law  1169.3

In prosecution for assault with intent to commit rape, where defendant testified that he had picked up prosecutrix and her two companions while they were hitchhiking and had driven them to a wooded area where they got out and ran away, and prosecutrix claimed defendant had raped her after she got out of defendant's automobile, defendant's identity as driver was not in dispute and allowing deputy sheriff to testify over objection as to identification made of defendant by prosecutrix at place where defendant was detained at time of his apprehension did not prejudice defendant. Robinson v. State, App. 4 Dist., 237 So.2d 268 (1970). Criminal Law  1169.3

Refusal to declare a mistrial in prosecution for murder because of reference in testimony of police officer to fact that defendant had previously been in trouble was not reversible error, where objection to such testimony was sustained and jury charged to ignore it and record contained several other similar references, admitted without objection, including defendant's statement to police. Meade v. State, 96 So.2d 776 (1957), certiorari denied 78 S.Ct. 351, 355 U.S. 920, 2 L.Ed.2d 279. Criminal Law  1169.3

In prosecution for receiving stolen goods, permitting officers to testify as to admissions made by defendant, if erroneous on ground that it did not appear that admissions were made voluntarily, was cured by defendant's own testimony to the effect that admissions were voluntarily made. King v. State, 156 Fla. 817, 24 So.2d 573 (1946). Criminal Law  1169.3

In perjury prosecution against witness in murder prosecution, admission of witness' testimony in first murder prosecution respecting incriminating statements made by codefendant in murder prosecution, if erroneous on ground that count relating to such statements was “nolle prossed” and that witness was tried only on count relating to statements made by defendant in murder prosecution, was harmless, where witness admitted at second murder prosecution that her testimony at first prosecution respecting statements made by both defendant and codefendant were false. Hall v. State, 136 Fla. 644, 187 So. 392 (1939). Criminal Law  1169.3

Error, if any, in receiving testimony on murder trial that defendant did not look right when seen by witness shortly after crime was harmless, where defendant testified to facts clearly showing his guilt. Smith v. State, 129 Fla. 388, 176 So. 506 (1937). Criminal Law  1169.3

In homicide prosecution, improper admission as part of res gestae of witness' testimony that woman had come up to him and asked his assistance, stating that defendant was killing a man and his wife did not require reversal, where defendant had testified he was killing such persons at time statement was made. Halfrich v. State, 122 Fla. 375, 165 So. 285 (1936). Criminal Law  1169.3

Where, in prosecution for forgery, evidence is introduced by the state to show flight or concealment by the accused, and he subsequently testifies as a witness, and admits facts showing his flight or concealment, in view of the probable discovery of the forgeries, objections to the evidence introduced by the state will not be considered. Wooldridge v. State, 49 Fla. 137, 38 So. 3 (1905). Criminal Law  1169.3

Although the court may err in admitting evidence of acts of a third person material to the issues, without proof that such third person was acting under authority from the defendant, yet if the defendant, as a witness, admits the authority of such persons to do the acts, the error is cured. Wallace v. State, 41 Fla. 547, 26 So. 713 (1899). Criminal Law  1169.3

Where the defendant in a criminal case, on cross-examination, admits having made certain statements under oath on a previous trial concerning the res gestae of the offense, apparently in conflict with his present testimony, it is not prejudicial error to permit the state to prove in rebuttal that defendant did make the statements as admitted. Singleton v. State, 39 Fla. 520, 22 So. 876 (1897). Criminal Law  1169.3

head.head.info: 209. ---- Confessions, curing defects or objections, criminal cases

para.paratext: Admission of federal habeas corpus petitioner's confession in state trial, even if only partially read to jury, could not be construed as error where petitioner had admitted that statement was his and it corroborated petitioner's version of homicide much like a prior consistent statement. Conyers v. Wainwright, S.D.Fla.1970, 309 F.Supp. 1101. Criminal Law  1169.3

In a joint trial, evidence given in a codefendant's confession as to same facts as defendant himself has freely and voluntarily given in a confession or testimony is not ground for reversal. State v. Stubbs, 239 So.2d 241 (1970). Criminal Law  1169.3

Defendant's testimony in prosecution for second-degree murder repeating substantially the matters stated in her confession for purpose of showing absence of proof of all elements of crime charged and presenting facts in reduction of offense or in mitigation did not constitute admission of guilt of offense charged and would not cure error in admitting confession in evidence, if it was otherwise inadmissible. Miori v. State, App. 3 Dist., 189 So.2d 208 (1966). Criminal Law  1169.3

head.head.info: 210. ---- Exclusion of similar evidence, curing defects or objections, criminal cases

para.paratext: Where testimony to the effect that although able to distinguish between right and wrong, defendant might not be able to conform his acts to requirements of the law was elicited by counsel for defendant on cross-examination of state's witness, a doctor who had examined defendant and testified as to his legal insanity, defendant could not be heard to complain of any prejudice in subsequent exclusion of similar evidence. Campbell v. State, 227 So.2d 873 (1969), petition dismissed 91 S.Ct. 7, 400 U.S. 801, 27 L.Ed.2d 33. Criminal Law  1170(2)

head.head.info: 211. ---- Favorability to accused, curing defects or objections, criminal cases

para.paratext: Despite fact that trial court, after sustaining defense objection to questions which the witness answered before court could rule on the objection, refused to give an instruction to the jury to disregard the questions or the answer, the answer given by the witness was not inflammatory or suggestive but was in fact favorable to the position taken by the defense and thus did not constitute reversible error. Wells v. State, App. 3 Dist., 256 So.2d 580 (1972). Criminal Law  1169.8

The action of the court in overruling an objection to a pertinent question to a state witness will not be reversed, especially when the answer thereby elicited tended to help accused. Wilson v. State, 47 Fla. 118, 36 So. 580 (1904). Criminal Law  1169.8

head.head.info: 212. ---- Immaterial or incompetent evidence, curing defects or objections, criminal cases

para.paratext: In prosecution on charges of extortionate credit transactions, defendant's rights were fully safeguarded with respect to conclusory statements by witness that defendants were partners with a third person in the shylocking business, where objection to such statements were sustained and the jury was directed to disregard them. U. S. v. Nakaladski, 1973, 481 F.2d 289, certiorari denied 94 S.Ct. 570, 414 U.S. 1064, 38 L.Ed.2d 469. Criminal Law  1169.5(4)

Remarks to jury by agent while narrating film taken when defendant was engaged in certain activities relevant to charges contained in indictment were not ground for reversal where most of defendant's objections were specifically sustained and remarks stricken. U. S. v. Pollack, 1970, 427 F.2d 1168, certiorari denied 91 S.Ct. 63, 400 U.S. 831, 27 L.Ed.2d 62. Criminal Law  1169.5(4)

Where testimony is introduced in support of a count that should have been stricken on motion to quash, and such testimony is not pertinent to a count that the court subsequently charges the jury to be the only one they could consider, reversible error may result if the impertinent testimony is harmful. Edington v. State, 81 Fla. 634, 88 So. 468 (1921). Criminal Law  1169.1(1)

head.head.info: 213. ---- Instructions, curing defects or objections, criminal cases

para.paratext: Instructions given by court corrected any error which might have occurred in prosecution for conspiracy and possession and distribution of cocaine when white woman testified that she worked as prostitute for defendant, a black man. U. S. v. Isaacs, 1975, 516 F.2d 409, certiorari denied 96 S.Ct. 295, 423 U.S. 936, 46 L.Ed.2d 269. Criminal Law  1169.5(2)

In joint trial of uncle and nephew on charge of conspiring to defraud the United States by impeding the Internal Revenue Service in collecting income taxes, uncle could not have been prejudiced by the introduction of nephew's preconspiracy financial statement, which purported to list nephew's outstanding obligations yet made no mention of a loan from uncle, since the jury was repeatedly instructed that statements of any conspirator made before the existence of the conspiracy may only be considered as evidence against the person making it. U. S. v. Diez, 1975, 515 F.2d 892, rehearing denied 521 F.2d 815, certiorari denied 96 S.Ct. 780, 423 U.S. 1052, 46 L.Ed.2d 641. Criminal Law  1169.5(2)

Even if evidence as to identity of “Georgia boys,” who purportedly had a contract out for government witness and FBI informant, was inadmissible, instruction which directed jury to disregard witness' answer as speculative and cautioned jury that there was no evidence in case from which any such inference could be drawn was sufficient to overcome reversible error. U. S. v. Cochran, 1974, 499 F.2d 380, rehearing denied 502 F.2d 1168, certiorari denied 95 S.Ct. 810, 419 U.S. 1124, 42 L.Ed.2d 825. Criminal Law  1169.5(2)

Clear instruction by trial judge not to consider certain evidence generally eliminates any reversible error in the admission of the evidence. U. S. v. Vosper, 1974, 493 F.2d 433. Criminal Law  1169.5(1)

Whether the admission of evidence becomes so prejudicial as to compel a new trial, notwithstanding a clear instruction not to consider the evidence, is determined on a case by case basis. U. S. v. Vosper, 1974, 493 F.2d 433. Criminal Law  1169.5(1)

Any possible prejudice to defendant from a witness' testimony that defendant said “if he or his writers would get picked up he had enough connections that he would or was sure that he could fix the case” was cured by the trial judge's prompt admonition to the jury to disregard the response since it was entirely unrelated to the proceedings. U. S. v. Perez, 1974, 489 F.2d 93. Criminal Law  1169.5(5)

Error in the admission of evidence under most circumstances may be cured by withdrawing the evidence from jury's consideration and instructing jury to disregard it. U. S. v. Troise, 1973, 483 F.2d 615, certiorari denied 94 S.Ct. 574, 414 U.S. 1066, 38 L.Ed.2d 471. Criminal Law  1169.5(1)

Rule, that error in the admission of evidence may be cured by withdrawing the evidence from jury's consideration and instructing jury to disregard it, has exception where the remark is so highly prejudicial as to be incurable by trial court's admonition. U. S. v. Troise, 1973, 483 F.2d 615, certiorari denied 94 S.Ct. 574, 414 U.S. 1066, 38 L.Ed.2d 471. Criminal Law  1169.5(1)

Evidence that defendant was present in Abilene, Texas at time blank checks used for deposit in several Florida banks were lost by or stolen from a particular individual was admissible in prosecution for interstate transporation of stolen articles used in counterfeiting for purpose of showing that defendant resided at Abilene at time in question and was in position to have possible access to lost or stolen checks, but assuming arguendo that evidence was inadmissible, where trial court reversed its ruling and directed jury to disregard such evidence, no prejudice arose to defendant. U. S. v. Kimbrell, 1972, 470 F.2d 280. Criminal Law  1169.5(2); Receiving Stolen Goods  8(2)

Evidence adduced in attempt to prove guilt of codefendant and existence of conspiracy to forge United States Treasury bonds did not prejudice defendant on theory that it was irrelevant where jury was instructed to disregard any evidence relating to codefendant and there was no improper joinder of defendants. Rubin v. U. S., 1969, 414 F.2d 473, certiorari denied 90 S.Ct. 571, 396 U.S. 1011, 24 L.Ed.2d 503. Criminal Law  1169.5(2)

Giving of an appropriate cautionary instruction negated any possible harmful effect of defendant's volunteered statement that not only she but that an otherwise unidentified female also identified defendant. Lynch v. State, 293 So.2d 44 (1974). Criminal Law  1169.5(5)
Even if court erroneously admitted testimony, the error was cured by court's subsequent explanation to the jury. Wallace v. State, App. 3 Dist., 221 So.2d 759 (1969). Criminal Law  1169.5(1)

In order for instructions to cure error in relation to evidence or testimony before jury, instruction must eradicate from minds of jury of laymen not only offending evidence itself, but imputations and inferences which might be drawn therefrom. Stewart v. State, App. 3 Dist., 221 So.2d 155 (1969). Criminal Law  1169.5(1)
Charge directing jury to disregard evidence corrects irregularities which may have occurred in connection therewith. Williams v. State, 74 So.2d 797 (1954). Criminal Law  1169.5(1)

Instructions which told jury that, unless it found from the evidence that alleged admissions or confessions were freely and voluntarily made, they should be excluded from consideration, was sufficient to cure any alleged error in possible consideration by jury of confession. Melton v. State, 159 Fla. 106, 30 So.2d 916 (1947). Criminal Law  1169.5(1)
Although difficult for juror to banish improper testimony from mind, it is not regarded as impossible or even impracticable. Butler v. State, 94 Fla. 163, 113 So. 699 (1927). Criminal Law  1169.1(1)

head.head.info: 214. ---- Other evidence of guilt, curing defects or objections, criminal cases

para.paratext: Erroneous admission of evidence is not ground for reversal, where there was other clear and convincing evidence of guilt. Linsley v. State, 88 Fla. 135, 101 So. 273 (1924); Hinson v. State, 62 Fla. 63, 56 So. 674 (1911); Sallas v. State, 61 Fla. 59, 54 So. 773 (1911).

In murder prosecution, evidence found in search of defendant's home without warrant was not objectionable, where such evidence was not harmful and evidence was otherwise sufficient. Jeffcoat v. State, 103 Fla. 466, 138 So. 385 (1931). Criminal Law  1169.2(5)

Refusal to permit introduction of search warrant and affidavit in evidence was harmless, where other evidence supported conviction for receiving stolen property. Reynolds v. State, 100 Fla. 1509, 131 So. 384 (1930). Criminal Law  1170(2)

Conviction by municipal judge of liquor violation, which on the record may be under ordinance and supported by sufficient legal evidence, will not be disturbed for illegality of search warrant. Combs v. Lake City, 93 Fla. 585, 112 So. 51 (1927). Criminal Law  1169.2(5)

head.head.info: 215. ---- Otherwise established facts, curing defects or objections, criminal cases

para.paratext: Admission of incompetent evidence is harmless error, where the fact to which such evidence relates is otherwise established by competent evidence. Hinson v. State, 62 Fla. 63, 56 So. 674 (1911); Flowers v. State, 59 Fla. 16, 52 So. 11 (1910); Boykin v. State, 40 Fla. 484, 24 So. 141 (1898).

Erroneous exclusion of record of state court adjudication of incompetency was not harmless error in criminal prosecution in which defendant raised insanity defense, although defense witnesses testified that defendant had been adjudged incompetent. U. S. v. Minor, 1972, 459 F.2d 103. Criminal Law  1170(2)

Admission in evidence in fraud and conspiracy prosecution of documents received by numerous investors which did not bear defendant's signature was harmless error, if it was error at all, where there was much additional documentary evidence of similar type introduced against defendant dealing with his own participation in activities of three companies with which he was associated, which documents were enclosed in letters actually signed by the defendant. Muir v. U. S., 1967, 373 F.2d 712. Criminal Law  1169.2(7)

Admission of government's rebuttal testimony as to statement made by witness, indicted for same offenses as defendant, when first arrested, was harmless to defendant's substantial rights, if erroneous, where such statement was substantially same as witness' testimony and did not tend to show defendant's guilt. Mason v. U.S., 1938, 95 F.2d 612. Criminal Law  1169.2(2)

Error in requiring defendant to testify as to previous conviction of codefendant was rendered harmless by subsequent testimony of codefendant admitting conviction. Williams v. U.S., 1931, 46 F.2d 731. Criminal Law  1169.2(2)

Refusing to permit introduction of evidence concerning specific, or individual, acts of prior intercourse between rape victim and a particular witness was not reversible error, considering that evidence of victim's general reputation for chastity in community was permitted. Thomas v. State, App. 3 Dist., 249 So.2d 510 (1971). Criminal Law  1170(2)

Exclusion of photographs of scene of homicide taken several weeks after the event was not prejudicial where jury viewed scene and proffered photographs were cumulative. Darty v. State, App. 2 Dist., 161 So.2d 864 (1964), certiorari denied 168 So.2d 147. Criminal Law  1170(2)

A ruling of the trial court, excluding proffered proof tending to discredit by showing his interest, the evidence of the principal state witness in a criminal prosecution is not erroneous, where the transaction alleged to show such interest fully appears from other evidence, which was admitted. Steele v. State, 85 Fla. 57, 95 So. 299 (1923). Criminal Law  1170(2)

Admission of incompetent evidence for the prosecution is not prejudicial, if the facts toward which it is directed were subsequently proved by similar evidence produced by defendant. Neicarta v. State, 80 Fla. 493, 86 So. 347 (1920). Criminal Law  1169.2(4)

head.head.info: 216. ---- Prior or subsequent admission of same evidence, curing defects or objections, criminal cases

para.paratext: The error, if any, in excluding evidence, is cured by the subsequent admission thereof. Branch v. State, 96 Fla. 307, 118 So. 13 (1928); Barton v. State, 72 Fla. 408, 73 So. 230 (1916); Koon v. State, 72 Fla. 148, 72 So. 673 (1916); Eatman v. State, 48 Fla. 21, 37 So. 576 (1904); Sylvester v. State, 46 Fla. 166, 35 So. 142 (1903).
Technical error in excluding evidence may be cured by admission of same evidence by another witness or accused. Denmark v. State, 95 Fla. 757, 116 So. 757 (1928). Criminal Law  1170(3)

It is harmful error to admit in evidence over defendant's objection that transcribed stenographic notes of the testimony of a witness for the state at a former trial of accused on the same indictment, and such error is not cured by subsequently producing the witness and causing him to give his testimony in person, although there is only a slight variance between the stenographic report and the witness' testimony on the second trial. Young v. State, 85 Fla. 348, 96 So. 381 (1923). Criminal Law  1169.2(2)
The error, if any, in excluding evidence in a criminal case which had already been given, is not prejudicial to accused. Eatman v. State, 48 Fla. 21, 37 So. 576 (1904). Criminal Law  1170(3)

Error, if any, in sustaining an objection to a question asked a witness, is cured by his subsequently being permitted to answer substantially the same question. Baker v. State, 30 Fla. 41, 11 So. 492 (1892). Criminal Law  1170(3)

head.head.info: 217. ---- Prior or subsequent examination of same witness, curing defects or objections, criminal cases

para.paratext: The refusal to permit a witness to testify to certain facts does not require a new trial, where at another time in the course of the trial the witness did testify as to those facts. Hoskins v. State, 70 Fla. 186, 69 So. 701 (1915); Smith v. State, 65 Fla. 56, 61 So. 120 (1913); Jenkins v. State, 58 Fla. 62, 50 So. 582 (1909); McCall v. State, 55 Fla. 108, 46 So. 321 (1908).

Where trial court erroneously refused to allow accused to cross-examine witness as to manner in which a confession, which court had previously admitted upon evidence taken outside presence of jury, had been obtained, other questions asked by defendant upon subsequent cross-examination of the witness with respect to the confession were insufficient to overcome the error already made. Pearce v. State, 143 Fla. 347, 196 So. 685 (1940). Criminal Law  1170(4)

Refusal to permit wife of defendant, accused of knowingly purchasing stolen fruit, to testify as to another time that defendant had purchased fruit, was harmless, if error, where witness later was permitted to testify to same matter in another way. Johnston v. State, 127 Fla. 100, 172 So. 708 (1937). Criminal Law  1170(4)
The rejection of evidence was not prejudicial, where the same facts were amply proved by the same or other witnesses. Ward v. State, 75 Fla. 756, 79 So. 699 (1918). Criminal Law  1170(2)
