On the issue of self-defense, it is not prejudicial error to exclude the testimony of accused that deceased “could have cut me if I had waited any longer to shoot him”; he having testified as to his belief of danger from deceased. Mayo v. State, 64 Fla. 95, 59 So. 861 (1912). Criminal Law  1170(4)

Where the court refuses to permit a proper question on cross-examination, but it appears that the question was, substantially answered, the error is harmless. Danford v. State, 53 Fla. 4, 43 So. 593 (1907). Criminal Law  1170(4)

A defendant cannot complain that the court refused to permit a witness to answer a proper question, where the court permitted the same question in substance to be asked subsequently and answered without any objection. Marlow v. State, 49 Fla. 7, 38 So. 653 (1905). Criminal Law  1170(4)

Where assignments of error are based on the refusal of the judge to allow witnesses to answer certain questions, and all such questions were substantially answered at a subsequent stage of the proceedings, the assignments will not be considered. Wooldridge v. State, 49 Fla. 137, 38 So. 3 (1905). Criminal Law  1170(4)

Where witness was asked as to what remark defendant, accused of murder, made at a certain time, and the question was excluded, but witness was permitted to give the entire conversation, there was no reversible error. Cook v. State, 46 Fla. 20, 35 So. 665 (1903). Criminal Law  1170(4)

head.head.info: 218. ---- Subsequent propriety of evidence, curing defects or objections, criminal cases

para.paratext: In prosecution for receiving stolen property, any technical error in prematurely admitting evidence of defendant's admissions will be cured by subsequent evidence which justifies introduction of proof of the admissions and shows that defendant knew property found in his possession was stolen. Cortes v. State, 135 Fla. 589, 185 So. 323 (1938). Criminal Law  1169.4

head.head.info: 219. ---- Verdict or determination, curing defects or objections, criminal cases

para.paratext: A conviction will not be reversed on error for technical errors in rulings on admission of evidence, where evidence of guilt is clear and any error was not prejudicial to defendant. Wilkins v. State, 75 Fla. 483, 78 So. 523 (1918); Settles v. State, 75 Fla. 296, 78 So. 287 (1918).

In prosecution under indictment containing five counts charging the making of false completion certificates in connection with Federal Housing Administration insurance, conviction on one count would not be reversed because of alleged erroneous admission in evidence of a letter dealing with matter charged in another count, where introduction of letter was not objected to and defendant was acquitted on count with which the letter dealt. Durden v. U.S., 1950, 181 F.2d 496. Criminal Law  1169.6

In prosecution for rape, errors in admitting analysis of a smear taken from the vagina of prosecuting witness and in admitting report of analysis without sufficient identification of smear and report were rendered harmless by verdict of assault with intent to commit rape, since such evidence was admitted only to establish penetration. Frenette v. State, 158 Fla. 675, 29 So.2d 869 (1947). Criminal Law  1169.6

head.head.info: 220. ---- Withdrawal or striking out evidence, curing defects or objections, criminal cases

para.paratext: In determining efficacy of admonition to disregard testimony, Court of Appeals would consider that “The Moving finger writes; and, having writ, Moves on: nor all your Piety nor Wit, Shall lure it back to cancel half a Line, Nor all your Tears wash out a Word of it.” Rubaiyat, Stanza 71. Odom v. U. S., 1967, 377 F.2d 853. Criminal Law  1169.5(1)

Generally, erroneous admission of evidence is cured by instructing jury to disregard it where substantial rights of defendant are not affected, i.e., where guilt is clear and error if any is harmless, but where testimony is highly prejudicial and otherwise irrelevant in case, not declaring mistrial constitutes plain error and is not cured by admonition to disregard. Odom v. U. S., 1967, 377 F.2d 853. Criminal Law  1039; Criminal Law  1169.5(1)

Generally, an erroneous admission of evidence is cured by instructions that jury disregard it, where substantial rights of defendant were not adversely affected, that is, where his guilt is clear and error, if any occurred, was harmless. McMillian v. U. S., 1966, 363 F.2d 165. Criminal Law  1169.5(1)

Generally, evidence which is withdrawn from jury with a direction by the court that it be disregarded may not be basis of reversible error. Fahning v. U. S., 1962, 299 F.2d 579. Criminal Law  1169.5(1)

Although it was improper for State to ask defendant's stepdaughter whether she had ever expressed an opinion as to defendant's guilt to which stepdaughter had answered in the negative and to attempt by use of rebuttal witness to show that stepdaughter had expressed such an opinion, where rebuttal witness' testimony had been stricken and jury was left only with denial by stepdaughter, errors were not grounds for reversal. Coppolino v. State, App. 2 Dist., 223 So.2d 68 (1968), appeal dismissed 234 So.2d 120, certiorari denied 90 S.Ct. 2242, 399 U.S. 927, 26 L.Ed.2d 794. Criminal Law  1169.5(5); Criminal Law  1170.5(2)

Admission, in homicide case, of reference to defendant's arrest for kidnapping was not reversible error, where there was evidence of defendant's admission that after shooting he had compelled third person to drive him away, and jury was instructed to disregard reference to kidnapping. Boyd v. State, App. 2 Dist., 162 So.2d 271 (1964). Criminal Law  1169.5(3)

In murder prosecution, court's striking rebuttal testimony of witness who had, in violation of rule, been present in court during presentation of testimony of other witnesses, coupled with instruction to jury on subject, effectively cured any irregularity which might have occurred in connection therewith and where counsel for defendant had only requested court to strike testimony and not to grant mistrial, error could not be predicated upon court's not having declared, of its own motion, a mistrial. Griffin v. State, App. 1 Dist., 124 So.2d 38 (1960). Criminal Law  1168(2)

Error in admitting evidence of another similar but unconnected offense was not cured by giving a liberal charge to the jury in defendant's behalf. Wilson v. State, 134 Fla. 199, 183 So. 748 (1938). Criminal Law  1169.5(2)

The overruling of defendant's objection to question asked state's witness on trial for stealing calf as to what he did at third person's place of business was not error where court sustained objection to answer that witness and defendant tried to sell such person some beef, and instructed jury that such an answer had nothing to do with issues. Harvey v. State, 129 Fla. 289, 176 So. 439 (1937). Criminal Law  1169.5(2)

In prosecution charging defendant with having withdrawn money from corporation of which he was agent and depositing it to credit of corporation in which he was a stockholder, constant reminding of jury that defendant was short in his accounts with corporation in which he was a stockholder and had embezzled many thousands of dollars from such corporation was prejudicial error which was not cured by instruction to disregard such evidence. Hartman v. State, 121 Fla. 627, 164 So. 354 (1935). Criminal Law  1169.5(2)
In prosecution for breaking and entering, admitting evidence of another similar crime was error regardless of admonition. Boyett v. State, 95 Fla. 597, 116 So. 476 (1928). Criminal Law  1169.5(3)

Ordinarily the prompt withdrawal of improper evidence and an instruction by the court to give it no consideration cures the error of its admission. Martinez v. State, 76 Fla. 159, 79 So. 751 (1918). Criminal Law  1169.5(1)
Error, if any, in refusing to strike testimony, was cured by subsequently striking it and directing the jury to disregard it. Wilson v. State, 47 Fla. 118, 36 So. 580 (1904). Criminal Law  1168(4)

head.head.info: 221. Offers of proof, criminal cases

para.paratext: Although government never made a formal tender of suitcase belonging to a codefendant, where it was evident that government intended to introduce suitcase before it had taken all preliminary steps to establish a foundation for its admission, act of trial court, in an effort to keep proceedings moving, in merely interposing its admissibility ruling before government formally tendered suitcase was not harmful procedural error. U. S. v. Sullivan, 1972, 456 F.2d 1273. Criminal Law  1168(2)

Refusal to subpoena defendant's daughter as defense witness and refusal to grant defendant continuance during trial to secure attendance of such witness was not prejudicial, where affidavit setting forth testimony expected to be given by daughter revealed that testimony would have been merely cumulative of that of defendant and two other subpoenaed witnesses and judge, having conducted defendant's prior trial, was in favorable position to properly evaluate request for subpoenaes. Thompson v. U. S., 1967, 372 F.2d 826. Criminal Law  1166(7); Criminal Law  1168(1)

Proffer was required to cross-examine sexual abuse victim about prior false accusation of sexual misconduct against another person, where record was silent as to whether victim had ever made such an accusation or withdrawn it. Kovaleski v. State, App. 4 Dist., 1 So.3d 254 (2009), rehearing denied, review granted 65 So.3d 516. Witnesses  351

Defense counsel who sought to elicit testimony on cross-examination of lead detective that, following defendant's arrest on charges of burglary and petit theft, there was “a rash” of robberies on the other side of town committed by a perpetrator who, like defendant, was an African-American male in his thirties failed to proffer sufficient evidence that the proposed testimony was relevant to the question of whether defendant committed the charged offenses, and thus trial court did not abuse its discretion by excluding the evidence; counsel was unable to provide any other information or details about the other incidents. Neals v. State, App. 3 Dist., 972 So.2d 1047 (2008). Criminal Law  670

Defense counsel's offer of proof failed to specify how, if at all, officer was involved in other case involving excessive force, and thus precluded appellate review of trial judge's alleged error in restricting defendant's cross-examination of officer, in fleeing and eluding a police officer trial, regarding officer's alleged use of excessive force in other case. Rowley v. State, App. 4 Dist., 939 So.2d 298 (2006). Criminal Law  1120(3)

Issue of whether trial court erred in excluding, for impeachment purposes, evidence of victim's use of drugs at, or about, same time as incident which was subject of victim's testimony, was preserved for appellate review of conviction for aggravated battery, even though defense counsel failed to make proffer of evidence, where record indicated that substance of evidence was made known at trial. Hammett v. State, App. 2 Dist., 908 So.2d 595 (2005). Criminal Law  1036.2

Evidence that other driver was intoxicated, while not admissible during state's case, became relevant when defendant testified that other driver came out of nowhere to cause accident that resulted in five-car collision, as opposed to prosecution's theory that defendant and other driver's drag racing caused accident, and evidence was thus admissible in prosecution for culpable negligence and manslaughter by culpable negligence; however, defendant did not preserve issue for appellate review because he failed to reoffer evidence of intoxication during defense case. Persaud v. State, App. 4 Dist., 755 So.2d 150 (2000). Automobiles  354(4); Automobiles  354(13); Criminal Law  1036.1(3.1)

Defense counsel's proffer of alleged accomplice's impeachment testimony in murder prosecution was sufficient to satisfy statutory requirement for preservation of any error in trial court's refusing to allow such testimony. Lee v. State, App. 1 Dist., 729 So.2d 975 (1999), rehearing denied. Criminal Law  1036.2

Defense counsel's failure to make proffer regarding relevancy and materiality of testimony of juvenile's mother did not preclude review of issue of whether mother's testimony was relevant, where defense counsel attempted to proffer mother's testimony, but proffer was cut off by trial court. G.A. v. State, App. 3 Dist., 549 So.2d 1203 (1989). Infants  243

Defendant's failure to proffer proposed rebuttal testimony was not fatal to his appeal where substance of excluded testimony was apparent since it would have been necessarily limited to refuting State's evidence tending to prove defendant's predisposition toward drug trafficking on the issue of entrapment. Reaves v. State, App. 5 Dist., 531 So.2d 401 (1988). Criminal Law  1035(10)

Party against whom a ruling of exclusion has been made must make a proffer of the proposed testimony so that the trial and appellate courts may be able to evaluate its weight, relevancy, and competency in determining the effect of its exclusion, since appellate review of an exclusion that has not been proffered on the record would require improper speculation as to what the excluded witness would have said as well as what effect, if any, it would have had on the proceedings. Nava v. State, App. 4 Dist., 450 So.2d 606 (1984), cause dismissed 508 So.2d 14. Criminal Law  670

Absence of offer of proof as to what testimony was expected from police officer to whom question concerning disciplinary investigations had been propounded precluded review of alleged error in sustaining State's objection to question. A. McD. v. State, App. 3 Dist., 422 So.2d 336 (1982). Criminal Law  1036.1(9)

Restriction of cross-examination cannot constitute fundamental error where party fails to make an offer of proof since, as a result of such failure, there is an absence of material in record to disclose error. A. McD. v. State, App. 3 Dist., 422 So.2d 336 (1982). Criminal Law  1036.1(9)

Where defense counsel asked that he be allowed to proffer testimony that witness was coerced by State into agreeing to testify and adhere to her original statement and where, after trial court denied such proffer, everything that could have been established on proffer was allowed by court through testimony of witness and police officer, trial court did not err in denying proffer. Williams v. State, App. 1 Dist., 353 So.2d 956 (1978). Criminal Law  670

Where State voluntarily withdrew its proffer of incriminating statements made by defendant in hospital after robbery, apparently because statements would have been inadmissible in that they were obtained while defendant was in custody prior to his having or effectively waiving counsel, and defendant thereafter took the stand on his own behalf and, after giving testimony on direct, denied his ever having admitted his guilt on cross-examination, error, if any, in permitting State over objection on rebuttal to offer testimony of officers who had taken incriminating statements from defendant was harmless. Nowlin v. State, App. 4 Dist., 320 So.2d 468 (1975), remanded 346 So.2d 1020. Criminal Law  1168(2)

head.head.info: 222. Assault, criminal cases

para.paratext: In prosecution for assault with intent to rape, admission of articles of clothing worn by prosecutrix at time of alleged assault was not shown to be reversible error, where record failed to disclose any change in condition of clothing at time of assault and at time it was offered and admitted in evidence. Luttrell v. State, 150 Fla. 809, 9 So.2d 93 (1942). Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

head.head.info: 223. Breaking and entering, criminal cases

para.paratext: Defendant was not entitled to reversal of conviction for conspiracy to enter building with intent to steal money insured by Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on ground of overruling of motion to suppress evidence obtained from him by Mexican officers at time of his arrest, where no evidence of fruits of search was ever offered in jury's presence. Hardin v. U. S., 1965, 340 F.2d 711. Criminal Law  1168(1)

Where state's evidence in chief was sufficient to establish that particular corporation, as tenant, was in possession of premises at time of alleged breaking and entering, any error in permitting state, over defendant's objections, to reopen case to adduce additional evidence as to ownership of premises was harmless. Young v. State, App. 3 Dist., 160 So.2d 719 (1964). Criminal Law  1168(2)

In prosecution for breaking and entering, admitting transcript of testimony of complaining witnesses adduced at preliminary hearing before county judge was harmful error. Davis v. State, 65 So.2d 307 (1953). Criminal Law  539(1); Criminal Law  1169.1(4)

In prosecution for breaking and entering and for receiving and concealing stolen goods, admitting over timely objection evidence obtained by searching dwelling, where neither warrant nor affidavit described objects to be seized, was reversible error. Gildrie v. State, 94 Fla. 134, 113 So. 704 (1927). Criminal Law  1169.1(8)

head.head.info: 224. Drug abuse, criminal cases

para.paratext: Brief references to discovery of marijuana cigarette butts in defendant's apartment in testimony by officers who searched apartment were not sufficiently prejudicial to require new trial in prosecution for possession of heroin with intent to distribute. U. S. v. Polite, 1974, 489 F.2d 679, certiorari denied 95 S.Ct. 99, 419 U.S. 854, 42 L.Ed.2d 87. Criminal Law  1169.1(2.1)

Where trial court erroneously refused to suppress tangible evidence, judgment was reversed and cause remanded with directions that appellant be accorded opportunity to withdraw his plea of nolo contendere to charges of violating Drug Abuse Law. Wallace v. State, App. 4 Dist., 321 So.2d 97 (1975). Criminal Law  1168(1)

In prosecution for sale of marijuana, trial judge did not commit reversible error when he excluded testimony of the polytypic nature of cannabis. Walker v. State, App. 3 Dist., 318 So.2d 519 (1975). Criminal Law  1170(1)

head.head.info: 225. Embezzlement, criminal cases

para.paratext: In prosecution of school superintendent for embezzlement of school materials, evidence of work and labor and services performed by school employees for superintendent was inadmissible, and the error was prejudicial. Farnell v. State, App. 2 Dist., 214 So.2d 753 (1968). Criminal Law  338(1); Criminal Law  1169.1(4)

In embezzlement prosecution, admission in evidence, over defendant's objection, of copy of a final judgment in a civil action involving items as enumerated in counts of information charging embezzlement, constituted prejudicial error. Lawton v. State, 152 Fla. 821, 13 So.2d 211 (1943). Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

head.head.info: 226. Fraud, criminal cases

para.paratext: Where certified file from Arizona Real Estate Department was authoritative indication that the state had given permission to defendants to sell advertised land and the file would tend to show that defendants were not knowingly engaged in fraudulent scheme, trial court's exclusion of the file from evidence in prosecution for use of mails to defraud was reversible error. U. S. v. Diamond, 1970, 430 F.2d 688. Criminal Law  429(1); Criminal Law  1170(1)

In prosecutions for mail fraud and for fraudulent interstate transactions arising out of sale of securities in connection with a new corporation organized by defendant for purpose of manufacturing paper from a new process, cumulative effect of errors occurring in trial, including testimony to the effect that stockholders had borrowed money on insurance to make investment and reference of prosecuting attorney to defendant as a “con” man, required reversal of conviction. Getchell v. U. S., 1960, 282 F.2d 681, rehearing denied 283 F.2d 695. Criminal Law  1169.1(2.1); Criminal Law  1171.6

head.head.info: 227. Gambling, criminal cases

para.paratext: Where defendant was charged with using United States mails with intent to promote or facilitate illegal gambling activity, admission of defendant's income tax returns from which jury could draw highly likely inference that defendant was an income tax evader and which disclosed nothing connecting defendant with gambling was highly prejudicial and required reversal of conviction. South v. U. S., 1966, 368 F.2d 202. Criminal Law  338(7); Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

Where defendant, who was charged with conspiracy to set up and promote lottery and with various substantive offenses under lottery statute, was convicted of various substantive offenses but was acquitted of conspiracy charge by jury, refusal of trial court to give instructions on effect of evidence and testimony relating to conspiracy count and failure of trial court to exclude all evidence as to acts, conversations, and transactions of others at time when defendant was not involved in alleged conspiracy where not reversible errors. Smith v. State, App. 2 Dist., 114 So.2d 363 (1959), certiorari denied 117 So.2d 843. Criminal Law  1169.1(2.1); Criminal Law  1173.2(9)

In view of fact that evidence of activities and admissions of person charged with engaging in lottery were such that jury could come to no other conclusion that that such person was guilty of violating lottery law, any error in permitting witness to identify certain third person as man who had been convicted the day before was not harmful. Fletcher v. State, 65 So.2d 845 (1953). Criminal Law  1169.1(2.1)

Admitting in evidence in prosecution for unlawful possession of lottery tickets, money and lottery tickets seized in unlawful search of automobile over defendants' objections and motion to suppress the evidence, constituted reversible error. Kraemer v. State, 60 So.2d 615 (1952). Criminal Law  392.15(9); Criminal Law  1169.1(8)

head.head.info: 228. Homicide, criminal cases

para.paratext: In manslaughter prosecution charging, inter alia, death due to operation of car by defendant while intoxicated, it was reversible error to admit, over objection, evidence of alcoholic hospitalization two and a half years before the accident and hospitalization “for her nerves,” not shown to have involved alcohol, three years before, where neither hospitalization was shown to have been related to the driving of a car and there was no showing of any continuing alcoholism or other interim connection after release. Anthony v. State, App. 2 Dist., 246 So.2d 600 (1971), certiorari denied 249 So.2d 441. Criminal Law  384; Criminal Law  1169.1(3)

Permitting liquor store clerk to testify that defendant purchased liquor two or three times a week for period of over two years prior to fatal collision and that defendant had stated that he “had a problem” was prejudicial error which required reversal of conviction of manslaughter by intoxicated motorists. Wadsworth v. State, App. 4 Dist., 201 So.2d 836 (1967), quashed 210 So.2d 4. Criminal Law  376; Criminal Law  1169.1(6)

Statement made by victim to witness, some eight minutes after shooting occurred, that “A man tried to rob me, I have been hurt; I need help,” where it was no part of any robbery or an integral part of a felonious assault or a part of the main transaction, which was the unlawful killing of the victim, was inadmissible as hearsay, and could not be rescued by res gestae theory, and its admission in murder case was prejudicial error. Williams v. State, App. 2 Dist., 188 So.2d 320 (1966), certiorari discharged 198 So.2d 21. Criminal Law  366(6); Criminal Law  1169.1(9)

In prosecution for manslaughter by operation of motor vehicle while intoxicated, admitting evidence as to actual facts concerning collision and its immediate results was not prejudicial error, though such evidence disclosed that persons other than deceased were injured in collision. Blair v. State, App. 3 Dist., 161 So.2d 233 (1964), certiorari denied 166 So.2d 753. Criminal Law  1169.1(2.1)

Evidence that arsenic was found in exhumed bodies of defendant's deceased husband and deceased friend, who died about ten years before alleged murder, was inadmissible in prosecution for murder of deceased who was killed by arsenic, and admission of that evidence was prejudicial error. Norris v. State, App. 1 Dist., 158 So.2d 803 (1963), certiorari discharged 168 So.2d 541. Criminal Law  338(1); Criminal Law  1169.1(3)

In prosecution for murder of wife, permitting medical examiner to testify that he had examined another body at same address and that it was the body of a man and use of pronoun “him” instead of “her” in charge defining murder were not prejudicial to defendant, in view of detailed account of both homicides given by defendant in statement to police, numerous references in record to body of slain man, made without objection, and fact that the two homicides were so closely related as to amount to one transaction. Meade v. State, 96 So.2d 776 (1957), certiorari denied 78 S.Ct. 351, 355 U.S. 920, 2 L.Ed.2d 279. Criminal Law  1169.1(3); Criminal Law  1172.1(5)

In manslaughter prosecution based on charge that defendant had operated an automobile in a culpably negligent manner in killing pedestrian struck by the automobile, error, if any, in admitting evidence of traffic sign, which indicated speed limit at place of accident to be much less than that at which defendant was driving, without proof that the sign had been placed there by lawful authority was harmless in view of fact that the area involved was congested, and that statute regulating speed was applicable to such situation. Johnson v. State, 92 So.2d 651 (1957). Criminal Law  1169.1(3)

In prosecution for homicide, though photograph showed hideous scene with dead woman stretched on sidewalk in pool of blood, admission was not reversible error in view of fact that they showed knife near hand of dead woman and same corroborated testimony of defendant. Thomas v. State, 59 So.2d 517 (1952). Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

In prosecution for murder during robbery, error, if any, in admitting hat worn by codefendant at time of holdup, where defendant testified he did not have hat, was harmless. Milligan v. State, 109 Fla. 219, 147 So. 260 (1933). Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

In a prosecution for a homicide by shooting, the admission of testimony of a witness as to a conversation between the defendant and the person shot on the day after the fatal shooting, in which conversation the mortally wounded person indicated resentment towards the defendant, and also that he thought the shooting was unnecessary, was error, the statements by decedent not being a part of the res gestae and not dying declarations; and such error was necessarily prejudicial to the defendant. Williamson v. State, 85 Fla. 188, 95 So. 569 (1923). Criminal Law  1169.1(9); Homicide  1090(3)

head.head.info: 229. Jury tampering, criminal cases

para.paratext: Error in admitting testimony that defendant's father attempted to keep witness from grand jury was reversible, guilt not being clear. Duke v. State, 106 Fla. 205, 142 So. 886 (1932). Criminal Law  1169.1(1)

head.head.info: 230. Larceny, criminal cases

para.paratext: Reading of grand jury testimony of coindictee during which prosecution had stated that they had information that coindictee met with a defendant and others to arrange for sale of stolen stock was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt where the prosecution had already presented its evidence and jury was aware of reasons for reference to the alleged meeting between coindictee and a defendant. U. S. v. Iacovetti, 1972, 466 F.2d 1147, certiorari denied 93 S.Ct. 963, 410 U.S. 908, 35 L.Ed.2d 270, certiorari denied 93 S.Ct. 973, 410 U.S. 908, 35 L.Ed.2d 270. Criminal Law  1169.1(4)

Admission, in prosecution for receiving and concealing stolen motor vehicle in interstate commerce in violation of Dyer Act, of evidence concerning existence of automobile theft ring did not unduly prejudice defendant where unequivocal testimony of two members of theft ring was that defendant had never been member of their group and that they had only sold him the one automobile in question rendering de minimus likelihood that defendant was implicated in wrongdoing of others in minds of jury. Powell v. U. S., 1969, 410 F.2d 710. Criminal Law  1169.1(4)

Transactions between defendant and motor vehicle authorities and the OPA, after defendant had taken an automobile and transported the same to another state, knowing the automobile belonged to another, could not justify the taking and exclusion of evidence of such transactions was harmless. Jeffers v. U.S., 1945, 151 F.2d 587. Automobiles  341; Criminal Law  1170(1)

Evidence that at least partly as result of default of defendant, charged with grand larceny, in making payments on mortgage obtained by home owner to pay supplier of materials used by defendant to construct addition to home, owner lost the home, was inadmissible, but admission of the evidence did not vitiate guilty verdict, considering the entire record. Winnemore v. State, App. 2 Dist., 150 So.2d 277 (1963). Criminal Law  338(7); Criminal Law  1169.1(4)

In prosecution for conspiracy to commit crime of larceny of automobiles, absence of evidence to connect defendant or his alleged coconspirators with certain automobiles described in indictment made it error to receive testimony from owners of such vehicles to effect that their automobiles had been stolen; and since there was no way to know what effect or influence that damaging evidence could have had on conclusion reached by jury, such error required reversal. Weiss v. State, App. 3 Dist., 124 So.2d 528 (1960). Criminal Law  338(4); Criminal Law  1169.1(4)

head.head.info: 231. Narcotics, criminal cases

para.paratext: Permitting police officer to testify over defendant's objection, in prosecution for uttering a forged prescription for a narcotic drug, that in his opinion certain scratch marks found on defendant's arms at time of defendant's arrest were the result of the use of heroin was prejudicial error. Baffuto v. State, App. 3 Dist., 187 So.2d 79 (1966). Criminal Law  338(7); Criminal Law  1169.9

head.head.info: 232. Perjury, criminal cases

para.paratext: In prosecutions for perjury and subornation of perjury, it was prejudicial error to allow testimony to be introduced on question of motives of a witness who disclosed a plan to violate the election laws, since such testimony painted defendants in an unfavorable light, and was completely immaterial on question of whether two of the defendants testified falsely before the grand jury as to their having been at the scene of an alleged payoff, and as to whether two of the other defendants induced them to testify accordingly. Gordon v. State, 104 So.2d 524 (1958). Criminal Law  1169.1(7); Perjury  32(2)

In prosecution for perjury, admission of testimony and record with exhibits offered by the state when defendant was on trial in the same court for the crime of grand larceny and acquitted was not reversible error. McKay v. State, 37 So.2d 698 (1948). Criminal Law  1169.1(2.1)

head.head.info: 233. Rape, criminal cases

para.paratext: Where evidence of guilt was overwhelming, rape convictions would not be reversed for claimed improper statements or questions by state or answers of witnesses. Williams v. State, App. 3 Dist., 243 So.2d 215 (1971), certiorari denied 249 So.2d 686. Criminal Law  1169.1(2.1); Criminal Law  1171.8(1)

Admission into evidence of gun wielded by one of participants in rape and of rape victim's dress was not harmful or prejudicial error. McClendon v. State, 196 So.2d 905 (1967). Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

Admission of revolver taken by police from automobile of one of alleged participants in rape which victim's fiance stated was “similar” to that wielded by defendant's companion during commission of rape was not harmful error, even though identification of gun as that involved in crime was not established. Newman v. State, 196 So.2d 897 (1967). Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

Certain physical evidence offered by state in rape prosecution and certain remarks made by state attorney in his closing arguments before the jury did not require reversal of conviction. Pitts v. State, 185 So.2d 164 (1966), vacated in part 92 S.Ct. 2856, 408 U.S. 941, 33 L.Ed.2d 765. Criminal Law  1169.1(10); Criminal Law  1171.1(1)

Admission of evidence of mother of alleged victim, with reference to details of outcry made after rape was alleged to have been committed, was reversible error. Custer v. State, 159 Fla. 574, 34 So.2d 100 (1947). Criminal Law  1169.1(9); Rape  48(2)

head.head.info: 234. Robbery, criminal cases

para.paratext: Examination of record showed that it was unlikely that jury, in prosecution for conspiracy to commit bank robbery and for possession of stolen bank money, after careful and detailed instructions on theory of conspiracy would infer bad character on part of defendant from references to juvenile offenses of coconspirator who was not on trial with defendant, and no prejudice to defendant was shown because of descriptive comments of two prosecution witnesses concerning such coconspirator. U. S. v. Grant, 1975, 510 F.2d 137. Criminal Law  1169.1(2.1)

Admission in evidence of FBI agent's testimony of seeing the defendant, his wife and the perpetrator of bank robbery together while agent had a house under surveillance approximately five weeks before the bank robbery and that the purpose of the surveillance was because there had been a series of bank robberies, that the occupant of the house under surveillance was suspected of being a bank robber and was expected to leave Florida to go to New Orleans in order to commit a bank robbery constituted prejudicial error in prosecution for bank robbery and conspiracy to commit the robbery. U. S. v. Vosper, 1974, 493 F.2d 433. Criminal Law  345; Criminal Law  1169.1(4)

Admission of motel registration cards in prosecution for bank robbery, if erroneous, was not so prejudicial as to constitute reversible error even if defendant was given no chance to see them before trial despite court order requiring government to permit defendant to inspect any papers, books, photographs and objects or other tangible things which the government had in its possession. Whalen v. U.S., 1966, 367 F.2d 468. Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

Admission of evidence concerning defendant's escape from prison ward at hospital at date prior to that of alleged robbery was at most harmless error in view of other evidence presented. Wingate v. State, App. 3 Dist., 232 So.2d 44 (1970), certiorari denied 237 So.2d 764, certiorari denied 91 S.Ct. 467, 400 U.S. 994, 27 L.Ed.2d 443. Criminal Law  1169.1(4)

In robbery prosecution, admission into evidence of a pistol, after the unintentionally misleading statement to defendants' attorney that pistol discovered at scene of crime was the property of alleged victim of the robbery, was not so prejudicial to defendants as to require a new trial, in view of the record. Smith v. State, App. 3 Dist., 199 So.2d 503 (1967). Criminal Law  1169.1(10)

head.head.info: 235. Tax evasion, criminal cases

para.paratext: Testimony as to the impecunious condition of person whom taxpayer, charged with evasion of income taxes, claimed to have paid sums which government charged taxpayer should have reported as income on his tax return was relevant as a part of the overall circumstances of case, and its admission would not constitute reversible error since its entire rejection would still leave substantial evidence of guilt. Cohen v. U.S., 1966, 363 F.2d 321, certiorari denied 87 S.Ct. 395, 385 U.S. 957, 17 L.Ed.2d 303. Criminal Law  1169.1(2.1); Internal Revenue  5294

In prosecution of principal defendant for possession of nontax-paid whisky and for concealment of such whisky, any error in admitting oral testimony as to alleged illicit whisky and unstamped containers was harmless where the emphasis at the trial was on the illegality of the search and seizure and it was recognized by all that illicit liquor was involved. Dicks v. U.S., 1958, 253 F.2d 713. Criminal Law  1169.1(2.1)

Where defendant was acquitted of substantive charge of unlawful possession of still, the res judicata doctrine was applicable and the government could not establish the fact of possession of identical still at identical time and place in a subsequent prosecution for conspiracy to violate Internal Revenue Code by unlawful possession of still; the erroneous admission of such evidence was harmful. Yawn v. U.S., 1957, 244 F.2d 235. Criminal Law  1169.1(2.1); Judgment  751

In prosecution for willful evasion of income tax, admission of evidence, over defendant's objection, having to do with moneys taken to New York by accused's wife, and with expenditures made by them for wedding party for their daughter, was prejudicial error. Blumberg v. U.S., 1955, 222 F.2d 496. Criminal Law  338(7); Criminal Law  1169.1(2.1)

In prosecution for willful evasion of income tax, statement by prosecutor that government was not claiming that money carried by accused's wife to New York to provide wedding for accused's daughter was additional income because it couldn't prove it, taken in connection with statements of prosecutor about wedding and money spent, did not render admission of such evidence harmless error. Blumberg v. U.S., 1955, 222 F.2d 496. Criminal Law  1169.1(2.1)

In prosecution for violating the internal revenue laws, where no error attended the conviction on first count and judgment and sentence was for a term less than the maximum which could have been imposed for violation of first count alone, it was unnecessary to consider correctness of defendant's claim that it was error to refuse to quash search warrant and to reject evidence on which conviction on second count was based. Rogers v. U.S., 1942, 128 F.2d 973. Criminal Law  1169.1(8)
